Parsing [sent. 15 len. 254]: Daring burglaries by armed men , and highway robberies , took place in the capital itself every night ; families were publicly cautioned not to go out of town without removing their furniture to upholsterers ' warehouses for security ; the highwayman in the dark was a City tradesman in the light , and , being recognised and challenged by his fellow-tradesman whom he stopped in his character of `` the Captain , '' gallantly shot him through the head and rode away ; the mall was waylaid by seven robbers , and the guard shot three dead , and then got shot dead himself by the other four , `` in consequence of the failure of his ammunition : '' after which the mall was robbed in peace ; that magnificent potentate , the Lord Mayor of London , was made to stand and deliver on Turnham Green , by one highwayman , who despoiled the illustrious creature in sight of all his retinue ; prisoners in London gaols fought battles with their turnkeys , and the majesty of the law fired blunderbusses in among them , loaded with rounds of shot and ball ; thieves snipped off diamond crosses from the necks of noble lords at Court drawing-rooms ; musketeers went into St. Giles 's , to search for contraband goods , and the mob fired on the musketeers , and the musketeers fired on the mob , and nobody thought any of these occurrences much out of the common way .

Parsing [sent. 158 len. 28]: III The Night Shadows A wonderful fact to reflect upon , that every human creature is constituted to be that profound secret and mystery to every other .
Parsing [sent. 159 len. 68]: A solemn consideration , when I enter a great city by night , that every one of those darkly clustered houses encloses its own secret ; that every room in every one of them encloses its own secret ; that every beating heart in the hundreds of thousands of breasts there , is , in some of its imaginings , a secret to the heart nearest it !

Parsing [sent. 206 len. 9]: Sometimes the broken reply was , `` Wait !
Parsing [sent. 207 len. 12]: It would kill me if I saw her too soon . ''
Parsing [sent. 208 len. 24]: Sometimes , it was given in a tender rain of tears , and then it was , `` Take me to her . ''
Parsing [sent. 209 len. 19]: Sometimes it was staring and bewildered , and then it was , `` I do n't know her .
Parsing [sent. 210 len. 6]: I do n't understand . ''
Parsing [sent. 211 len. 41]: After such imaginary discourse , the passenger in his fancy would dig , and dig , dig -- now with a spade , now with a great key , now with his hands -- to dig this wretched creature out .
Parsing [sent. 212 len. 22]: Got out at last , with earth hanging about his face and hair , he would suddenly fan away to dust .
Parsing [sent. 213 len. 25]: The passenger would then start to himself , and lower the window , to get the reality of mist and rain on his cheek .
Parsing [sent. 214 len. 50]: Yet even when his eyes were opened on the mist and rain , on the moving patch of light from the lamps , and the hedge at the roadside retreating by jerks , the night shadows outside the coach would fall into the train of the night shadows within .
Parsing [sent. 215 len. 38]: The real Banking-house by Temple Bar , the real business of the past day , the real strong rooms , the real express sent after him , and the real message returned , would all be there .
Parsing [sent. 216 len. 20]: Out of the midst of them , the ghostly face would rise , and he would accost it again .
Parsing [sent. 217 len. 6]: `` Buried how long ? ''
Parsing [sent. 218 len. 6]: `` Almost eighteen years . ''
Parsing [sent. 219 len. 9]: `` I hope you care to live ? ''
Parsing [sent. 220 len. 7]: `` I ca n't say . ''
Parsing [sent. 221 len. 63]: Dig -- dig -- dig -- until an impatient movement from one of the two passengers would admonish him to pull up the window , draw his arm securely through the leathern strap , and speculate upon the two slumbering forms , until his mind lost its hold of them , and they again slid away into the bank and the grave .
Parsing [sent. 222 len. 6]: `` Buried how long ? ''
Parsing [sent. 223 len. 6]: `` Almost eighteen years . ''
Parsing [sent. 224 len. 12]: `` You had abandoned all hope of being dug out ? ''
Parsing [sent. 225 len. 5]: `` Long ago . ''
Parsing [sent. 226 len. 47]: The words were still in his hearing as just spoken -- distinctly in his hearing as ever spoken words had been in his life -- when the weary passenger started to the consciousness of daylight , and found that the shadows of the night were gone .
Parsing [sent. 227 len. 13]: He lowered the window , and looked out at the rising sun .
Parsing [sent. 228 len. 48]: There was a ridge of ploughed land , with a plough upon it where it had been left last night when the horses were unyoked ; beyond , a quiet coppice-wood , in which many leaves of burning red and golden yellow still remained upon the trees .
Parsing [sent. 229 len. 24]: Though the earth was cold and wet , the sky was clear , and the sun rose bright , placid , and beautiful .
Parsing [sent. 230 len. 5]: `` Eighteen years ! ''
Parsing [sent. 231 len. 9]: said the passenger , looking at the sun .
Parsing [sent. 232 len. 6]: `` Gracious Creator of day !
Parsing [sent. 233 len. 9]: To be buried alive for eighteen years ! ''
Parsing [sent. 234 len. 34]: IV The Preparation When the mail got successfully to Dover , in the course of the forenoon , the head drawer at the Royal George Hotel opened the coach-door as his custom was .
Parsing [sent. 235 len. 27]: He did it with some flourish of ceremony , for a mail journey from London in winter was an achievement to congratulate an adventurous traveller upon .
Parsing [sent. 236 len. 28]: By that time , there was only one adventurous traveller left be congratulated : for the two others had been set down at their respective roadside destinations .
Parsing [sent. 237 len. 29]: The mildewy inside of the coach , with its damp and dirty straw , its disageeable smell , and its obscurity , was rather like a larger dog-kennel .
Parsing [sent. 238 len. 38]: Mr. Lorry , the passenger , shaking himself out of it in chains of straw , a tangle of shaggy wrapper , flapping hat , and muddy legs , was rather like a larger sort of dog .

Parsing [sent. 253 len. 67]: The Concord bed-chamber being always assigned to a passenger by the mail , and passengers by the mail being always heavily wrapped up from head to foot , the room had the odd interest for the establishment of the Royal George , that although but one kind of man was seen to go into it , all kinds and varieties of men came out of it .
Parsing [sent. 254 len. 78]: Consequently , another drawer , and two porters , and several maids and the landlady , were all loitering by accident at various points of the road between the Concord and the coffee-room , when a gentleman of sixty , formally dressed in a brown suit of clothes , pretty well worn , but very well kept , with large square cuffs and large flaps to the pockets , passed along on his way to his breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 255 len. 16]: The coffee-room had no other occupant , that forenoon , than the gentleman in brown .
Parsing [sent. 256 len. 40]: His breakfast-table was drawn before the fire , and as he sat , with its light shining on him , waiting for the meal , he sat so still , that he might have been sitting for his portrait .
Parsing [sent. 257 len. 45]: Very orderly and methodical he looked , with a hand on each knee , and a loud watch ticking a sonorous sermon under his flapped waist-coat , as though it pitted its gravity and longevity against the levity and evanescence of the brisk fire .
Parsing [sent. 258 len. 43]: He had a good leg , and was a little vain of it , for his brown stockings fitted sleek and close , and were of a fine texture ; his shoes and buckles , too , though plain , were trim .
Parsing [sent. 259 len. 48]: He wore an odd little sleek crisp flaxen wig , setting very close to his head : which wig , it is to be presumed , was made of hair , but which looked far more as though it were spun from filaments of silk or glass .
Parsing [sent. 260 len. 44]: His linen , though not of a fineness in accordance with his stockings , was as white as the tops of the waves that broke upon the neighbouring beach , or the specks of sail that glinted in the sunlight far at sea .
Parsing [sent. 261 len. 50]: A face habitually suppressed and quieted , was still lighted up under the quaint wig by a pair of moist bright eyes that it must have cost their owner , in years gone by , some pains to drill to the composed and reserved expression of Tellson 's Bank .
Parsing [sent. 262 len. 22]: He had a healthy colour in his cheeks , and his face , though lined , bore few traces of anxiety .
Parsing [sent. 263 len. 36]: But , perhaps the confidential bachelor clerks in Tellson 's Bank were principally occupied with the cares of other people ; and perhaps second-hand cares , like second-hand clothes , come easily off and on .
Parsing [sent. 264 len. 20]: Completing his resemblance to a man who was sitting for his portrait , Mr. Lorry dropped off to sleep .

Parsing [sent. 288 len. 53]: Rounding his mouth and both his eyes , as he stepped backward from the table , the waiter shifted his napkin from his right arm to his left , dropped into a comfortable attitude , and stood surveying the guest while he ate and drank , as from an observatory or watchtower .
Parsing [sent. 289 len. 11]: According to the immemorial usage of waiters in all ages .
Parsing [sent. 290 len. 18]: When Mr. Lorry had finished his breakfast , he went out for a stroll on the beach .
Parsing [sent. 291 len. 29]: The little narrow , crooked town of Dover hid itself away from the beach , and ran its head into the chalk cliffs , like a marine ostrich .
Parsing [sent. 292 len. 30]: The beach was a desert of heaps of sea and stones tumbling wildly about , and the sea did what it liked , and what it liked was destruction .
Parsing [sent. 293 len. 20]: It thundered at the town , and thundered at the cliffs , and brought the coast down , madly .
Parsing [sent. 294 len. 39]: The air among the houses was of so strong a piscatory flavour that one might have supposed sick fish went up to be dipped in it , as sick people went down to be dipped in the sea .
Parsing [sent. 295 len. 36]: A little fishing was done in the port , and a quantity of strolling about by night , and looking seaward : particularly at those times when the tide made , and was near flood .
Parsing [sent. 296 len. 29]: Small tradesmen , who did no business whatever , sometimes unaccountably realised large fortunes , and it was remarkable that nobody in the neighbourhood could endure a lamplighter .
Parsing [sent. 297 len. 45]: As the day declined into the afternoon , and the air , which had been at intervals clear enough to allow the French coast to be seen , became again charged with mist and vapour , Mr. Lorry 's thoughts seemed to cloud too .
Parsing [sent. 298 len. 39]: When it was dark , and he sat before the coffee-room fire , awaiting his dinner as he had awaited his breakfast , his mind was busily digging , digging , digging , in the live red coals .
Parsing [sent. 299 len. 31]: A bottle of good claret after dinner does a digger in the red coals no harm , otherwise than as it has a tendency to throw him out of work .
Parsing [sent. 300 len. 67]: Mr. Lorry had been idle a long time , and had just poured out his last glassful of wine with as complete an appearance of satisfaction as is ever to be found in an elderly gentleman of a fresh complexion who has got to the end of a bottle , when a rattling of wheels came up the narrow street , and rumbled into the inn-yard .
Parsing [sent. 301 len. 7]: He set down his glass untouched .

Parsing [sent. 303 len. 3]: said he .

Parsing [sent. 307 len. 42]: The gentleman from Tellson 's had nothing left for it but to empty his glass with an air of stolid desperation , settle his odd little flaxen wig at the ears , and follow the waiter to Miss Manette 's apartment .
Parsing [sent. 308 len. 24]: It was a large , dark room , furnished in a funereal manner with black horsehair , and loaded with heavy dark tables .
Parsing [sent. 309 len. 58]: These had been oiled and oiled , until the two tall candles on the table in the middle of the room were gloomily reflected on every leaf ; as if THEY were buried , in deep graves of black mahogany , and no light to speak of could be expected from them until they were dug out .
Parsing [sent. 310 len. 86]: The obscurity was so difficult to penetrate that Mr. Lorry , picking his way over the well-worn Turkey carpet , supposed Miss Manette to be , for the moment , in some adjacent room , until , having got past the two tall candles , he saw standing to receive him by the table between them and the fire , a young lady of not more than seventeen , in a riding-cloak , and still holding her straw travelling-hat by its ribbon in her hand .
Parsing [sent. 311 len. 135]: As his eyes rested on a short , slight , pretty figure , a quantity of golden hair , a pair of blue eyes that met his own with an inquiring look , and a forehead with a singular capacity -LRB- remembering how young and smooth it was -RRB- , of rifting and knitting itself into an expression that was not quite one of perplexity , or wonder , or alarm , or merely of a bright fixed attention , though it included all the four expressions-as his eyes rested on these things , a sudden vivid likeness passed before him , of a child whom he had held in his arms on the passage across that very Channel , one cold time , when the hail drifted heavily and the sea ran high .

Parsing [sent. 425 len. 6]: See now , see now !
Parsing [sent. 426 len. 12]: The best and the worst are known to you , now .
Parsing [sent. 427 len. 36]: You are well on your way to the poor wronged gentleman , and , with a fair sea voyage , and a fair land journey , you will be soon at his dear side . ''
Parsing [sent. 428 len. 32]: She repeated in the same tone , sunk to a whisper , `` I have been free , I have been happy , yet his Ghost has never haunted me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 429 len. 42]: `` Only one thing more , '' said Mr. Lorry , laying stress upon it as a wholesome means of enforcing her attention : `` he has been found under another name ; his own , long forgotten or long concealed .
Parsing [sent. 430 len. 32]: It would be worse than useless now to inquire which ; worse than useless to seek to know whether he has been for years overlooked , or always designedly held prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 431 len. 18]: It would be worse than useless now to make any inquiries , because it would be dangerous .
Parsing [sent. 432 len. 29]: Better not to mention the subject , anywhere or in any way , and to remove him -- for a while at all events -- out of France .
Parsing [sent. 433 len. 28]: Even I , safe as an Englishman , and even Tellson 's , important as they are to French credit , avoid all naming of the matter .
Parsing [sent. 434 len. 15]: I carry about me , not a scrap of writing openly referring to it .
Parsing [sent. 435 len. 7]: This is a secret service altogether .
Parsing [sent. 436 len. 27]: My credentials , entries , and memoranda , are all comprehended in the one line , ` Recalled to Life ; ' which may mean anything .
Parsing [sent. 437 len. 6]: But what is the matter !
Parsing [sent. 438 len. 7]: She does n't notice a word !
Parsing [sent. 439 len. 4]: Miss Manette ! ''
Parsing [sent. 440 len. 49]: Perfectly still and silent , and not even fallen back in her chair , she sat under his hand , utterly insensible ; with her eyes open and fixed upon him , and with that last expression looking as if it were carved or branded into her forehead .
Parsing [sent. 441 len. 31]: So close was her hold upon his arm , that he feared to detach himself lest he should hurt her ; therefore he called out loudly for assistance without moving .
Parsing [sent. 442 len. 109]: A wild-looking woman , whom even in his agitation , Mr. Lorry observed to be all of a red colour , and to have red hair , and to be dressed in some extraordinary tight-fitting fashion , and to have on her head a most wonderful bonnet like a Grenadier wooden measure , and good measure too , or a great Stilton cheese , came running into the room in advance of the inn servants , and soon settled the question of his detachment from the poor young lady , by laying a brawny hand upon his chest , and sending him flying back against the nearest wall .
Parsing [sent. 443 len. 12]: -LRB- `` I really think this must be a man ! ''
Parsing [sent. 444 len. 16]: was Mr. Lorry 's breathless reflection , simultaneously with his coming against the wall . -RRB-
Parsing [sent. 445 len. 9]: `` Why , look at you all ! ''
Parsing [sent. 446 len. 9]: bawled this figure , addressing the inn servants .
Parsing [sent. 447 len. 18]: `` Why do n't you go and fetch things , instead of standing there staring at me ?
Parsing [sent. 448 len. 12]: I am not so much to look at , am I ?
Parsing [sent. 449 len. 9]: Why do n't you go and fetch things ?
Parsing [sent. 450 len. 25]: I 'll let you know , if you do n't bring smelling-salts , cold water , and vinegar , quick , I will . ''
Parsing [sent. 451 len. 35]: There was an immediate dispersal for these restoratives , and she softly laid the patient on a sofa , and tended her with great skill and gentleness : calling her `` my precious ! ''
Parsing [sent. 452 len. 6]: and `` my bird ! ''
Parsing [sent. 453 len. 15]: and spreading her golden hair aside over her shoulders with great pride and care .
Parsing [sent. 454 len. 7]: `` And you in brown ! ''
Parsing [sent. 455 len. 28]: she said , indignantly turning to Mr. Lorry ; `` could n't you tell her what you had to tell her , without frightening her to death ?
Parsing [sent. 456 len. 14]: Look at her , with her pretty pale face and her cold hands .
Parsing [sent. 457 len. 9]: Do you call THAT being a Banker ? ''
Parsing [sent. 458 len. 84]: Mr. Lorry was so exceedingly disconcerted by a question so hard to answer , that he could only look on , at a distance , with much feebler sympathy and humility , while the strong woman , having banished the inn servants under the mysterious penalty of `` letting them know '' something not mentioned if they stayed there , staring , recovered her charge by a regular series of gradations , and coaxed her to lay her drooping head upon her shoulder .
Parsing [sent. 459 len. 14]: `` I hope she will do well now , '' said Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 460 len. 12]: `` No thanks to you in brown , if she does .
Parsing [sent. 461 len. 5]: My darling pretty ! ''
Parsing [sent. 462 len. 28]: `` I hope , '' said Mr. Lorry , after another pause of feeble sympathy and humility , `` that you accompany Miss Manette to France ? ''
Parsing [sent. 463 len. 8]: `` A likely thing , too ! ''
Parsing [sent. 464 len. 5]: replied the strong woman .
Parsing [sent. 465 len. 28]: `` If it was ever intended that I should go across salt water , do you suppose Providence would have cast my lot in an island ? ''
Parsing [sent. 466 len. 16]: This being another question hard to answer , Mr. Jarvis Lorry withdrew to consider it .
Parsing [sent. 467 len. 18]: V The Wine-shop A large cask of wine had been dropped and broken , in the street .
Parsing [sent. 468 len. 45]: The accident had happened in getting it out of a cart ; the cask had tumbled out with a run , the hoops had burst , and it lay on the stones just outside the door of the wine-shop , shattered like a walnut-shell .
Parsing [sent. 469 len. 24]: All the people within reach had suspended their business , or their idleness , to run to the spot and drink the wine .
Parsing [sent. 470 len. 56]: The rough , irregular stones of the street , pointing every way , and designed , one might have thought , expressly to lame all living creatures that approached them , had dammed it into little pools ; these were surrounded , each by its own jostling group or crowd , according to its size .
Parsing [sent. 471 len. 42]: Some men kneeled down , made scoops of their two hands joined , and sipped , or tried to help women , who bent over their shoulders , to sip , before the wine had all run out between their fingers .
Parsing [sent. 472 len. 103]: Others , men and women , dipped in the puddles with little mugs of mutilated earthenware , or even with handkerchiefs from women 's heads , which were squeezed dry into infants ' mouths ; others made small mud-embankments , to stem the wine as it ran ; others , directed by lookers-on up at high windows , darted here and there , to cut off little streams of wine that started away in new directions ; others devoted themselves to the sodden and lee-dyed pieces of the cask , licking , and even champing the moister wine-rotted fragments with eager relish .
Parsing [sent. 473 len. 56]: There was no drainage to carry off the wine , and not only did it all get taken up , but so much mud got taken up along with it , that there might have been a scavenger in the street , if anybody acquainted with it could have believed in such a miraculous presence .
Parsing [sent. 474 len. 29]: A shrill sound of laughter and of amused voices -- voices of men , women , and children -- resounded in the street while this wine game lasted .
Parsing [sent. 475 len. 12]: There was little roughness in the sport , and much playfulness .
Parsing [sent. 476 len. 57]: There was a special companionship in it , an observable inclination on the part of every one to join some other one , which led , especially among the luckier or lighter-hearted , to frolicsome embraces , drinking of healths , shaking of hands , and even joining of hands and dancing , a dozen together .
Parsing [sent. 477 len. 35]: When the wine was gone , and the places where it had been most abundant were raked into a gridiron-pattern by fingers , these demonstrations ceased , as suddenly as they had broken out .
Parsing [sent. 478 len. 110]: The man who had left his saw sticking in the firewood he was cutting , set it in motion again ; the women who had left on a door-step the little pot of hot ashes , at which she had been trying to soften the pain in her own starved fingers and toes , or in those of her child , returned to it ; men with bare arms , matted locks , and cadaverous faces , who had emerged into the winter light from cellars , moved away , to descend again ; and a gloom gathered on the scene that appeared more natural to it than sunshine .
Parsing [sent. 479 len. 30]: The wine was red wine , and had stained the ground of the narrow street in the suburb of Saint Antoine , in Paris , where it was spilled .
Parsing [sent. 480 len. 22]: It had stained many hands , too , and many faces , and many naked feet , and many wooden shoes .
Parsing [sent. 481 len. 44]: The hands of the man who sawed the wood , left red marks on the billets ; and the forehead of the woman who nursed her baby , was stained with the stain of the old rag she wound about her head again .
Parsing [sent. 482 len. 58]: Those who had been greedy with the staves of the cask , had acquired a tigerish smear about the mouth ; and one tall joker so besmirched , his head more out of a long squalid bag of a nightcap than in it , scrawled upon a wall with his finger dipped in muddy wine-lees -- BLOOD .
Parsing [sent. 483 len. 30]: The time was to come , when that wine too would be spilled on the street-stones , and when the stain of it would be red upon many there .
Parsing [sent. 484 len. 60]: And now that the cloud settled on Saint Antoine , which a momentary gleam had driven from his sacred countenance , the darkness of it was heavy-cold , dirt , sickness , ignorance , and want , were the lords in waiting on the saintly presence-nobles of great power all of them ; but , most especially the last .
Parsing [sent. 485 len. 59]: Samples of a people that had undergone a terrible grinding and regrinding in the mill , and certainly not in the fabulous mill which ground old people young , shivered at every corner , passed in and out at every doorway , looked from every window , fluttered in every vestige of a garment that the wind shook .
Parsing [sent. 486 len. 54]: The mill which had worked them down , was the mill that grinds young people old ; the children had ancient faces and grave voices ; and upon them , and upon the grown faces , and ploughed into every furrow of age and coming up afresh , was the sigh , Hunger .
Parsing [sent. 487 len. 5]: It was prevalent everywhere .
Parsing [sent. 488 len. 81]: Hunger was pushed out of the tall houses , in the wretched clothing that hung upon poles and lines ; Hunger was patched into them with straw and rag and wood and paper ; Hunger was repeated in every fragment of the small modicum of firewood that the man sawed off ; Hunger stared down from the smokeless chimneys , and started up from the filthy street that had no offal , among its refuse , of anything to eat .
Parsing [sent. 489 len. 37]: Hunger was the inscription on the baker 's shelves , written in every small loaf of his scanty stock of bad bread ; at the sausage-shop , in every dead-dog preparation that was offered for sale .
Parsing [sent. 490 len. 37]: Hunger rattled its dry bones among the roasting chestnuts in the turned cylinder ; Hunger was shred into atomics in every farthing porringer of husky chips of potato , fried with some reluctant drops of oil .
Parsing [sent. 491 len. 11]: Its abiding place was in all things fitted to it .
Parsing [sent. 492 len. 47]: A narrow winding street , full of offence and stench , with other narrow winding streets diverging , all peopled by rags and nightcaps , and all smelling of rags and nightcaps , and all visible things with a brooding look upon them that looked ill .
Parsing [sent. 493 len. 21]: In the hunted air of the people there was yet some wild-beast thought of the possibility of turning at bay .
Parsing [sent. 494 len. 43]: Depressed and slinking though they were , eyes of fire were not wanting among them ; nor compressed lips , white with what they suppressed ; nor foreheads knitted into the likeness of the gallows-rope they mused about enduring , or inflicting .
Parsing [sent. 495 len. 23]: The trade signs -LRB- and they were almost as many as the shops -RRB- were , all , grim illustrations of Want .
Parsing [sent. 496 len. 24]: The butcher and the porkman painted up , only the leanest scrags of meat ; the baker , the coarsest of meagre loaves .
Parsing [sent. 497 len. 27]: The people rudely pictured as drinking in the wine-shops , croaked over their scanty measures of thin wine and beer , and were gloweringly confidential together .
Parsing [sent. 498 len. 41]: Nothing was represented in a flourishing condition , save tools and weapons ; but , the cutler 's knives and axes were sharp and bright , the smith 's hammers were heavy , and the gunmaker 's stock was murderous .
Parsing [sent. 499 len. 29]: The crippling stones of the pavement , with their many little reservoirs of mud and water , had no footways , but broke off abruptly at the doors .
Parsing [sent. 500 len. 42]: The kennel , to make amends , ran down the middle of the street -- when it ran at all : which was only after heavy rains , and then it ran , by many eccentric fits , into the houses .
Parsing [sent. 501 len. 58]: Across the streets , at wide intervals , one clumsy lamp was slung by a rope and pulley ; at night , when the lamplighter had let these down , and lighted , and hoisted them again , a feeble grove of dim wicks swung in a sickly manner overhead , as if they were at sea .
Parsing [sent. 502 len. 17]: Indeed they were at sea , and the ship and crew were in peril of tempest .
Parsing [sent. 503 len. 60]: For , the time was to come , when the gaunt scarecrows of that region should have watched the lamplighter , in their idleness and hunger , so long , as to conceive the idea of improving on his method , and hauling up men by those ropes and pulleys , to flare upon the darkness of their condition .
Parsing [sent. 504 len. 39]: But , the time was not come yet ; and every wind that blew over France shook the rags of the scarecrows in vain , for the birds , fine of song and feather , took no warning .
Parsing [sent. 505 len. 46]: The wine-shop was a corner shop , better than most others in its appearance and degree , and the master of the wine-shop had stood outside it , in a yellow waistcoat and green breeches , looking on at the struggle for the lost wine .
Parsing [sent. 506 len. 19]: `` It 's not my affair , '' said he , with a final shrug of the shoulders .
Parsing [sent. 507 len. 9]: `` The people from the market did it .
Parsing [sent. 508 len. 6]: Let them bring another . ''
Parsing [sent. 509 len. 38]: There , his eyes happening to catch the tall joker writing up his joke , he called to him across the way : `` Say , then , my Gaspard , what do you do there ? ''
Parsing [sent. 510 len. 19]: The fellow pointed to his joke with immense significance , as is often the way with his tribe .
Parsing [sent. 511 len. 19]: It missed its mark , and completely failed , as is often the way with his tribe too .
Parsing [sent. 512 len. 4]: `` What now ?
Parsing [sent. 513 len. 10]: Are you a subject for the mad hospital ? ''
Parsing [sent. 514 len. 30]: said the wine-shop keeper , crossing the road , and obliterating the jest with a handful of mud , picked up for the purpose , and smeared over it .
Parsing [sent. 515 len. 10]: `` Why do you write in the public streets ?
Parsing [sent. 516 len. 19]: Is there -- tell me thou -- is there no other place to write such words in ? ''
Parsing [sent. 517 len. 21]: In his expostulation he dropped his cleaner hand -LRB- perhaps accidentally , perhaps not -RRB- upon the joker 's heart .
Parsing [sent. 518 len. 41]: The joker rapped it with his own , took a nimble spring upward , and came down in a fantastic dancing attitude , with one of his stained shoes jerked off his foot into his hand , and held out .
Parsing [sent. 519 len. 20]: A joker of an extremely , not to say wolfishly practical character , he looked , under those circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 520 len. 14]: `` Put it on , put it on , '' said the other .
Parsing [sent. 521 len. 11]: `` Call wine , wine ; and finish there . ''
Parsing [sent. 522 len. 42]: With that advice , he wiped his soiled hand upon the joker 's dress , such as it was -- quite deliberately , as having dirtied the hand on his account ; and then recrossed the road and entered the wine-shop .
Parsing [sent. 523 len. 44]: This wine-shop keeper was a bull-necked , martial-looking man of thirty , and he should have been of a hot temperament , for , although it was a bitter day , he wore no coat , but carried one slung over his shoulder .
Parsing [sent. 524 len. 18]: His shirt-sleeves were rolled up , too , and his brown arms were bare to the elbows .
Parsing [sent. 525 len. 17]: Neither did he wear anything more on his head than his own crisply-curling short dark hair .
Parsing [sent. 526 len. 18]: He was a dark man altogether , with good eyes and a good bold breadth between them .
Parsing [sent. 527 len. 50]: Good-humoured looking on the whole , but implacable-looking , too ; evidently a man of a strong resolution and a set purpose ; a man not desirable to be met , rushing down a narrow pass with a gulf on either side , for nothing would turn the man .
Parsing [sent. 528 len. 18]: Madame Defarge , his wife , sat in the shop behind the counter as he came in .
Parsing [sent. 529 len. 43]: Madame Defarge was a stout woman of about his own age , with a watchful eye that seldom seemed to look at anything , a large hand heavily ringed , a steady face , strong features , and great composure of manner .
Parsing [sent. 530 len. 33]: There was a character about Madame Defarge , from which one might have predicated that she did not often make mistakes against herself in any of the reckonings over which she presided .
Parsing [sent. 531 len. 34]: Madame Defarge being sensitive to cold , was wrapped in fur , and had a quantity of bright shawl twined about her head , though not to the concealment of her large earrings .
Parsing [sent. 532 len. 20]: Her knitting was before her , but she had laid it down to pick her teeth with a toothpick .
Parsing [sent. 533 len. 31]: Thus engaged , with her right elbow supported by her left hand , Madame Defarge said nothing when her lord came in , but coughed just one grain of cough .
Parsing [sent. 534 len. 55]: This , in combination with the lifting of her darkly defined eyebrows over her toothpick by the breadth of a line , suggested to her husband that he would do well to look round the shop among the customers , for any new customer who had dropped in while he stepped over the way .
Parsing [sent. 535 len. 28]: The wine-shop keeper accordingly rolled his eyes about , until they rested upon an elderly gentleman and a young lady , who were seated in a corner .
Parsing [sent. 536 len. 26]: Other company were there : two playing cards , two playing dominoes , three standing by the counter lengthening out a short supply of wine .
Parsing [sent. 537 len. 30]: As he passed behind the counter , he took notice that the elderly gentleman said in a look to the young lady , `` This is our man . ''
Parsing [sent. 538 len. 13]: `` What the devil do YOU do in that galley there ? ''
Parsing [sent. 539 len. 14]: said Monsieur Defarge to himself ; `` I do n't know you . ''
Parsing [sent. 540 len. 27]: But , he feigned not to notice the two strangers , and fell into discourse with the triumvirate of customers who were drinking at the counter .
Parsing [sent. 541 len. 8]: `` How goes it , Jacques ? ''
Parsing [sent. 542 len. 9]: said one of these three to Monsieur Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 543 len. 9]: `` Is all the spilt wine swallowed ? ''
Parsing [sent. 544 len. 11]: `` Every drop , Jacques , '' answered Monsieur Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 545 len. 36]: When this interchange of Christian name was effected , Madame Defarge , picking her teeth with her toothpick , coughed another grain of cough , and raised her eyebrows by the breadth of another line .
Parsing [sent. 546 len. 40]: `` It is not often , '' said the second of the three , addressing Monsieur Defarge , `` that many of these miserable beasts know the taste of wine , or of anything but black bread and death .
Parsing [sent. 547 len. 8]: Is it not so , Jacques ? ''
Parsing [sent. 548 len. 12]: `` It is so , Jacques , '' Monsieur Defarge returned .
Parsing [sent. 549 len. 37]: At this second interchange of the Christian name , Madame Defarge , still using her toothpick with profound composure , coughed another grain of cough , and raised her eyebrows by the breadth of another line .
Parsing [sent. 550 len. 23]: The last of the three now said his say , as he put down his empty drinking vessel and smacked his lips .
Parsing [sent. 551 len. 3]: `` Ah !
Parsing [sent. 552 len. 5]: So much the worse !
Parsing [sent. 553 len. 23]: A bitter taste it is that such poor cattle always have in their mouths , and hard lives they live , Jacques .
Parsing [sent. 554 len. 7]: Am I right , Jacques ? ''
Parsing [sent. 555 len. 15]: `` You are right , Jacques , '' was the response of Monsieur Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 556 len. 32]: This third interchange of the Christian name was completed at the moment when Madame Defarge put her toothpick by , kept her eyebrows up , and slightly rustled in her seat .
Parsing [sent. 557 len. 4]: `` Hold then !
Parsing [sent. 558 len. 3]: True ! ''
Parsing [sent. 559 len. 4]: muttered her husband .
Parsing [sent. 560 len. 7]: `` Gentlemen -- my wife ! ''
Parsing [sent. 561 len. 15]: The three customers pulled off their hats to Madame Defarge , with three flourishes .
Parsing [sent. 562 len. 16]: She acknowledged their homage by bending her head , and giving them a quick look .
Parsing [sent. 563 len. 30]: Then she glanced in a casual manner round the wine-shop , took up her knitting with great apparent calmness and repose of spirit , and became absorbed in it .
Parsing [sent. 564 len. 22]: `` Gentlemen , '' said her husband , who had kept his bright eye observantly upon her , `` good day .
Parsing [sent. 565 len. 27]: The chamber , furnished bachelor-fashion , that you wished to see , and were inquiring for when I stepped out , is on the fifth floor .
Parsing [sent. 566 len. 31]: The doorway of the staircase gives on the little courtyard close to the left here , '' pointing with his hand , `` near to the window of my establishment .
Parsing [sent. 567 len. 21]: But , now that I remember , one of you has already been there , and can show the way .
Parsing [sent. 568 len. 5]: Gentlemen , adieu ! ''
Parsing [sent. 569 len. 11]: They paid for their wine , and left the place .
Parsing [sent. 570 len. 29]: The eyes of Monsieur Defarge were studying his wife at her knitting when the elderly gentleman advanced from his corner , and begged the favour of a word .
Parsing [sent. 571 len. 19]: `` Willingly , sir , '' said Monsieur Defarge , and quietly stepped with him to the door .
Parsing [sent. 572 len. 10]: Their conference was very short , but very decided .
Parsing [sent. 573 len. 14]: Almost at the first word , Monsieur Defarge started and became deeply attentive .
Parsing [sent. 574 len. 14]: It had not lasted a minute , when he nodded and went out .
Parsing [sent. 575 len. 17]: The gentleman then beckoned to the young lady , and they , too , went out .
Parsing [sent. 576 len. 14]: Madame Defarge knitted with nimble fingers and steady eyebrows , and saw nothing .
Parsing [sent. 577 len. 30]: Mr. Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette , emerging from the wine-shop thus , joined Monsieur Defarge in the doorway to which he had directed his own company just before .
Parsing [sent. 578 len. 30]: It opened from a stinking little black courtyard , and was the general public entrance to a great pile of houses , inhabited by a great number of people .
Parsing [sent. 579 len. 34]: In the gloomy tile-paved entry to the gloomy tile-paved staircase , Monsieur Defarge bent down on one knee to the child of his old master , and put her hand to his lips .
Parsing [sent. 580 len. 26]: It was a gentle action , but not at all gently done ; a very remarkable transformation had come over him in a few seconds .
Parsing [sent. 581 len. 26]: He had no good-humour in his face , nor any openness of aspect left , but had become a secret , angry , dangerous man .
Parsing [sent. 582 len. 12]: `` It is very high ; it is a little difficult .
Parsing [sent. 583 len. 6]: Better to begin slowly . ''
Parsing [sent. 584 len. 21]: Thus , Monsieur Defarge , in a stern voice , to Mr. Lorry , as they began ascending the stairs .
Parsing [sent. 585 len. 6]: `` Is he alone ? ''
Parsing [sent. 586 len. 4]: the latter whispered .
Parsing [sent. 587 len. 3]: `` Alone !
Parsing [sent. 588 len. 11]: God help him , who should be with him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 589 len. 10]: said the other , in the same low voice .
Parsing [sent. 590 len. 9]: `` Is he always alone , then ? ''
Parsing [sent. 591 len. 4]: `` Yes . ''
Parsing [sent. 592 len. 7]: `` Of his own desire ? ''
Parsing [sent. 593 len. 6]: `` Of his own necessity .
Parsing [sent. 594 len. 42]: As he was , when I first saw him after they found me and demanded to know if I would take him , and , at my peril be discreet -- as he was then , so he is now . ''
Parsing [sent. 595 len. 7]: `` He is greatly changed ? ''
Parsing [sent. 596 len. 4]: `` Changed ! ''
Parsing [sent. 597 len. 20]: The keeper of the wine-shop stopped to strike the wall with his hand , and mutter a tremendous curse .
Parsing [sent. 598 len. 10]: No direct answer could have been half so forcible .
Parsing [sent. 599 len. 20]: Mr. Lorry 's spirits grew heavier and heavier , as he and his two companions ascended higher and higher .
Parsing [sent. 600 len. 40]: Such a staircase , with its accessories , in the older and more crowded parts of Paris , would be bad enough now ; but , at that time , it was vile indeed to unaccustomed and unhardened senses .
Parsing [sent. 601 len. 52]: Every little habitation within the great foul nest of one high building -- that is to say , the room or rooms within every door that opened on the general staircase -- left its own heap of refuse on its own landing , besides flinging other refuse from its own windows .
Parsing [sent. 602 len. 40]: The uncontrollable and hopeless mass of decomposition so engendered , would have polluted the air , even if poverty and deprivation had not loaded it with their intangible impurities ; the two bad sources combined made it almost insupportable .
Parsing [sent. 603 len. 19]: Through such an atmosphere , by a steep dark shaft of dirt and poison , the way lay .
Parsing [sent. 604 len. 30]: Yielding to his own disturbance of mind , and to his young companion 's agitation , which became greater every instant , Mr. Jarvis Lorry twice stopped to rest .
Parsing [sent. 605 len. 37]: Each of these stoppages was made at a doleful grating , by which any languishing good airs that were left uncorrupted , seemed to escape , and all spoilt and sickly vapours seemed to crawl in .
Parsing [sent. 606 len. 51]: Through the rusted bars , tastes , rather than glimpses , were caught of the jumbled neighbourhood ; and nothing within range , nearer or lower than the summits of the two great towers of Notre -- Dame , had any promise on it of healthy life or wholesome aspirations .
Parsing [sent. 607 len. 19]: At last , the top of the staircase was gained , and they stopped for the third time .
Parsing [sent. 608 len. 27]: There was yet an upper staircase , of a steeper inclination and of contracted dimensions , to be ascended , before the garret story was reached .
Parsing [sent. 609 len. 64]: The keeper of the wine-shop , always going a little in advance , and always going on the side which Mr. Lorry took , as though he dreaded to be asked any question by the young lady , turned himself about here , and , carefully feeling in the pockets of the coat he carried over his shoulder , took out a key .
Parsing [sent. 610 len. 11]: `` The door is locked then , my friend ? ''
Parsing [sent. 611 len. 6]: said Mr. Lorry , surprised .
Parsing [sent. 612 len. 3]: `` Ay .
Parsing [sent. 613 len. 11]: Yes , '' was the grim reply of Monsieur Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 614 len. 14]: `` You think it necessary to keep the unfortunate gentleman so retired ? ''
Parsing [sent. 615 len. 11]: `` I think it necessary to turn the key . ''
Parsing [sent. 616 len. 13]: Monsieur Defarge whispered it closer in his ear , and frowned heavily .
Parsing [sent. 617 len. 4]: `` Why ? ''
Parsing [sent. 618 len. 3]: `` Why !
Parsing [sent. 619 len. 33]: Because he has lived so long , locked up , that he would be frightened-rave-tear himself to pieces-die-come to I know not what harm -- if his door was left open . ''
Parsing [sent. 620 len. 6]: `` Is it possible ! ''
Parsing [sent. 621 len. 4]: exclaimed Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 622 len. 6]: `` Is it possible ! ''
Parsing [sent. 623 len. 5]: repeated Defarge , bitterly .
Parsing [sent. 624 len. 3]: `` Yes .
Parsing [sent. 625 len. 35]: And a beautiful world we live in , when it IS possible , and when many other such things are possible , and not only possible , but done -- done , see you !
Parsing [sent. 626 len. 9]: -- under that sky there , every day .
Parsing [sent. 627 len. 5]: Long live the Devil .
Parsing [sent. 628 len. 6]: Let us go on . ''
Parsing [sent. 629 len. 26]: This dialogue had been held in so very low a whisper , that not a word of it had reached the young lady 's ears .
Parsing [sent. 630 len. 47]: But , by this time she trembled under such strong emotion , and her face expressed such deep anxiety , and , above all , such dread and terror , that Mr. Lorry felt it incumbent on him to speak a word or two of reassurance .
Parsing [sent. 631 len. 6]: `` Courage , dear miss !
Parsing [sent. 632 len. 2]: Courage !
Parsing [sent. 633 len. 2]: Business !
Parsing [sent. 634 len. 22]: The worst will be over in a moment ; it is but passing the room-door , and the worst is over .
Parsing [sent. 635 len. 24]: Then , all the good you bring to him , all the relief , all the happiness you bring to him , begin .
Parsing [sent. 636 len. 12]: Let our good friend here , assist you on that side .
Parsing [sent. 637 len. 7]: That 's well , friend Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 638 len. 4]: Come , now .
Parsing [sent. 639 len. 5]: Business , business ! ''
Parsing [sent. 640 len. 7]: They went up slowly and softly .
Parsing [sent. 641 len. 13]: The staircase was short , and they were soon at the top .
Parsing [sent. 642 len. 59]: There , as it had an abrupt turn in it , they came all at once in sight of three men , whose heads were bent down close together at the side of a door , and who were intently looking into the room to which the door belonged , through some chinks or holes in the wall .
Parsing [sent. 643 len. 32]: On hearing footsteps close at hand , these three turned , and rose , and showed themselves to be the three of one name who had been drinking in the wine-shop .
Parsing [sent. 644 len. 16]: `` I forgot them in the surprise of your visit , '' explained Monsieur Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 645 len. 13]: `` Leave us , good boys ; we have business here . ''
Parsing [sent. 646 len. 10]: The three glided by , and went silently down .
Parsing [sent. 647 len. 52]: There appearing to be no other door on that floor , and the keeper of the wine-shop going straight to this one when they were left alone , Mr. Lorry asked him in a whisper , with a little anger : `` Do you make a show of Monsieur Manette ? ''
Parsing [sent. 648 len. 18]: `` I show him , in the way you have seen , to a chosen few . ''
Parsing [sent. 649 len. 6]: `` Is that well ? ''
Parsing [sent. 650 len. 8]: `` I think it is well . ''
Parsing [sent. 651 len. 6]: `` Who are the few ?
Parsing [sent. 652 len. 7]: How do you choose them ? ''
Parsing [sent. 653 len. 27]: `` I choose them as real men , of my name -- Jacques is my name -- to whom the sight is likely to do good .
Parsing [sent. 654 len. 11]: Enough ; you are English ; that is another thing .
Parsing [sent. 655 len. 12]: Stay there , if you please , a little moment . ''
Parsing [sent. 656 len. 22]: With an admonitory gesture to keep them back , he stooped , and looked in through the crevice in the wall .
Parsing [sent. 657 len. 27]: Soon raising his head again , he struck twice or thrice upon the door -- evidently with no other object than to make a noise there .
Parsing [sent. 658 len. 35]: With the same intention , he drew the key across it , three or four times , before he put it clumsily into the lock , and turned it as heavily as he could .
Parsing [sent. 659 len. 19]: The door slowly opened inward under his hand , and he looked into the room and said something .
Parsing [sent. 660 len. 6]: A faint voice answered something .
Parsing [sent. 661 len. 14]: Little more than a single syllable could have been spoken on either side .
Parsing [sent. 662 len. 13]: He looked back over his shoulder , and beckoned them to enter .
Parsing [sent. 663 len. 24]: Mr. Lorry got his arm securely round the daughter 's waist , and held her ; for he felt that she was sinking .
Parsing [sent. 664 len. 6]: `` A-a-a-business , business ! ''
Parsing [sent. 665 len. 16]: he urged , with a moisture that was not of business shining on his cheek .
Parsing [sent. 666 len. 8]: `` Come in , come in ! ''
Parsing [sent. 667 len. 13]: `` I am afraid of it , '' she answered , shuddering .
Parsing [sent. 668 len. 4]: `` Of it ?
Parsing [sent. 669 len. 3]: What ? ''
Parsing [sent. 670 len. 6]: `` I mean of him .
Parsing [sent. 671 len. 5]: Of my father . ''
Parsing [sent. 672 len. 42]: Rendered in a manner desperate , by her state and by the beckoning of their conductor , he drew over his neck the arm that shook upon his shoulder , lifted her a little , and hurried her into the room .
Parsing [sent. 673 len. 17]: He sat her down just within the door , and held her , clinging to him .
Parsing [sent. 674 len. 29]: Defarge drew out the key , closed the door , locked it on the inside , took out the key again , and held it in his hand .
Parsing [sent. 675 len. 22]: All this he did , methodically , and with as loud and harsh an accompaniment of noise as he could make .
Parsing [sent. 676 len. 17]: Finally , he walked across the room with a measured tread to where the window was .
Parsing [sent. 677 len. 8]: He stopped there , and faced round .
Parsing [sent. 678 len. 71]: The garret , built to be a depository for firewood and the like , was dim and dark : for , the window of dormer shape , was in truth a door in the roof , with a little crane over it for the hoisting up of stores from the street : unglazed , and closing up the middle in two pieces , like any other door of French construction .
Parsing [sent. 679 len. 25]: To exclude the cold , one half of this door was fast closed , and the other was opened but a very little way .
Parsing [sent. 680 len. 50]: Such a scanty portion of light was admitted through these means , that it was difficult , on first coming in , to see anything ; and long habit alone could have slowly formed in any one , the ability to do any work requiring nicety in such obscurity .
Parsing [sent. 681 len. 57]: Yet , work of that kind was being done in the garret ; for , with his back towards the door , and his face towards the window where the keeper of the wine-shop stood looking at him , a white-haired man sat on a low bench , stooping forward and very busy , making shoes .
Parsing [sent. 682 len. 8]: VI The Shoemaker `` Good day ! ''
Parsing [sent. 683 len. 17]: said Monsieur Defarge , looking down at the white head that bent low over the shoemaking .
Parsing [sent. 684 len. 30]: It was raised for a moment , and a very faint voice responded to the salutation , as if it were at a distance : `` Good day ! ''
Parsing [sent. 685 len. 12]: `` You are still hard at work , I see ? ''
Parsing [sent. 686 len. 26]: After a long silence , the head was lifted for another moment , and the voice replied , `` Yes -- I am working . ''
Parsing [sent. 687 len. 21]: This time , a pair of haggard eyes had looked at the questioner , before the face had dropped again .
Parsing [sent. 688 len. 10]: The faintness of the voice was pitiable and dreadful .
Parsing [sent. 689 len. 22]: It was not the faintness of physical weakness , though confinement and hard fare no doubt had their part in it .
Parsing [sent. 690 len. 15]: Its deplorable peculiarity was , that it was the faintness of solitude and disuse .
Parsing [sent. 691 len. 16]: It was like the last feeble echo of a sound made long and long ago .
Parsing [sent. 692 len. 32]: So entirely had it lost the life and resonance of the human voice , that it affected the senses like a once beautiful colour faded away into a poor weak stain .
Parsing [sent. 693 len. 15]: So sunken and suppressed it was , that it was like a voice underground .
Parsing [sent. 694 len. 42]: So expressive it was , of a hopeless and lost creature , that a famished traveller , wearied out by lonely wandering in a wilderness , would have remembered home and friends in such a tone before lying down to die .
Parsing [sent. 695 len. 52]: Some minutes of silent work had passed : and the haggard eyes had looked up again : not with any interest or curiosity , but with a dull mechanical perception , beforehand , that the spot where the only visitor they were aware of had stood , was not yet empty .
Parsing [sent. 696 len. 28]: `` I want , '' said Defarge , who had not removed his gaze from the shoemaker , `` to let in a little more light here .
Parsing [sent. 697 len. 8]: You can bear a little more ? ''
Parsing [sent. 698 len. 43]: The shoemaker stopped his work ; looked with a vacant air of listening , at the floor on one side of him ; then similarly , at the floor on the other side of him ; then , upward at the speaker .
Parsing [sent. 699 len. 7]: `` What did you say ? ''
Parsing [sent. 700 len. 10]: `` You can bear a little more light ? ''
Parsing [sent. 701 len. 13]: `` I must bear it , if you let it in . ''
Parsing [sent. 702 len. 14]: -LRB- Laying the palest shadow of a stress upon the second word . -RRB-
Parsing [sent. 703 len. 18]: The opened half-door was opened a little further , and secured at that angle for the time .
Parsing [sent. 704 len. 27]: A broad ray of light fell into the garret , and showed the workman with an unfinished shoe upon his lap , pausing in his labour .
Parsing [sent. 705 len. 18]: His few common tools and various scraps of leather were at his feet and on his bench .
Parsing [sent. 706 len. 23]: He had a white beard , raggedly cut , but not very long , a hollow face , and exceedingly bright eyes .
Parsing [sent. 707 len. 45]: The hollowness and thinness of his face would have caused them to look large , under his yet dark eyebrows and his confused white hair , though they had been really otherwise ; but , they were naturally large , and looked unnaturally so .
Parsing [sent. 708 len. 21]: His yellow rags of shirt lay open at the throat , and showed his body to be withered and worn .
Parsing [sent. 709 len. 55]: He , and his old canvas frock , and his loose stockings , and all his poor tatters of clothes , had , in a long seclusion from direct light and air , faded down to such a dull uniformity of parchment-yellow , that it would have been hard to say which was which .
Parsing [sent. 710 len. 22]: He had put up a hand between his eyes and the light , and the very bones of it seemed transparent .
Parsing [sent. 711 len. 15]: So he sat , with a steadfastly vacant gaze , pausing in his work .
Parsing [sent. 712 len. 52]: He never looked at the figure before him , without first looking down on this side of himself , then on that , as if he had lost the habit of associating place with sound ; he never spoke , without first wandering in this manner , and forgetting to speak .

Parsing [sent. 748 len. 48]: The task of recalling him from the vagrancy into which he always sank when he had spoken , was like recalling some very weak person from a swoon , or endeavouring , in the hope of some disclosure , to stay the spirit of a fast-dying man .

Parsing [sent. 754 len. 27]: With a weary sound that was not a sigh , nor a groan , he bent to work again , until the silence was again broken .

Parsing [sent. 761 len. 4]: I taught myself .
Parsing [sent. 762 len. 25]: I asked leave to -- '' He lapsed away , even for minutes , ringing those measured changes on his hands the whole time .
Parsing [sent. 763 len. 48]: His eyes came slowly back , at last , to the face from which they had wandered ; when they rested on it , he started , and resumed , in the manner of a sleeper that moment awake , reverting to a subject of last night .
Parsing [sent. 764 len. 29]: `` I asked leave to teach myself , and I got it with much difficulty after a long while , and I have made shoes ever since . ''

Parsing [sent. 771 len. 49]: As the captive of many years sat looking fixedly , by turns , at Mr. Lorry and at Defarge , some long obliterated marks of an actively intent intelligence in the middle of the forehead , gradually forced themselves through the black mist that had fallen on him .
Parsing [sent. 772 len. 19]: They were overclouded again , they were fainter , they were gone ; but they had been there .
Parsing [sent. 773 len. 133]: And so exactly was the expression repeated on the fair young face of her who had crept along the wall to a point where she could see him , and where she now stood looking at him , with hands which at first had been only raised in frightened compassion , if not even to keep him off and shut out the sight of him , but which were now extending towards him , trembling with eagerness to lay the spectral face upon her warm young breast , and love it back to life and hope -- so exactly was the expression repeated -LRB- though in stronger characters -RRB- on her fair young face , that it looked as though it had passed like a moving light , from him to her .

Parsing [sent. 859 len. 63]: When the quiet of the garret had been long undisturbed , and his heaving breast and shaken form had long yielded to the calm that must follow all storms -- emblem to humanity , of the rest and silence into which the storm called Life must hush at last -- they came forward to raise the father and daughter from the ground .
Parsing [sent. 860 len. 18]: He had gradually dropped to the floor , and lay there in a lethargy , worn out .

Parsing [sent. 862 len. 63]: `` If , without disturbing him , '' she said , raising her hand to Mr. Lorry as he stooped over them , after repeated blowings of his nose , `` all could be arranged for our leaving Paris at once , so that , from the , very door , he could be taken away -- '' `` But , consider .

Parsing [sent. 872 len. 5]: Why should you be ?
Parsing [sent. 873 len. 34]: If you will lock the door to secure us from interruption , I do not doubt that you will find him , when you come back , as quiet as you leave him .

Parsing [sent. 881 len. 21]: No human intelligence could have read the mysteries of his mind , in the scared blank wonder of his face .
Parsing [sent. 882 len. 34]: Whether he knew what had happened , whether he recollected what they had said to him , whether he knew that he was free , were questions which no sagacity could have solved .
Parsing [sent. 883 len. 40]: They tried speaking to him ; but , he was so confused , and so very slow to answer , that they took fright at his bewilderment , and agreed for the time to tamper with him no more .
Parsing [sent. 884 len. 50]: He had a wild , lost manner of occasionally clasping his head in his hands , that had not been seen in him before ; yet , he had some pleasure in the mere sound of his daughter 's voice , and invariably turned to it when she spoke .
Parsing [sent. 885 len. 42]: In the submissive way of one long accustomed to obey under coercion , he ate and drank what they gave him to eat and drink , and put on the cloak and other wrappings , that they gave him to wear .

Parsing [sent. 899 len. 28]: No crowd was about the door ; no people were discernible at any of the many windows ; not even a chance passerby was in the street .

Parsing [sent. 922 len. 33]: Book the Second -- the Golden Thread I Five Years Later Tellson 's Bank by Temple Bar was an old-fashioned place , even in the year one thousand seven hundred and eighty .
Parsing [sent. 923 len. 14]: It was very small , very dark , very ugly , very incommodious .
Parsing [sent. 924 len. 39]: It was an old-fashioned place , moreover , in the moral attribute that the partners in the House were proud of its smallness , proud of its darkness , proud of its ugliness , proud of its incommodiousness .
Parsing [sent. 925 len. 32]: They were even boastful of its eminence in those particulars , and were fired by an express conviction that , if it were less objectionable , it would be less respectable .
Parsing [sent. 926 len. 20]: This was no passive belief , but an active weapon which they flashed at more convenient places of business .
Parsing [sent. 927 len. 22]: Tellson 's -LRB- they said -RRB- wanted no elbow-room , Tellson 's wanted no light , Tellson 's wanted no embellishment .
Parsing [sent. 928 len. 20]: Noakes and Co. ` s might , or Snooks Brothers ' might ; but Tellson 's , thank Heaven !
Parsing [sent. 929 len. 19]: -- Any one of these partners would have disinherited his son on the question of rebuilding Tellson 's .
Parsing [sent. 930 len. 42]: In this respect the House was much on a par with the Country ; which did very often disinherit its sons for suggesting improvements in laws and customs that had long been highly objectionable , but were only the more respectable .
Parsing [sent. 931 len. 17]: Thus it had come to pass , that Tellson 's was the triumphant perfection of inconvenience .
Parsing [sent. 932 len. 100]: After bursting open a door of idiotic obstinacy with a weak rattle in its throat , you fell into Tellson 's down two steps , and came to your senses in a miserable little shop , with two little counters , where the oldest of men made your cheque shake as if the wind rustled it , while they examined the signature by the dingiest of windows , which were always under a shower-bath of mud from Fleet-street , and which were made the dingier by their own iron bars proper , and the heavy shadow of Temple Bar .
Parsing [sent. 933 len. 55]: If your business necessitated your seeing `` the House , '' you were put into a species of Condemned Hold at the back , where you meditated on a misspent life , until the House came with its hands in its pockets , and you could hardly blink at it in the dismal twilight .
Parsing [sent. 934 len. 33]: Your money came out of , or went into , wormy old wooden drawers , particles of which flew up your nose and down your throat when they were opened and shut .
Parsing [sent. 935 len. 17]: Your bank-notes had a musty odour , as if they were fast decomposing into rags again .
Parsing [sent. 936 len. 23]: Your plate was stowed away among the neighbouring cesspools , and evil communications corrupted its good polish in a day or two .
Parsing [sent. 937 len. 26]: Your deeds got into extemporised strong-rooms made of kitchens and sculleries , and fretted all the fat out of their parchments into the banking-house air .
Parsing [sent. 938 len. 91]: Your lighter boxes of family papers went up-stairs into a Barmecide room , that always had a great dining-table in it and never had a dinner , and where , even in the year one thousand seven hundred and eighty , the first letters written to you by your old love , or by your little children , were but newly released from the horror of being ogled through the windows , by the heads exposed on Temple Bar with an insensate brutality and ferocity worthy of Abyssinia or Ashantee .
Parsing [sent. 939 len. 31]: But indeed , at that time , putting to death was a recipe much in vogue with all trades and professions , and not least of all with Tellson 's .
Parsing [sent. 940 len. 15]: Death is Nature 's remedy for all things , and why not Legislation 's ?
Parsing [sent. 941 len. 94]: Accordingly , the forger was put to Death ; the utterer of a bad note was put to Death ; the unlawful opener of a letter was put to Death ; the purloiner of forty shillings and sixpence was put to Death ; the holder of a horse at Tellson 's door , who made off with it , was put to Death ; the coiner of a bad shilling was put to Death ; the sounders of three-fourths of the notes in the whole gamut of Crime , were put to Death .
Parsing [sent. 942 len. 58]: Not that it did the least good in the way of prevention -- it might almost have been worth remarking that the fact was exactly the reverse -- but , it cleared off -LRB- as to this world -RRB- the trouble of each particular case , and left nothing else connected with it to be looked after .
Parsing [sent. 943 len. 65]: Thus , Tellson 's , in its day , like greater places of business , its contemporaries , had taken so many lives , that , if the heads laid low before it had been ranged on Temple Bar instead of being privately disposed of , they would probably have excluded what little light the ground floor had , in a rather significant manner .
Parsing [sent. 944 len. 23]: Cramped in all kinds of dun cupboards and hutches at Tellson 's , the oldest of men carried on the business gravely .
Parsing [sent. 945 len. 21]: When they took a young man into Tellson 's London house , they hid him somewhere till he was old .
Parsing [sent. 946 len. 24]: They kept him in a dark place , like a cheese , until he had the full Tellson flavour and blue-mould upon him .
Parsing [sent. 947 len. 29]: Then only was he permitted to be seen , spectacularly poring over large books , and casting his breeches and gaiters into the general weight of the establishment .
Parsing [sent. 948 len. 35]: Outside Tellson 's -- never by any means in it , unless called in -- was an odd-job-man , an occasional porter and messenger , who served as the live sign of the house .
Parsing [sent. 949 len. 34]: He was never absent during business hours , unless upon an errand , and then he was represented by his son : a grisly urchin of twelve , who was his express image .
Parsing [sent. 950 len. 15]: People understood that Tellson 's , in a stately way , tolerated the odd-job-man .
Parsing [sent. 951 len. 23]: The house had always tolerated some person in that capacity , and time and tide had drifted this person to the post .
Parsing [sent. 952 len. 37]: His surname was Cruncher , and on the youthful occasion of his renouncing by proxy the works of darkness , in the easterly parish church of Hounsditch , he had received the added appellation of Jerry .
Parsing [sent. 953 len. 34]: The scene was Mr. Cruncher 's private lodging in Hanging-sword-alley , Whitefriars : the time , half-past seven of the clock on a windy March morning , Anno Domini seventeen hundred and eighty .
Parsing [sent. 954 len. 45]: -LRB- Mr. Cruncher himself always spoke of the year of our Lord as Anna Dominoes : apparently under the impression that the Christian era dated from the invention of a popular game , by a lady who had bestowed her name upon it . -RRB-
Parsing [sent. 955 len. 36]: Mr. Cruncher 's apartments were not in a savoury neighbourhood , and were but two in number , even if a closet with a single pane of glass in it might be counted as one .
Parsing [sent. 956 len. 7]: But they were very decently kept .
Parsing [sent. 957 len. 47]: Early as it was , on the windy March morning , the room in which he lay abed was already scrubbed throughout ; and between the cups and saucers arranged for breakfast , and the lumbering deal table , a very clean white cloth was spread .
Parsing [sent. 958 len. 14]: Mr. Cruncher reposed under a patchwork counterpane , like a Harlequin at home .

Parsing [sent. 960 len. 27]: At which juncture , he exclaimed , in a voice of dire exasperation : `` Bust me , if she ai n't at it agin ! ''

Parsing [sent. 966 len. 50]: It was a very muddy boot , and may introduce the odd circumstance connected with Mr. Cruncher 's domestic economy , that , whereas he often came home after banking hours with clean boots , he often got up next morning to find the same boots covered with clay .

Parsing [sent. 1017 len. 46]: Exceedingly red-eyed and grim , as if he had been up all night at a party which had taken anything but a convivial turn , Jerry Cruncher worried his breakfast rather than ate it , growling over it like any four-footed inmate of a menagerie .

Parsing [sent. 1020 len. 83]: His stock consisted of a wooden stool , made out of a broken-backed chair cut down , which stool , young Jerry , walking at his father 's side , carried every morning to beneath the banking-house window that was nearest Temple Bar : where , with the addition of the first handful of straw that could be gleaned from any passing vehicle to keep the cold and wet from the odd-job-man 's feet , it formed the encampment for the day .
Parsing [sent. 1021 len. 30]: On this post of his , Mr. Cruncher was as well known to Fleet-street and the Temple , as the Bar itself , -- and was almost as in-looking .
Parsing [sent. 1022 len. 78]: Encamped at a quarter before nine , in good time to touch his three-cornered hat to the oldest of men as they passed in to Tellson 's , Jerry took up his station on this windy March morning , with young Jerry standing by him , when not engaged in making forays through the Bar , to inflict bodily and mental injuries of an acute description on passing boys who were small enough for his amiable purpose .
Parsing [sent. 1023 len. 46]: Father and son , extremely like each other , looking silently on at the morning traffic in Fleet-street , with their two heads as near to one another as the two eyes of each were , bore a considerable resemblance to a pair of monkeys .
