Parsing [sent. 1076 len. 27]: They hanged at Tyburn , in those days , so the street outside Newgate had not obtained one infamous notoriety that has since attached to it .
Parsing [sent. 1077 len. 56]: But , the gaol was a vile place , in which most kinds of debauchery and villainy were practised , and where dire diseases were bred , that came into court with the prisoners , and sometimes rushed straight from the dock at my Lord Chief Justice himself , and pulled him off the bench .
Parsing [sent. 1078 len. 31]: It had more than once happened , that the Judge in the black cap pronounced his own doom as certainly as the prisoner 's , and even died before him .
Parsing [sent. 1079 len. 60]: For the rest , the Old Bailey was famous as a kind of deadly inn-yard , from which pale travellers set out continually , in carts and coaches , on a violent passage into the other world : traversing some two miles and a half of public street and road , and shaming few good citizens , if any .
Parsing [sent. 1080 len. 16]: So powerful is use , and so desirable to be good use in the beginning .
Parsing [sent. 1081 len. 77]: It was famous , too , for the pillory , a wise old institution , that inflicted a punishment of which no one could foresee the extent ; also , for the whipping-post , another dear old institution , very humanising and softening to behold in action ; also , for extensive transactions in blood-money , another fragment of ancestral wisdom , systematically leading to the most frightful mercenary crimes that could be committed under Heaven .
Parsing [sent. 1082 len. 55]: Altogether , the Old Bailey , at that date , was a choice illustration of the precept , that `` Whatever is is right ; '' an aphorism that would be as final as it is lazy , did it not include the troublesome consequence , that nothing that ever was , was wrong .
Parsing [sent. 1083 len. 51]: Making his way through the tainted crowd , dispersed up and down this hideous scene of action , with the skill of a man accustomed to make his way quietly , the messenger found out the door he sought , and handed in his letter through a trap in it .
Parsing [sent. 1084 len. 34]: For , people then paid to see the play at the Old Bailey , just as they paid to see the play in Bedlam -- only the former entertainment was much the dearer .
Parsing [sent. 1085 len. 33]: Therefore , all the Old Bailey doors were well guarded -- except , indeed , the social doors by which the criminals got there , and those were always left wide open .
Parsing [sent. 1086 len. 29]: After some delay and demur , the door grudgingly turned on its hinges a very little way , and allowed Mr. Jerry Cruncher to squeeze himself into court .
Parsing [sent. 1087 len. 6]: `` What 's on ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1088 len. 16]: he asked , in a whisper , of the man he found himself next to .
Parsing [sent. 1089 len. 5]: `` Nothing yet . ''
Parsing [sent. 1090 len. 7]: `` What 's coming on ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1091 len. 6]: `` The Treason case . ''
Parsing [sent. 1092 len. 8]: `` The quartering one , eh ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1093 len. 4]: `` Ah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1094 len. 67]: returned the man , with a relish ; `` he 'll be drawn on a hurdle to be half hanged , and then he 'll be taken down and sliced before his own face , and then his inside will be taken out and burnt while he looks on , and then his head will be chopped off , and he 'll be cut into quarters .
Parsing [sent. 1095 len. 6]: That 's the sentence . ''
Parsing [sent. 1096 len. 13]: `` If he 's found Guilty , you mean to say ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1097 len. 8]: Jerry added , by way of proviso .
Parsing [sent. 1098 len. 3]: `` Oh !
Parsing [sent. 1099 len. 11]: they 'll find him guilty , '' said the other .
Parsing [sent. 1100 len. 10]: `` Do n't you be afraid of that . ''
Parsing [sent. 1101 len. 28]: Mr. Cruncher 's attention was here diverted to the door-keeper , whom he saw making his way to Mr. Lorry , with the note in his hand .
Parsing [sent. 1102 len. 73]: Mr. Lorry sat at a table , among the gentlemen in wigs : not far from a wigged gentleman , the prisoner 's counsel , who had a great bundle of papers before him : and nearly opposite another wigged gentleman with his hands in his pockets , whose whole attention , when Mr. Cruncher looked at him then or afterwards , seemed to be concentrated on the ceiling of the court .
Parsing [sent. 1103 len. 41]: After some gruff coughing and rubbing of his chin and signing with his hand , Jerry attracted the notice of Mr. Lorry , who had stood up to look for him , and who quietly nodded and sat down again .
Parsing [sent. 1104 len. 12]: `` What 's HE got to do with the case ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1105 len. 8]: asked the man he had spoken with .
Parsing [sent. 1106 len. 10]: `` Blest if I know , '' said Jerry .
Parsing [sent. 1107 len. 19]: `` What have YOU got to do with it , then , if a person may inquire ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1108 len. 12]: `` Blest if I know that either , '' said Jerry .
Parsing [sent. 1109 len. 22]: The entrance of the Judge , and a consequent great stir and settling down in the court , stopped the dialogue .
Parsing [sent. 1110 len. 11]: Presently , the dock became the central point of interest .
Parsing [sent. 1111 len. 25]: Two gaolers , who had been standing there , wont out , and the prisoner was brought in , and put to the bar .
Parsing [sent. 1112 len. 18]: Everybody present , except the one wigged gentleman who looked at the ceiling , stared at him .
Parsing [sent. 1113 len. 24]: All the human breath in the place , rolled at him , like a sea , or a wind , or a fire .
Parsing [sent. 1114 len. 85]: Eager faces strained round pillars and corners , to get a sight of him ; spectators in back rows stood up , not to miss a hair of him ; people on the floor of the court , laid their hands on the shoulders of the people before them , to help themselves , at anybody 's cost , to a view of him -- stood a-tiptoe , got upon ledges , stood upon next to nothing , to see every inch of him .
Parsing [sent. 1115 len. 83]: Conspicuous among these latter , like an animated bit of the spiked wall of Newgate , Jerry stood : aiming at the prisoner the beery breath of a whet he had taken as he came along , and discharging it to mingle with the waves of other beer , and gin , and tea , and coffee , and what not , that flowed at him , and already broke upon the great windows behind him in an impure mist and rain .
Parsing [sent. 1116 len. 30]: The object of all this staring and blaring , was a young man of about five-and-twenty , well-grown and well-looking , with a sunburnt cheek and a dark eye .
Parsing [sent. 1117 len. 9]: His condition was that of a young gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 1118 len. 45]: He was plainly dressed in black , or very dark grey , and his hair , which was long and dark , was gathered in a ribbon at the back of his neck ; more to be out of his way than for ornament .
Parsing [sent. 1119 len. 41]: As an emotion of the mind will express itself through any covering of the body , so the paleness which his situation engendered came through the brown upon his cheek , showing the soul to be stronger than the sun .
Parsing [sent. 1120 len. 15]: He was otherwise quite self-possessed , bowed to the Judge , and stood quiet .
Parsing [sent. 1121 len. 22]: The sort of interest with which this man was stared and breathed at , was not a sort that elevated humanity .
Parsing [sent. 1122 len. 38]: Had he stood in peril of a less horrible sentence -- had there been a chance of any one of its savage details being spared -- by just so much would he have lost in his fascination .
Parsing [sent. 1123 len. 34]: The form that was to be doomed to be so shamefully mangled , was the sight ; the immortal creature that was to be so butchered and torn asunder , yielded the sensation .
Parsing [sent. 1124 len. 32]: Whatever gloss the various spectators put upon the interest , according to their several arts and powers of self-deceit , the interest was , at the root of it , Ogreish .
Parsing [sent. 1125 len. 5]: Silence in the court !
Parsing [sent. 1126 len. 161]: Charles Darnay had yesterday pleaded Not Guilty to an indictment denouncing him -LRB- with infinite jingle and jangle -RRB- for that he was a false traitor to our serene , illustrious , excellent , and so forth , prince , our Lord the King , by reason of his having , on divers occasions , and by divers means and ways , assisted Lewis , the French King , in his wars against our said serene , illustrious , excellent , and so forth ; that was to say , by coming and going , between the dominions of our said serene , illustrious , excellent , and so forth , and those of the said French Lewis , and wickedly , falsely , traitorously , and otherwise evil-adverbiously , revealing to the said French Lewis what forces our said serene , illustrious , excellent , and so forth , had in preparation to send to Canada and North America .
Parsing [sent. 1127 len. 74]: This much , Jerry , with his head becoming more and more spiky as the law terms bristled it , made out with huge satisfaction , and so arrived circuitously at the understanding that the aforesaid , and over and over again aforesaid , Charles Darnay , stood there before him upon his trial ; that the jury were swearing in ; and that Mr. Attorney -- General was making ready to speak .
Parsing [sent. 1128 len. 39]: The accused , who was -LRB- and who knew he was -RRB- being mentally hanged , beheaded , and quartered , by everybody there , neither flinched from the situation , nor assumed any theatrical air in it .
Parsing [sent. 1129 len. 48]: He was quiet and attentive ; watched the opening proceedings with a grave interest ; and stood with his hands resting on the slab of wood before him , so composedly , that they had not displaced a leaf of the herbs with which it was strewn .
Parsing [sent. 1130 len. 22]: The court was all bestrewn with herbs and sprinkled with vinegar , as a precaution against gaol air and gaol fever .
Parsing [sent. 1131 len. 18]: Over the prisoner 's head there was a mirror , to throw the light down upon him .
Parsing [sent. 1132 len. 25]: Crowds of the wicked and the wretched had been reflected in it , and had passed from its surface and this earth 's together .
Parsing [sent. 1133 len. 36]: Haunted in a most ghastly manner that abominable place would have been , if the glass could ever have rendered back its reflections , as the ocean is one day to give up its dead .
Parsing [sent. 1134 len. 23]: Some passing thought of the infamy and disgrace for which it had been reserved , may have struck the prisoner 's mind .
Parsing [sent. 1135 len. 46]: Be that as it may , a change in his position making him conscious of a bar of light across his face , he looked up ; and when he saw the glass his face flushed , and his right hand pushed the herbs away .
Parsing [sent. 1136 len. 21]: It happened , that the action turned his face to that side of the court which was on his left .
Parsing [sent. 1137 len. 56]: About on a level with his eyes , there sat , in that corner of the Judge 's bench , two persons upon whom his look immediately rested ; so immediately , and so much to the changing of his aspect , that all the eyes that were tamed upon him , turned to them .
Parsing [sent. 1138 len. 62]: The spectators saw in the two figures , a young lady of little more than twenty , and a gentleman who was evidently her father ; a man of a very remarkable appearance in respect of the absolute whiteness of his hair , and a certain indescribable intensity of face : not of an active kind , but pondering and self-communing .
Parsing [sent. 1139 len. 53]: When this expression was upon him , he looked as if he were old ; but when it was stirred and broken up -- as it was now , in a moment , on his speaking to his daughter -- he became a handsome man , not past the prime of life .
Parsing [sent. 1140 len. 25]: His daughter had one of her hands drawn through his arm , as she sat by him , and the other pressed upon it .
Parsing [sent. 1141 len. 22]: She had drawn close to him , in her dread of the scene , and in her pity for the prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 1142 len. 22]: Her forehead had been strikingly expressive of an engrossing terror and compassion that saw nothing but the peril of the accused .
Parsing [sent. 1143 len. 40]: This had been so very noticeable , so very powerfully and naturally shown , that starers who had had no pity for him were touched by her ; and the whisper went about , `` Who are they ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1144 len. 40]: Jerry , the messenger , who had made his own observations , in his own manner , and who had been sucking the rust off his fingers in his absorption , stretched his neck to hear who they were .
Parsing [sent. 1145 len. 40]: The crowd about him had pressed and passed the inquiry on to the nearest attendant , and from him it had been more slowly pressed and passed back ; at last it got to Jerry : `` Witnesses . ''
Parsing [sent. 1146 len. 6]: `` For which side ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1147 len. 4]: `` Against . ''
Parsing [sent. 1148 len. 6]: `` Against what side ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1149 len. 6]: `` The prisoner 's . ''
Parsing [sent. 1150 len. 57]: The Judge , whose eyes had gone in the general direction , recalled them , leaned back in his seat , and looked steadily at the man whose life was in his hand , as Mr. Attorney -- General rose to spin the rope , grind the axe , and hammer the nails into the scaffold .
Parsing [sent. 1151 len. 38]: III A Disappointment Mr. Attorney -- General had to inform the jury , that the prisoner before them , though young in years , was old in the treasonable practices which claimed the forfeit of his life .
Parsing [sent. 1152 len. 30]: That this correspondence with the public enemy was not a correspondence of to-day , or of yesterday , or even of last year , or of the year before .
Parsing [sent. 1153 len. 39]: That , it was certain the prisoner had , for longer than that , been in the habit of passing and repassing between France and England , on secret business of which he could give no honest account .
Parsing [sent. 1154 len. 34]: That , if it were in the nature of traitorous ways to thrive -LRB- which happily it never was -RRB- , the real wickedness and guilt of his business might have remained undiscovered .
Parsing [sent. 1155 len. 56]: That Providence , however , had put it into the heart of a person who was beyond fear and beyond reproach , to ferret out the nature of the prisoner 's schemes , and , struck with horror , to disclose them to his Majesty 's Chief Secretary of State and most honourable Privy Council .
Parsing [sent. 1156 len. 10]: That , this patriot would be produced before them .
Parsing [sent. 1157 len. 14]: That , his position and attitude were , on the whole , sublime .
Parsing [sent. 1158 len. 48]: That , he had been the prisoner 's friend , but , at once in an auspicious and an evil hour detecting his infamy , had resolved to immolate the traitor he could no longer cherish in his bosom , on the sacred altar of his country .
Parsing [sent. 1159 len. 29]: That , if statues were decreed in Britain , as in ancient Greece and Rome , to public benefactors , this shining citizen would assuredly have had one .
Parsing [sent. 1160 len. 16]: That , as they were not so decreed , he probably would not have one .
Parsing [sent. 1161 len. 73]: That , Virtue , as had been observed by the poets -LRB- in many passages which he well knew the jury would have , word for word , at the tips of their tongues ; whereat the jury 's countenances displayed a guilty consciousness that they knew nothing about the passages -RRB- , was in a manner contagious ; more especially the bright virtue known as patriotism , or love of country .
Parsing [sent. 1162 len. 56]: That , the lofty example of this immaculate and unimpeachable witness for the Crown , to refer to whom however unworthily was an honour , had communicated itself to the prisoner 's servant , and had engendered in him a holy determination to examine his master 's table-drawers and pockets , and secrete his papers .
Parsing [sent. 1163 len. 62]: That , he -LRB- Mr. Attorney -- General -RRB- was prepared to hear some disparagement attempted of this admirable servant ; but that , in a general way , he preferred him to his -LRB- Mr. Attorney -- General 's -RRB- brothers and sisters , and honoured him more than his -LRB- Mr. Attorney -- General 's -RRB- father and mother .
Parsing [sent. 1164 len. 15]: That , he called with confidence on the jury to come and do likewise .
Parsing [sent. 1165 len. 67]: That , the evidence of these two witnesses , coupled with the documents of their discovering that would be produced , would show the prisoner to have been furnished with lists of his Majesty 's forces , and of their disposition and preparation , both by sea and land , and would leave no doubt that he had habitually conveyed such information to a hostile power .
Parsing [sent. 1166 len. 48]: That , these lists could not be proved to be in the prisoner 's handwriting ; but that it was all the same ; that , indeed , it was rather the better for the prosecution , as showing the prisoner to be artful in his precautions .
Parsing [sent. 1167 len. 43]: That , the proof would go back five years , and would show the prisoner already engaged in these pernicious missions , within a few weeks before the date of the very first action fought between the British troops and the Americans .
Parsing [sent. 1168 len. 55]: That , for these reasons , the jury , being a loyal jury -LRB- as he knew they were -RRB- , and being a responsible jury -LRB- as THEY knew they were -RRB- , must positively find the prisoner Guilty , and make an end of him , whether they liked it or not .
Parsing [sent. 1169 len. 81]: That , they never could lay their heads upon their pillows ; that , they never could tolerate the idea of their wives laying their heads upon their pillows ; that , they never could endure the notion of their children laying their heads upon their pillows ; in short , that there never more could be , for them or theirs , any laying of heads upon pillows at all , unless the prisoner 's head was taken off .
Parsing [sent. 1170 len. 49]: That head Mr. Attorney -- General concluded by demanding of them , in the name of everything he could think of with a round turn in it , and on the faith of his solemn asseveration that he already considered the prisoner as good as dead and gone .
Parsing [sent. 1171 len. 36]: When the Attorney -- General ceased , a buzz arose in the court as if a cloud of great blue-flies were swarming about the prisoner , in anticipation of what he was soon to become .
Parsing [sent. 1172 len. 13]: When toned down again , the unimpeachable patriot appeared in the witness-box .
Parsing [sent. 1173 len. 24]: Mr. Solicitor -- General then , following his leader 's lead , examined the patriot : John Barsad , gentleman , by name .
Parsing [sent. 1174 len. 32]: The story of his pure soul was exactly what Mr. Attorney -- General had described it to be -- perhaps , if it had a fault , a little too exactly .
Parsing [sent. 1175 len. 42]: Having released his noble bosom of its burden , he would have modestly withdrawn himself , but that the wigged gentleman with the papers before him , sitting not far from Mr. Lorry , begged to ask him a few questions .
Parsing [sent. 1176 len. 15]: The wigged gentleman sitting opposite , still looking at the ceiling of the court .
Parsing [sent. 1177 len. 8]: Had he ever been a spy himself ?
Parsing [sent. 1178 len. 8]: No , he scorned the base insinuation .
Parsing [sent. 1179 len. 6]: What did he live upon ?
Parsing [sent. 1180 len. 3]: His property .
Parsing [sent. 1181 len. 5]: Where was his property ?
Parsing [sent. 1182 len. 9]: He did n't precisely remember where it was .
Parsing [sent. 1183 len. 4]: What was it ?
Parsing [sent. 1184 len. 6]: No business of anybody 's .
Parsing [sent. 1185 len. 5]: Had he inherited it ?
Parsing [sent. 1186 len. 5]: Yes , he had .
Parsing [sent. 1187 len. 3]: From whom ?
Parsing [sent. 1188 len. 3]: Distant relation .
Parsing [sent. 1189 len. 3]: Very distant ?
Parsing [sent. 1190 len. 2]: Rather .
Parsing [sent. 1191 len. 5]: Ever been in prison ?
Parsing [sent. 1192 len. 3]: Certainly not .
Parsing [sent. 1193 len. 7]: Never in a debtors ' prison ?
Parsing [sent. 1194 len. 11]: Did n't see what that had to do with it .
Parsing [sent. 1195 len. 7]: Never in a debtors ' prison ?
Parsing [sent. 1196 len. 6]: -- Come , once again .
Parsing [sent. 1197 len. 2]: Never ?
Parsing [sent. 1198 len. 2]: Yes .
Parsing [sent. 1199 len. 4]: How many times ?
Parsing [sent. 1200 len. 5]: Two or three times .
Parsing [sent. 1201 len. 5]: Not five or six ?
Parsing [sent. 1202 len. 2]: Perhaps .
Parsing [sent. 1203 len. 4]: Of what profession ?
Parsing [sent. 1204 len. 2]: Gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 1205 len. 4]: Ever been kicked ?
Parsing [sent. 1206 len. 4]: Might have been .
Parsing [sent. 1207 len. 2]: Frequently ?
Parsing [sent. 1208 len. 2]: No .
Parsing [sent. 1209 len. 4]: Ever kicked downstairs ?
Parsing [sent. 1210 len. 22]: Decidedly not ; once received a kick on the top of a staircase , and fell downstairs of his own accord .
Parsing [sent. 1211 len. 9]: Kicked on that occasion for cheating at dice ?
Parsing [sent. 1212 len. 21]: Something to that effect was said by the intoxicated liar who committed the assault , but it was not true .
Parsing [sent. 1213 len. 6]: Swear it was not true ?
Parsing [sent. 1214 len. 2]: Positively .
Parsing [sent. 1215 len. 7]: Ever live by cheating at play ?
Parsing [sent. 1216 len. 2]: Never .
Parsing [sent. 1217 len. 5]: Ever live by play ?
Parsing [sent. 1218 len. 7]: Not more than other gentlemen do .
Parsing [sent. 1219 len. 7]: Ever borrow money of the prisoner ?
Parsing [sent. 1220 len. 2]: Yes .
Parsing [sent. 1221 len. 4]: Ever pay him ?
Parsing [sent. 1222 len. 2]: No .
Parsing [sent. 1223 len. 27]: Was not this intimacy with the prisoner , in reality a very slight one , forced upon the prisoner in coaches , inns , and packets ?
Parsing [sent. 1224 len. 2]: No .
Parsing [sent. 1225 len. 9]: Sure he saw the prisoner with these lists ?
Parsing [sent. 1226 len. 2]: Certain .
Parsing [sent. 1227 len. 7]: Knew no more about the lists ?
Parsing [sent. 1228 len. 2]: No .
Parsing [sent. 1229 len. 9]: Had not procured them himself , for instance ?
Parsing [sent. 1230 len. 2]: No .
Parsing [sent. 1231 len. 8]: Expect to get anything by this evidence ?
Parsing [sent. 1232 len. 2]: No .
Parsing [sent. 1233 len. 12]: Not in regular government pay and employment , to lay traps ?
Parsing [sent. 1234 len. 4]: Oh dear no .
Parsing [sent. 1235 len. 5]: Or to do anything ?
Parsing [sent. 1236 len. 4]: Oh dear no .
Parsing [sent. 1237 len. 3]: Swear that ?
Parsing [sent. 1238 len. 5]: Over and over again .
Parsing [sent. 1239 len. 8]: No motives but motives of sheer patriotism ?
Parsing [sent. 1240 len. 3]: None whatever .
Parsing [sent. 1241 len. 18]: The virtuous servant , Roger Cly , swore his way through the case at a great rate .
Parsing [sent. 1242 len. 18]: He had taken service with the prisoner , in good faith and simplicity , four years ago .
Parsing [sent. 1243 len. 25]: He had asked the prisoner , aboard the Calais packet , if he wanted a handy fellow , and the prisoner had engaged him .
Parsing [sent. 1244 len. 24]: He had not asked the prisoner to take the handy fellow as an act of charity -- never thought of such a thing .
Parsing [sent. 1245 len. 20]: He began to have suspicions of the prisoner , and to keep an eye upon him , soon afterwards .
Parsing [sent. 1246 len. 26]: In arranging his clothes , while travelling , he had seen similar lists to these in the prisoner 's pockets , over and over again .
Parsing [sent. 1247 len. 14]: He had taken these lists from the drawer of the prisoner 's desk .
Parsing [sent. 1248 len. 8]: He had not put them there first .
Parsing [sent. 1249 len. 28]: He had seen the prisoner show these identical lists to French gentlemen at Calais , and similar lists to French gentlemen , both at Calais and Boulogne .
Parsing [sent. 1250 len. 16]: He loved his country , and could n't bear it , and had given information .
Parsing [sent. 1251 len. 30]: He had never been suspected of stealing a silver tea-pot ; he had been maligned respecting a mustard-pot , but it turned out to be only a plated one .
Parsing [sent. 1252 len. 17]: He had known the last witness seven or eight years ; that was merely a coincidence .
Parsing [sent. 1253 len. 15]: He did n't call it a particularly curious coincidence ; most coincidences were curious .
Parsing [sent. 1254 len. 17]: Neither did he call it a curious coincidence that true patriotism was HIS only motive too .
Parsing [sent. 1255 len. 14]: He was a true Briton , and hoped there were many like him .
Parsing [sent. 1256 len. 15]: The blue-flies buzzed again , and Mr. Attorney -- General called Mr. Jarvis Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 1257 len. 15]: `` Mr. Jarvis Lorry , are you a clerk in Tellson 's bank ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1258 len. 5]: `` I am . ''
Parsing [sent. 1259 len. 30]: `` On a certain Friday night in November one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five , did business occasion you to travel between London and Dover by the mail ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1260 len. 5]: `` It did . ''
Parsing [sent. 1261 len. 11]: `` Were there any other passengers in the mail ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1262 len. 4]: `` Two . ''
Parsing [sent. 1263 len. 15]: `` Did they alight on the road in the course of the night ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1264 len. 5]: `` They did . ''
Parsing [sent. 1265 len. 9]: `` Mr. Lorry , look upon the prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 1266 len. 9]: Was he one of those two passengers ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1267 len. 12]: `` I can not undertake to say that he was . ''
Parsing [sent. 1268 len. 11]: `` Does he resemble either of these two passengers ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1269 len. 32]: `` Both were so wrapped up , and the night was so dark , and we were all so reserved , that I can not undertake to say even that . ''
Parsing [sent. 1270 len. 10]: `` Mr. Lorry , look again upon the prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 1271 len. 30]: Supposing him wrapped up as those two passengers were , is there anything in his bulk and stature to render it unlikely that he was one of them ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1272 len. 4]: `` No . ''
Parsing [sent. 1273 len. 18]: `` You will not swear , Mr. Lorry , that he was not one of them ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1274 len. 4]: `` No . ''
Parsing [sent. 1275 len. 15]: `` So at least you say he may have been one of them ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1276 len. 3]: `` Yes .
Parsing [sent. 1277 len. 27]: Except that I remember them both to have been -- like myself -- timorous of highwaymen , and the prisoner has not a timorous air . ''
Parsing [sent. 1278 len. 14]: `` Did you ever see a counterfeit of timidity , Mr. Lorry ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1279 len. 8]: `` I certainly have seen that . ''
Parsing [sent. 1280 len. 11]: `` Mr. Lorry , look once more upon the prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 1281 len. 13]: Have you seen him , to your certain knowledge , before ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1282 len. 5]: `` I have . ''
Parsing [sent. 1283 len. 4]: `` When ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1284 len. 36]: `` I was returning from France a few days afterwards , and , at Calais , the prisoner came on board the packet-ship in which I returned , and made the voyage with me . ''
Parsing [sent. 1285 len. 11]: `` At what hour did he come on board ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1286 len. 8]: `` At a little after midnight . ''
Parsing [sent. 1287 len. 8]: `` In the dead of the night .
Parsing [sent. 1288 len. 15]: Was he the only passenger who came on board at that untimely hour ? ''

Parsing [sent. 1290 len. 11]: `` Never mind about ` happening , ' Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 1291 len. 17]: He was the only passenger who came on board in the dead of the night ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1292 len. 5]: `` He was . ''
Parsing [sent. 1293 len. 15]: `` Were you travelling alone , Mr. Lorry , or with any companion ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1294 len. 5]: `` With two companions .
Parsing [sent. 1295 len. 5]: A gentleman and lady .
Parsing [sent. 1296 len. 5]: They are here . ''
Parsing [sent. 1297 len. 5]: `` They are here .
Parsing [sent. 1298 len. 9]: Had you any conversation with the prisoner ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1299 len. 4]: `` Hardly any .
Parsing [sent. 1300 len. 26]: The weather was stormy , and the passage long and rough , and I lay on a sofa , almost from shore to shore . ''
Parsing [sent. 1301 len. 5]: `` Miss Manette ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1302 len. 26]: The young lady , to whom all eyes had been turned before , and were now turned again , stood up where she had sat .
Parsing [sent. 1303 len. 15]: Her father rose with her , and kept her hand drawn through his arm .
Parsing [sent. 1304 len. 10]: `` Miss Manette , look upon the prisoner . ''
Parsing [sent. 1305 len. 30]: To be confronted with such pity , and such earnest youth and beauty , was far more trying to the accused than to be confronted with all the crowd .
Parsing [sent. 1306 len. 38]: Standing , as it were , apart with her on the edge of his grave , not all the staring curiosity that looked on , could , for the moment , nerve him to remain quite still .
Parsing [sent. 1307 len. 40]: His hurried right hand parcelled out the herbs before him into imaginary beds of flowers in a garden ; and his efforts to control and steady his breathing shook the lips from which the colour rushed to his heart .
Parsing [sent. 1308 len. 10]: The buzz of the great flies was loud again .
Parsing [sent. 1309 len. 12]: `` Miss Manette , have you seen the prisoner before ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1310 len. 6]: `` Yes , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 1311 len. 4]: `` Where ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1312 len. 20]: `` On board of the packet-ship just now referred to , sir , and on the same occasion . ''
Parsing [sent. 1313 len. 12]: `` You are the young lady just now referred to ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1314 len. 3]: `` O !
Parsing [sent. 1315 len. 7]: most unhappily , I am ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1316 len. 38]: The plaintive tone of her compassion merged into the less musical voice of the Judge , as he said something fiercely : `` Answer the questions put to you , and make no remark upon them . ''
Parsing [sent. 1317 len. 19]: `` Miss Manette , had you any conversation with the prisoner on that passage across the Channel ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1318 len. 6]: `` Yes , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 1319 len. 5]: `` Recall it . ''
Parsing [sent. 1320 len. 29]: In the midst of a profound stillness , she faintly began : `` When the gentleman came on board -- '' `` Do you mean the prisoner ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1321 len. 8]: inquired the Judge , knitting his brows .
Parsing [sent. 1322 len. 7]: `` Yes , my Lord . ''
Parsing [sent. 1323 len. 7]: `` Then say the prisoner . ''
Parsing [sent. 1324 len. 40]: `` When the prisoner came on board , he noticed that my father , '' turning her eyes lovingly to him as he stood beside her , `` was much fatigued and in a very weak state of health .
Parsing [sent. 1325 len. 48]: My father was so reduced that I was afraid to take him out of the air , and I had made a bed for him on the deck near the cabin steps , and I sat on the deck at his side to take care of him .
Parsing [sent. 1326 len. 12]: There were no other passengers that night , but we four .
Parsing [sent. 1327 len. 30]: The prisoner was so good as to beg permission to advise me how I could shelter my father from the wind and weather , better than I had done .
Parsing [sent. 1328 len. 25]: I had not known how to do it well , not understanding how the wind would set when we were out of the harbour .
Parsing [sent. 1329 len. 6]: He did it for me .
Parsing [sent. 1330 len. 20]: He expressed great gentleness and kindness for my father 's state , and I am sure he felt it .
Parsing [sent. 1331 len. 12]: That was the manner of our beginning to speak together . ''
Parsing [sent. 1332 len. 9]: `` Let me interrupt you for a moment .
Parsing [sent. 1333 len. 8]: Had he come on board alone ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1334 len. 4]: `` No . ''
Parsing [sent. 1335 len. 8]: `` How many were with him ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1336 len. 6]: `` Two French gentlemen . ''
Parsing [sent. 1337 len. 7]: `` Had they conferred together ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1338 len. 26]: `` They had conferred together until the last moment , when it was necessary for the French gentlemen to be landed in their boat . ''
Parsing [sent. 1339 len. 16]: `` Had any papers been handed about among them , similar to these lists ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1340 len. 19]: `` Some papers had been handed about among them , but I do n't know what papers . ''
Parsing [sent. 1341 len. 9]: `` Like these in shape and size ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1342 len. 72]: `` Possibly , but indeed I do n't know , although they stood whispering very near to me : because they stood at the top of the cabin steps to have the light of the lamp that was hanging there ; it was a dull lamp , and they spoke very low , and I did not hear what they said , and saw only that they looked at papers . ''
Parsing [sent. 1343 len. 13]: `` Now , to the prisoner 's conversation , Miss Manette . ''
Parsing [sent. 1344 len. 34]: `` The prisoner was as open in his confidence with me -- which arose out of my helpless situation -- as he was kind , and good , and useful to my father .
Parsing [sent. 1345 len. 21]: I hope , '' bursting into tears , `` I may not repay him by doing him harm to-day . ''
Parsing [sent. 1346 len. 5]: Buzzing from the blue-flies .
Parsing [sent. 1347 len. 52]: `` Miss Manette , if the prisoner does not perfectly understand that you give the evidence which it is your duty to give -- which you must give -- and which you can not escape from giving -- with great unwillingness , he is the only person present in that condition .
Parsing [sent. 1348 len. 6]: Please to go on . ''
Parsing [sent. 1349 len. 35]: `` He told me that he was travelling on business of a delicate and difficult nature , which might get people into trouble , and that he was therefore travelling under an assumed name .
Parsing [sent. 1350 len. 40]: He said that this business had , within a few days , taken him to France , and might , at intervals , take him backwards and forwards between France and England for a long time to come . ''
Parsing [sent. 1351 len. 11]: `` Did he say anything about America , Miss Manette ?
Parsing [sent. 1352 len. 4]: Be particular . ''
Parsing [sent. 1353 len. 37]: `` He tried to explain to me how that quarrel had arisen , and he said that , so far as he could judge , it was a wrong and foolish one on England 's part .
Parsing [sent. 1354 len. 26]: He added , in a jesting way , that perhaps George Washington might gain almost as great a name in history as George the Third .
Parsing [sent. 1355 len. 24]: But there was no harm in his way of saying this : it was said laughingly , and to beguile the time . ''
Parsing [sent. 1356 len. 34]: Any strongly marked expression of face on the part of a chief actor in a scene of great interest to whom many eyes are directed , will be unconsciously imitated by the spectators .
Parsing [sent. 1357 len. 39]: Her forehead was painfully anxious and intent as she gave this evidence , and , in the pauses when she stopped for the Judge to write it down , watched its effect upon the counsel for and against .
Parsing [sent. 1358 len. 52]: Among the lookers-on there was the same expression in all quarters of the court ; insomuch , that a great majority of the foreheads there , might have been mirrors reflecting the witness , when the Judge looked up from his notes to glare at that tremendous heresy about George Washington .
Parsing [sent. 1359 len. 35]: Mr. Attorney -- General now signified to my Lord , that he deemed it necessary , as a matter of precaution and form , to call the young lady 's father , Doctor Manette .
Parsing [sent. 1360 len. 5]: Who was called accordingly .
Parsing [sent. 1361 len. 9]: `` Doctor Manette , look upon the prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 1362 len. 8]: Have you ever seen him before ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1363 len. 3]: `` Once .
Parsing [sent. 1364 len. 9]: When he caged at my lodgings in London .
Parsing [sent. 1365 len. 13]: Some three years , or three years and a half ago . ''
Parsing [sent. 1366 len. 23]: `` Can you identify him as your fellow-passenger on board the packet , or speak to his conversation with your daughter ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1367 len. 9]: `` Sir , I can do neither . ''
Parsing [sent. 1368 len. 17]: `` Is there any particular and special reason for your being unable to do either ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1369 len. 13]: He answered , in a low voice , `` There is . ''
Parsing [sent. 1370 len. 28]: `` Has it been your misfortune to undergo a long imprisonment , without trial , or even accusation , in your native country , Doctor Manette ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1371 len. 18]: He answered , in a tone that went to every heart , `` A long imprisonment . ''
Parsing [sent. 1372 len. 12]: `` Were you newly released on the occasion in question ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1373 len. 7]: `` They tell me so . ''
Parsing [sent. 1374 len. 10]: `` Have you no remembrance of the occasion ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1375 len. 3]: `` None .
Parsing [sent. 1376 len. 47]: My mind is a blank , from some time -- I can not even say what time -- when I employed myself , in my captivity , in making shoes , to the time when I found myself living in London with my dear daughter here .
Parsing [sent. 1377 len. 30]: She had become familiar to me , when a gracious God restored my faculties ; but , I am quite unable even to say how she had become familiar .
Parsing [sent. 1378 len. 9]: I have no remembrance of the process . ''
Parsing [sent. 1379 len. 16]: Mr. Attorney -- General sat down , and the father and daughter sat down together .
Parsing [sent. 1380 len. 9]: A singular circumstance then arose in the case .
Parsing [sent. 1381 len. 110]: The object in hand being to show that the prisoner went down , with some fellow-plotter untracked , in the Dover mail on that Friday night in November five years ago , and got out of the mail in the night , as a blind , at a place where he did not remain , but from which he travelled back some dozen miles or more , to a garrison and dockyard , and there collected information ; a witness was called to identify him as having been at the precise time required , in the coffee-room of an hotel in that garrison-and-dockyard town , waiting for another person .
Parsing [sent. 1382 len. 65]: The prisoner 's counsel was cross-examining this witness with no result , except that he had never seen the prisoner on any other occasion , when the wigged gentleman who had all this time been looking at the ceiling of the court , wrote a word or two on a little piece of paper , screwed it up , and tossed it to him .
Parsing [sent. 1383 len. 22]: Opening this piece of paper in the next pause , the counsel looked with great attention and curiosity at the prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 1384 len. 15]: `` You say again you are quite sure that it was the prisoner ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1385 len. 6]: The witness was quite sure .
Parsing [sent. 1386 len. 12]: `` Did you ever see anybody very like the prisoner ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1387 len. 15]: Not so like -LRB- the witness said -RRB- as that he could be mistaken .
Parsing [sent. 1388 len. 32]: `` Look well upon that gentleman , my learned friend there , '' pointing to him who had tossed the paper over , `` and then look well upon the prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 1389 len. 4]: How say you ?
Parsing [sent. 1390 len. 8]: Are they very like each other ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1391 len. 41]: Allowing for my learned friend 's appearance being careless and slovenly if not debauched , they were sufficiently like each other to surprise , not only the witness , but everybody present , when they were thus brought into comparison .
Parsing [sent. 1392 len. 28]: My Lord being prayed to bid my learned friend lay aside his wig , and giving no very gracious consent , the likeness became much more remarkable .
Parsing [sent. 1393 len. 31]: My Lord inquired of Mr. Stryver -LRB- the prisoner 's counsel -RRB- , whether they were next to try Mr. Carton -LRB- name of my learned friend -RRB- for treason ?
Parsing [sent. 1394 len. 61]: But , Mr. Stryver replied to my Lord , no ; but he would ask the witness to tell him whether what happened once , might happen twice ; whether he would have been so confident if he had seen this illustration of his rashness sooner , whether he would be so confident , having seen it ; and more .
Parsing [sent. 1395 len. 27]: The upshot of which , was , to smash this witness like a crockery vessel , and shiver his part of the case to useless lumber .
Parsing [sent. 1396 len. 22]: Mr. Cruncher had by this time taken quite a lunch of rust off his fingers in his following of the evidence .
Parsing [sent. 1397 len. 65]: He had now to attend while Mr. Stryver fitted the prisoner 's case on the jury , like a compact suit of clothes ; showing them how the patriot , Barsad , was a hired spy and traitor , an unblushing trafficker in blood , and one of the greatest scoundrels upon earth since accursed Judas -- which he certainly did look rather like .
Parsing [sent. 1398 len. 90]: How the virtuous servant , Cly , was his friend and partner , and was worthy to be ; how the watchful eyes of those forgers and false swearers had rested on the prisoner as a victim , because some family affairs in France , he being of French extraction , did require his making those passages across the Channel -- though what those affairs were , a consideration for others who were near and dear to him , forbade him , even for his life , to disclose .
Parsing [sent. 1399 len. 80]: How the evidence that had been warped and wrested from the young lady , whose anguish in giving it they had witnessed , came to nothing , involving the mere little innocent gallantries and politenesses likely to pass between any young gentleman and young lady so thrown together ; -- with the exception of that reference to George Washington , which was altogether too extravagant and impossible to be regarded in any other light than as a monstrous joke .
Parsing [sent. 1400 len. 75]: How it would be a weakness in the government to break down in this attempt to practise for popularity on the lowest national antipathies and fears , and therefore Mr. Attorney -- General had made the most of it ; how , nevertheless , it rested upon nothing , save that vile and infamous character of evidence too often disfiguring such cases , and of which the State Trials of this country were full .
Parsing [sent. 1401 len. 35]: But , there my Lord interposed -LRB- with as grave a face as if it had not been true -RRB- , saying that he could not sit upon that Bench and suffer those allusions .
Parsing [sent. 1402 len. 62]: Mr. Stryver then called his few witnesses , and Mr. Cruncher had next to attend while Mr. Attorney -- General turned the whole suit of clothes Mr. Stryver had fitted on the jury , inside out ; showing how Barsad and Cly were even a hundred times better than he had thought them , and the prisoner a hundred times worse .
Parsing [sent. 1403 len. 36]: Lastly , came my Lord himself , turning the suit of clothes , now inside out , now outside in , but on the whole decidedly trimming and shaping them into grave-clothes for the prisoner .
Parsing [sent. 1404 len. 16]: And now , the jury turned to consider , and the great flies swarmed again .
Parsing [sent. 1405 len. 29]: Mr. Carton , who had so long sat looking at the ceiling of the court , changed neither his place nor his attitude , even in this excitement .
Parsing [sent. 1406 len. 135]: While his teamed friend , Mr. Stryver , massing his papers before him , whispered with those who sat near , and from time to time glanced anxiously at the jury ; while all the spectators moved more or less , and grouped themselves anew ; while even my Lord himself arose from his seat , and slowly paced up and down his platform , not unattended by a suspicion in the minds of the audience that his state was feverish ; this one man sat leaning back , with his torn gown half off him , his untidy wig put on just as it had happened to fight on his head after its removal , his hands in his pockets , and his eyes on the ceiling as they had been all day .
Parsing [sent. 1407 len. 70]: Something especially reckless in his demeanour , not only gave him a disreputable look , but so diminished the strong resemblance he undoubtedly bore to the prisoner -LRB- which his momentary earnestness , when they were compared together , had strengthened -RRB- , that many of the lookers-on , taking note of him now , said to one another they would hardly have thought the two were so alike .

Parsing [sent. 1470 len. 73]: IV Congratulatory From the dimly-lighted passages of the court , the last sediment of the human stew that had been boiling there all day , was straining off , when Doctor Manette , Lucie Manette , his daughter , Mr. Lorry , the solicitor for the defence , and its counsel , Mr. Stryver , stood gathered round Mr. Charles Darnay -- just released -- congratulating him on his escape from death .
Parsing [sent. 1471 len. 33]: It would have been difficult by a far brighter light , to recognise in Doctor Manette , intellectual of face and upright of bearing , the shoemaker of the garret in Paris .
Parsing [sent. 1472 len. 48]: Yet , no one could have looked at him twice , without looking again : even though the opportunity of observation had not extended to the mournful cadence of his low grave voice , and to the abstraction that overclouded him fitfully , without any apparent reason .
Parsing [sent. 1473 len. 88]: While one external cause , and that a reference to his long lingering agony , would always -- as on the trial -- evoke this condition from the depths of his soul , it was also in its nature to arise of itself , and to draw a gloom over him , as incomprehensible to those unacquainted with his story as if they had seen the shadow of the actual Bastille thrown upon him by a summer sun , when the substance was three hundred miles away .
Parsing [sent. 1474 len. 15]: Only his daughter had the power of charming this black brooding from his mind .
Parsing [sent. 1475 len. 52]: She was the golden thread that united him to a Past beyond his misery , and to a Present beyond his misery : and the sound of her voice , the light of her face , the touch of her hand , had a strong beneficial influence with him almost always .
Parsing [sent. 1476 len. 30]: Not absolutely always , for she could recall some occasions on which her power had failed ; but they were few and slight , and she believed them over .
Parsing [sent. 1477 len. 22]: Mr. Darnay had kissed her hand fervently and gratefully , and had turned to Mr. Stryver , whom he warmly thanked .
Parsing [sent. 1478 len. 65]: Mr. Stryver , a man of little more than thirty , but looking twenty years older than he was , stout , loud , red , bluff , and free from any drawback of delicacy , had a pushing way of shouldering himself -LRB- morally and physically -RRB- into companies and conversations , that argued well for his shouldering his way up in life .
Parsing [sent. 1479 len. 50]: He still had his wig and gown on , and he said , squaring himself at his late client to that degree that he squeezed the innocent Mr. Lorry clean out of the group : `` I am glad to have brought you off with honour , Mr. Darnay .
Parsing [sent. 1480 len. 21]: It was an infamous prosecution , grossly infamous ; but not the less likely to succeed on that account . ''
Parsing [sent. 1481 len. 27]: `` You have laid me under an obligation to you for life -- in two senses , '' said his late client , taking his hand .
Parsing [sent. 1482 len. 27]: `` I have done my best for you , Mr. Darnay ; and my best is as good as another man 's , I believe . ''
Parsing [sent. 1483 len. 36]: It clearly being incumbent on some one to say , `` Much better , '' Mr. Lorry said it ; perhaps not quite disinterestedly , but with the interested object of squeezing himself back again .
Parsing [sent. 1484 len. 6]: `` You think so ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1485 len. 4]: said Mr. Stryver .
Parsing [sent. 1486 len. 3]: `` Well !
Parsing [sent. 1487 len. 13]: you have been present all day , and you ought to know .
Parsing [sent. 1488 len. 10]: You are a man of business , too . ''
Parsing [sent. 1489 len. 59]: `` And as such , '' quoth Mr. Lorry , whom the counsel learned in the law had now shouldered back into the group , just as he had previously shouldered him out of it -- `` as such I will appeal to Doctor Manette , to break up this conference and order us all to our homes .
Parsing [sent. 1490 len. 19]: Miss Lucie looks ill , Mr. Darnay has had a terrible day , we are worn out . ''
Parsing [sent. 1491 len. 23]: `` Speak for yourself , Mr. Lorry , '' said Stryver ; `` I have a night 's work to do yet .

Parsing [sent. 1494 len. 15]: He asked her the question pointedly , and with a glance at her father .

Parsing [sent. 1496 len. 12]: With this strange expression on him his thoughts had wandered away .
Parsing [sent. 1497 len. 15]: `` My father , '' said Lucie , softly laying her hand on his .
Parsing [sent. 1498 len. 12]: He slowly shook the shadow off , and turned to her .
Parsing [sent. 1499 len. 10]: `` Shall we go home , my father ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1500 len. 11]: With a long breath , he answered `` Yes . ''
Parsing [sent. 1501 len. 28]: The friends of the acquitted prisoner had dispersed , under the impression -- which he himself had originated -- that he would not be released that night .
Parsing [sent. 1502 len. 48]: The lights were nearly all extinguished in the passages , the iron gates were being closed with a jar and a rattle , and the dismal place was deserted until to-morrow morning 's interest of gallows , pillory , whipping-post , and branding-iron , should repeople it .

Parsing [sent. 1507 len. 16]: He now stepped up to where Mr. Lorry and Mr. Darnay stood upon the pavement .
Parsing [sent. 1508 len. 6]: `` So , Mr. Lorry !
Parsing [sent. 1509 len. 11]: Men of business may speak to Mr. Darnay now ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1510 len. 22]: Nobody had made any acknowledgment of Mr. Carton 's part in the day 's proceedings ; nobody had known of it .
Parsing [sent. 1511 len. 14]: He was unrobed , and was none the better for it in appearance .
Parsing [sent. 1512 len. 36]: `` If you knew what a conflict goes on in the business mind , when the business mind is divided between good-natured impulse and business appearances , you would be amused , Mr. Darnay . ''
Parsing [sent. 1513 len. 18]: Mr. Lorry reddened , and said , warmly , `` You have mentioned that before , sir .
