Parsing [sent. 2822 len. 45]: `` Then I say yes , '' said Stryver : `` I wo n't go up there now , I am not so hot upon it as that comes to ; I say yes , and I shall expect you to look in to-night .
Parsing [sent. 2823 len. 4]: Good morning . ''
Parsing [sent. 2824 len. 45]: Then Mr. Stryver turned and burst out of the Bank , causing such a concussion of air on his passage through , that to stand up against it bowing behind the two counters , required the utmost remaining strength of the two ancient clerks .
Parsing [sent. 2825 len. 46]: Those venerable and feeble persons were always seen by the public in the act of bowing , and were popularly believed , when they had bowed a customer out , still to keep on bowing in the empty office until they bowed another customer in .
Parsing [sent. 2826 len. 30]: The barrister was keen enough to divine that the banker would not have gone so far in his expression of opinion on any less solid ground than moral certainty .
Parsing [sent. 2827 len. 18]: Unprepared as he was for the large pill he had to swallow , he got it down .
Parsing [sent. 2828 len. 42]: `` And now , '' said Mr. Stryver , shaking his forensic forefinger at the Temple in general , when it was down , `` my way out of this , is , to put you all in the wrong . ''
Parsing [sent. 2829 len. 20]: It was a bit of the art of an Old Bailey tactician , in which he found great relief .
Parsing [sent. 2830 len. 27]: `` You shall not put me in the wrong , young lady , '' said Mr. Stryver ; `` I 'll do that for you . ''
Parsing [sent. 2831 len. 45]: Accordingly , when Mr. Lorry called that night as late as ten o'clock , Mr. Stryver , among a quantity of books and papers littered out for the purpose , seemed to have nothing less on his mind than the subject of the morning .
Parsing [sent. 2832 len. 20]: He even showed surprise when he saw Mr. Lorry , and was altogether in an absent and preoccupied state .
Parsing [sent. 2833 len. 4]: `` Well ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2834 len. 20]: said that good-natured emissary , after a full half-hour of bootless attempts to bring him round to the question .
Parsing [sent. 2835 len. 8]: `` I have been to Soho . ''
Parsing [sent. 2836 len. 5]: `` To Soho ? ''
Parsing [sent. 2837 len. 6]: repeated Mr. Stryver , coldly .
Parsing [sent. 2838 len. 7]: `` Oh , to be sure !
Parsing [sent. 2839 len. 7]: What am I thinking of ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2840 len. 23]: `` And I have no doubt , '' said Mr. Lorry , `` that I was right in the conversation we had .
Parsing [sent. 2841 len. 12]: My opinion is confirmed , and I reiterate my advice . ''
Parsing [sent. 2842 len. 37]: `` I assure you , '' returned Mr. Stryver , in the friendliest way , `` that I am sorry for it on your account , and sorry for it on the poor father 's account .
Parsing [sent. 2843 len. 22]: I know this must always be a sore subject with the family ; let us say no more about it . ''
Parsing [sent. 2844 len. 12]: `` I do n't understand you , '' said Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 2845 len. 28]: `` I dare say not , '' rejoined Stryver , nodding his head in a smoothing and final way ; `` no matter , no matter . ''
Parsing [sent. 2846 len. 11]: `` But it does matter , '' Mr. Lorry urged .
Parsing [sent. 2847 len. 13]: `` No it does n't ; I assure you it does n't .
Parsing [sent. 2848 len. 38]: Having supposed that there was sense where there is no sense , and a laudable ambition where there is not a laudable ambition , I am well out of my mistake , and no harm is done .
Parsing [sent. 2849 len. 20]: Young women have committed similar follies often before , and have repented them in poverty and obscurity often before .
Parsing [sent. 2850 len. 76]: In an unselfish aspect , I am sorry that the thing is dropped , because it would have been a bad thing for me in a worldly point of view ; in a selfish aspect , I am glad that the thing has dropped , because it would have been a bad thing for me in a worldly point of view -- it is hardly necessary to say I could have gained nothing by it .
Parsing [sent. 2851 len. 8]: There is no harm at all done .

Parsing [sent. 2861 len. 24]: XIII The Fellow of No Delicacy If Sydney Carton ever shone anywhere , he certainly never shone in the house of Doctor Manette .
Parsing [sent. 2862 len. 23]: He had been there often , during a whole year , and had always been the same moody and morose lounger there .
Parsing [sent. 2863 len. 38]: When he cared to talk , he talked well ; but , the cloud of caring for nothing , which overshadowed him with such a fatal darkness , was very rarely pierced by the light within him .
Parsing [sent. 2864 len. 24]: And yet he did care something for the streets that environed that house , and for the senseless stones that made their pavements .
Parsing [sent. 2865 len. 80]: Many a night he vaguely and unhappily wandered there , when wine had brought no transitory gladness to him ; many a dreary daybreak revealed his solitary figure lingering there , and still lingering there when the first beams of the sun brought into strong relief , removed beauties of architecture in spires of churches and lofty buildings , as perhaps the quiet time brought some sense of better things , else forgotten and unattainable , into his mind .
Parsing [sent. 2866 len. 45]: Of late , the neglected bed in the Temple Court had known him more scantily than ever ; and often when he had thrown himself upon it no longer than a few minutes , he had got up again , and haunted that neighbourhood .
Parsing [sent. 2867 len. 78]: On a day in August , when Mr. Stryver -LRB- after notifying to his jackal that `` he had thought better of that marrying matter '' -RRB- had carried his delicacy into Devonshire , and when the sight and scent of flowers in the City streets had some waifs of goodness in them for the worst , of health for the sickliest , and of youth for the oldest , Sydney 's feet still trod those stones .
Parsing [sent. 2868 len. 33]: From being irresolute and purposeless , his feet became animated by an intention , and , in the working out of that intention , they took him to the Doctor 's door .
Parsing [sent. 2869 len. 14]: He was shown up-stairs , and found Lucie at her work , alone .
Parsing [sent. 2870 len. 26]: She had never been quite at her ease with him , and received him with some little embarrassment as he seated himself near her table .
Parsing [sent. 2871 len. 23]: But , looking up at his face in the interchange of the first few common-places , she observed a change in it .

Parsing [sent. 2963 len. 39]: XIV The Honest Tradesman To the eyes of Mr. Jeremiah Cruncher , sitting on his stool in Fleet-street with his grisly urchin beside him , a vast number and variety of objects in movement were every day presented .
Parsing [sent. 2964 len. 62]: Who could sit upon anything in Fleet-street during the busy hours of the day , and not be dazed and deafened by two immense processions , one ever tending westward with the sun , the other ever tending eastward from the sun , both ever tending to the plains beyond the range of red and purple where the sun goes down !
Parsing [sent. 2965 len. 43]: With his straw in his mouth , Mr. Cruncher sat watching the two streams , like the heathen rustic who has for several centuries been on duty watching one stream -- saving that Jerry had no expectation of their ever running dry .
Parsing [sent. 2966 len. 53]: Nor would it have been an expectation of a hopeful kind , since a small part of his income was derived from the pilotage of timid women -LRB- mostly of a full habit and past the middle term of life -RRB- from Tellson 's side of the tides to the opposite shore .
Parsing [sent. 2967 len. 38]: Brief as such companionship was in every separate instance , Mr. Cruncher never failed to become so interested in the lady as to express a strong desire to have the honour of drinking her very good health .
Parsing [sent. 2968 len. 28]: And it was from the gifts bestowed upon him towards the execution of this benevolent purpose , that he recruited his finances , as just now observed .
Parsing [sent. 2969 len. 23]: Time was , when a poet sat upon a stool in a public place , and mused in the sight of men .
Parsing [sent. 2970 len. 29]: Mr. Cruncher , sitting on a stool in a public place , but not being a poet , mused as little as possible , and looked about him .
Parsing [sent. 2971 len. 66]: It fell out that he was thus engaged in a season when crowds were few , and belated women few , and when his affairs in general were so unprosperous as to awaken a strong suspicion in his breast that Mrs. Cruncher must have been `` flopping '' in some pointed manner , when an unusual concourse pouring down Fleet-street westward , attracted his attention .
Parsing [sent. 2972 len. 31]: Looking that way , Mr. Cruncher made out that some kind of funeral was coming along , and that there was popular objection to this funeral , which engendered uproar .

Parsing [sent. 3026 len. 3]: Spies ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3027 len. 51]: The idea was so acceptable in the prevalent absence of any idea , that the crowd caught it up with eagerness , and loudly repeating the suggestion to have 'em out , and to pull 'em out , mobbed the two vehicles so closely that they came to a stop .
Parsing [sent. 3028 len. 70]: On the crowd 's opening the coach doors , the one mourner scuffled out of himself and was in their hands for a moment ; but he was so alert , and made such good use of his time , that in another moment he was scouring away up a bye-street , after shedding his cloak , hat , long hatband , white pocket-handkerchief , and other symbolical tears .
Parsing [sent. 3029 len. 42]: These , the people tore to pieces and scattered far and wide with great enjoyment , while the tradesmen hurriedly shut up their shops ; for a crowd in those times stopped at nothing , and was a monster much dreaded .
Parsing [sent. 3030 len. 33]: They had already got the length of opening the hearse to take the coffin out , when some brighter genius proposed instead , its being escorted to its destination amidst general rejoicing .
Parsing [sent. 3031 len. 52]: Practical suggestions being much needed , this suggestion , too , was received with acclamation , and the coach was immediately filled with eight inside and a dozen out , while as many people got on the roof of the hearse as could by any exercise of ingenuity stick upon it .
Parsing [sent. 3032 len. 33]: Among the first of these volunteers was Jerry Cruncher himself , who modestly concealed his spiky head from the observation of Tellson 's , in the further corner of the mourning coach .
Parsing [sent. 3033 len. 48]: The officiating undertakers made some protest against these changes in the ceremonies ; but , the river being alarmingly near , and several voices remarking on the efficacy of cold immersion in bringing refractory members of the profession to reason , the protest was faint and brief .
Parsing [sent. 3034 len. 49]: The remodelled procession started , with a chimney-sweep driving the hearse -- advised by the regular driver , who was perched beside him , under close inspection , for the purpose -- and with a pieman , also attended by his cabinet minister , driving the mourning coach .
Parsing [sent. 3035 len. 55]: A bear-leader , a popular street character of the time , was impressed as an additional ornament , before the cavalcade had gone far down the Strand ; and his bear , who was black and very mangy , gave quite an Undertaking air to that part of the procession in which he walked .
Parsing [sent. 3036 len. 36]: Thus , with beer-drinking , pipe-smoking , song-roaring , and infinite caricaturing of woe , the disorderly procession went its way , recruiting at every step , and all the shops shutting up before it .
Parsing [sent. 3037 len. 16]: Its destination was the old church of Saint Pancras , far off in the fields .
Parsing [sent. 3038 len. 37]: It got there in course of time ; insisted on pouring into the burial-ground ; finally , accomplished the interment of the deceased Roger Cly in its own way , and highly to its own satisfaction .
Parsing [sent. 3039 len. 49]: The dead man disposed of , and the crowd being under the necessity of providing some other entertainment for itself , another brighter genius -LRB- or perhaps the same -RRB- conceived the humour of impeaching casual passers-by , as Old Bailey spies , and wreaking vengeance on them .
Parsing [sent. 3040 len. 36]: Chase was given to some scores of inoffensive persons who had never been near the Old Bailey in their lives , in the realisation of this fancy , and they were roughly hustled and maltreated .
Parsing [sent. 3041 len. 21]: The transition to the sport of window-breaking , and thence to the plundering of public-houses , was easy and natural .
Parsing [sent. 3042 len. 40]: At last , after several hours , when sundry summer-houses had been pulled down , and some area-railings had been torn up , to arm the more belligerent spirits , a rumour got about that the Guards were coming .
Parsing [sent. 3043 len. 32]: Before this rumour , the crowd gradually melted away , and perhaps the Guards came , and perhaps they never came , and this was the usual progress of a mob .
Parsing [sent. 3044 len. 26]: Mr. Cruncher did not assist at the closing sports , but had remained behind in the churchyard , to confer and condole with the undertakers .
Parsing [sent. 3045 len. 9]: The place had a soothing influence on him .
Parsing [sent. 3046 len. 24]: He procured a pipe from a neighbouring public-house , and smoked it , looking in at the railings and maturely considering the spot .
Parsing [sent. 3047 len. 46]: `` Jerry , '' said Mr. Cruncher , apostrophising himself in his usual way , `` you see that there Cly that day , and you see with your own eyes that he was a young ` un and a straight made ` un . ''
Parsing [sent. 3048 len. 35]: Having smoked his pipe out , and ruminated a little longer , he turned himself about , that he might appear , before the hour of closing , on his station at Tellson 's .
Parsing [sent. 3049 len. 65]: Whether his meditations on mortality had touched his liver , or whether his general health had been previously at all amiss , or whether he desired to show a little attention to an eminent man , is not so much to the purpose , as that he made a short call upon his medical adviser -- a distinguished surgeon -- on his way back .
Parsing [sent. 3050 len. 17]: Young Jerry relieved his father with dutiful interest , and reported No job in his absence .
Parsing [sent. 3051 len. 27]: The bank closed , the ancient clerks came out , the usual watch was set , and Mr. Cruncher and his son went home to tea .

Parsing [sent. 3053 len. 10]: said Mr. Cruncher to his wife , on entering .

Parsing [sent. 3055 len. 8]: The dejected Mrs. Cruncher shook her head .
Parsing [sent. 3056 len. 12]: `` Why , you 're at it afore my face ! ''

Parsing [sent. 3059 len. 10]: `` Well , then ; do n't meditate nothing .

Parsing [sent. 3087 len. 38]: He devoted himself during the remainder of the evening to keeping a most vigilant watch on Mrs. Cruncher , and sullenly holding her in conversation that she might be prevented from meditating any petitions to his disadvantage .
Parsing [sent. 3088 len. 50]: With this view , he urged his son to hold her in conversation also , and led the unfortunate woman a hard life by dwelling on any causes of complaint he could bring against her , rather than he would leave her for a moment to her own reflections .
Parsing [sent. 3089 len. 26]: The devoutest person could have rendered no greater homage to the efficacy of an honest prayer than he did in this distrust of his wife .
Parsing [sent. 3090 len. 17]: It was as if a professed unbeliever in ghosts should be frightened by a ghost story .
Parsing [sent. 3091 len. 6]: `` And mind you ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3092 len. 4]: said Mr. Cruncher .

Parsing [sent. 3104 len. 52]: This touched Young Jerry on a tender place ; who adjured his mother to perform her first duty , and , whatever else she did or neglected , above all things to lay especial stress on the discharge of that maternal function so affectingly and delicately indicated by his other parent .
Parsing [sent. 3105 len. 30]: Thus the evening wore away with the Cruncher family , until Young Jerry was ordered to bed , and his mother , laid under similar injunctions , obeyed them .
Parsing [sent. 3106 len. 25]: Mr. Cruncher beguiled the earlier watches of the night with solitary pipes , and did not start upon his excursion until nearly one o'clock .
Parsing [sent. 3107 len. 52]: Towards that small and ghostly hour , he rose up from his chair , took a key out of his pocket , opened a locked cupboard , and brought forth a sack , a crowbar of convenient size , a rope and chain , and other fishing tackle of that nature .
Parsing [sent. 3108 len. 26]: Disposing these articles about him in skilful manner , he bestowed a parting defiance on Mrs. Cruncher , extinguished the light , and went out .
Parsing [sent. 3109 len. 24]: Young Jerry , who had only made a feint of undressing when he went to bed , was not long after his father .
Parsing [sent. 3110 len. 28]: Under cover of the darkness he followed out of the room , followed down the stairs , followed down the court , followed out into the streets .
Parsing [sent. 3111 len. 28]: He was in no uneasiness concerning his getting into the house again , for it was full of lodgers , and the door stood ajar all night .
Parsing [sent. 3112 len. 49]: Impelled by a laudable ambition to study the art and mystery of his father 's honest calling , Young Jerry , keeping as close to house fronts , walls , and doorways , as his eyes were close to one another , held his honoured parent in view .
Parsing [sent. 3113 len. 29]: The honoured parent steering Northward , had not gone far , when he was joined by another disciple of Izaak Walton , and the two trudged on together .
Parsing [sent. 3114 len. 31]: Within half an hour from the first starting , they were beyond the winking lamps , and the more than winking watchmen , and were out upon a lonely road .
Parsing [sent. 3115 len. 44]: Another fisherman was picked up here -- and that so silently , that if Young Jerry had been superstitious , he might have supposed the second follower of the gentle craft to have , all of a sudden , split himself into two .
Parsing [sent. 3116 len. 22]: The three went on , and Young Jerry went on , until the three stopped under a bank overhanging the road .
Parsing [sent. 3117 len. 18]: Upon the top of the bank was a low brick wall , surmounted by an iron railing .
Parsing [sent. 3118 len. 41]: In the shadow of bank and wall the three turned out of the road , and up a blind lane , of which the wall -- there , risen to some eight or ten feet high -- formed one side .
Parsing [sent. 3119 len. 43]: Crouching down in a corner , peeping up the lane , the next object that Young Jerry saw , was the form of his honoured parent , pretty well defined against a watery and clouded moon , nimbly scaling an iron gate .
Parsing [sent. 3120 len. 18]: He was soon over , and then the second fisherman got over , and then the third .
Parsing [sent. 3121 len. 20]: They all dropped softly on the ground within the gate , and lay there a little -- listening perhaps .
Parsing [sent. 3122 len. 11]: Then , they moved away on their hands and knees .
Parsing [sent. 3123 len. 20]: It was now Young Jerry 's turn to approach the gate : which he did , holding his breath .
Parsing [sent. 3124 len. 24]: Crouching down again in a corner there , and looking in , he made out the three fishermen creeping through some rank grass !
Parsing [sent. 3125 len. 40]: and all the gravestones in the churchyard -- it was a large churchyard that they were in -- looking on like ghosts in white , while the church tower itself looked on like the ghost of a monstrous giant .
Parsing [sent. 3126 len. 13]: They did not creep far , before they stopped and stood upright .
Parsing [sent. 3127 len. 7]: And then they began to fish .
Parsing [sent. 3128 len. 9]: They fished with a spade , at first .
Parsing [sent. 3129 len. 15]: Presently the honoured parent appeared to be adjusting some instrument like a great corkscrew .
Parsing [sent. 3130 len. 38]: Whatever tools they worked with , they worked hard , until the awful striking of the church clock so terrified Young Jerry , that he made off , with his hair as stiff as his father 's .
Parsing [sent. 3131 len. 27]: But , his long-cherished desire to know more about these matters , not only stopped him in his running away , but lured him back again .
Parsing [sent. 3132 len. 29]: They were still fishing perseveringly , when he peeped in at the gate for the second time ; but , now they seemed to have got a bite .
Parsing [sent. 3133 len. 23]: There was a screwing and complaining sound down below , and their bent figures were strained , as if by a weight .
Parsing [sent. 3134 len. 18]: By slow degrees the weight broke away the earth upon it , and came to the surface .
Parsing [sent. 3135 len. 57]: Young Jerry very well knew what it would be ; but , when he saw it , and saw his honoured parent about to wrench it open , he was so frightened , being new to the sight , that he made off again , and never stopped until he had run a mile or more .
Parsing [sent. 3136 len. 36]: He would not have stopped then , for anything less necessary than breath , it being a spectral sort of race that he ran , and one highly desirable to get to the end of .
Parsing [sent. 3137 len. 59]: He had a strong idea that the coffin he had seen was running after him ; and , pictured as hopping on behind him , bolt upright , upon its narrow end , always on the point of overtaking him and hopping on at his side -- perhaps taking his arm -- it was a pursuer to shun .
Parsing [sent. 3138 len. 53]: It was an inconsistent and ubiquitous fiend too , for , while it was making the whole night behind him dreadful , he darted out into the roadway to avoid dark alleys , fearful of its coming hopping out of them like a dropsical boy 's -- Kite without tail and wings .
Parsing [sent. 3139 len. 27]: It hid in doorways too , rubbing its horrible shoulders against doors , and drawing them up to its ears , as if it were laughing .
Parsing [sent. 3140 len. 19]: It got into shadows on the road , and lay cunningly on its back to trip him up .
Parsing [sent. 3141 len. 32]: All this time it was incessantly hopping on behind and gaining on him , so that when the boy got to his own door he had reason for being half dead .
Parsing [sent. 3142 len. 42]: And even then it would not leave him , but followed him upstairs with a bump on every stair , scrambled into bed with him , and bumped down , dead and heavy , on his breast when he fell asleep .
Parsing [sent. 3143 len. 29]: From his oppressed slumber , Young Jerry in his closet was awakened after daybreak and before sunrise , by the presence of his father in the family room .
Parsing [sent. 3144 len. 41]: Something had gone wrong with him ; at least , so Young Jerry inferred , from the circumstance of his holding Mrs. Cruncher by the ears , and knocking the back of her head against the head-board of the bed .
Parsing [sent. 3145 len. 18]: `` I told you I would , '' said Mr. Cruncher , `` and I did . ''

Parsing [sent. 3149 len. 15]: You was to honour and obey ; why the devil do n't you ? ''

Parsing [sent. 3154 len. 14]: `` You had n't taken to the dreadful business then , Jerry . ''

Parsing [sent. 3162 len. 14]: There was no fish for breakfast , and not much of anything else .

Parsing [sent. 3165 len. 45]: Young Jerry , walking with the stool under his arm at his father 's side along sunny and crowded Fleet-street , was a very different Young Jerry from him of the previous night , running home through darkness and solitude from his grim pursuer .

Parsing [sent. 3167 len. 39]: `` Father , '' said Young Jerry , as they walked along : taking care to keep at arm 's length and to have the stool well between them : `` what 's a Resurrection -- Man ? ''

''
Parsing [sent. 3183 len. 16]: XV Knitting There had been earlier drinking than usual in the wine-shop of Monsieur Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 3184 len. 28]: As early as six o'clock in the morning , sallow faces peeping through its barred windows had descried other faces within , bending over measures of wine .
Parsing [sent. 3185 len. 31]: Monsieur Defarge sold a very thin wine at the best of times , but it would seem to have been an unusually thin wine that he sold at this time .
Parsing [sent. 3186 len. 27]: A sour wine , moreover , or a souring , for its influence on the mood of those who drank it was to make them gloomy .
Parsing [sent. 3187 len. 33]: No vivacious Bacchanalian flame leaped out of the pressed grape of Monsieur Defarge : but , a smouldering fire that burnt in the dark , lay hidden in the dregs of it .
Parsing [sent. 3188 len. 23]: This had been the third morning in succession , on which there had been early drinking at the wine-shop of Monsieur Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 3189 len. 12]: It had begun on Monday , and here was Wednesday come .
Parsing [sent. 3190 len. 49]: There had been more of early brooding than drinking ; for , many men had listened and whispered and slunk about there from the time of the opening of the door , who could not have laid a piece of money on the counter to save their souls .
Parsing [sent. 3191 len. 49]: These were to the full as interested in the place , however , as if they could have commanded whole barrels of wine ; and they glided from seat to seat , and from corner to corner , swallowing talk in lieu of drink , with greedy looks .
Parsing [sent. 3192 len. 16]: Notwithstanding an unusual flow of company , the master of the wine-shop was not visible .
Parsing [sent. 3193 len. 73]: He was not missed ; for , nobody who crossed the threshold looked for him , nobody asked for him , nobody wondered to see only Madame Defarge in her seat , presiding over the distribution of wine , with a bowl of battered small coins before her , as much defaced and beaten out of their original impress as the small coinage of humanity from whose ragged pockets they had come .
Parsing [sent. 3194 len. 45]: A suspended interest and a prevalent absence of mind , were perhaps observed by the spies who looked in at the wine-shop , as they looked in at every place , high and low , from the kings palace to the criminal 's gaol .
Parsing [sent. 3195 len. 53]: Games at cards languished , players at dominoes musingly built towers with them , drinkers drew figures on the tables with spilt drops of wine , Madame Defarge herself picked out the pattern on her sleeve with her toothpick , and saw and heard something inaudible and invisible a long way off .
Parsing [sent. 3196 len. 14]: Thus , Saint Antoine in this vinous feature of his , until midday .
Parsing [sent. 3197 len. 38]: It was high noontide , when two dusty men passed through his streets and under his swinging lamps : of whom , one was Monsieur Defarge : the other a mender of roads in a blue cap .
Parsing [sent. 3198 len. 11]: All adust and athirst , the two entered the wine-shop .
Parsing [sent. 3199 len. 36]: Their arrival had lighted a kind of fire in the breast of Saint Antoine , fast spreading as they came along , which stirred and flickered in flames of faces at most doors and windows .
Parsing [sent. 3200 len. 30]: Yet , no one had followed them , and no man spoke when they entered the wine-shop , though the eyes of every man there were turned upon them .
Parsing [sent. 3201 len. 7]: `` Good day , gentlemen ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3202 len. 4]: said Monsieur Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 3203 len. 12]: It may have been a signal for loosening the general tongue .
Parsing [sent. 3204 len. 11]: It elicited an answering chorus of `` Good day ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3205 len. 16]: `` It is bad weather , gentlemen , '' said Defarge , shaking his head .
Parsing [sent. 3206 len. 21]: Upon which , every man looked at his neighbour , and then all cast down their eyes and sat silent .
Parsing [sent. 3207 len. 11]: Except one man , who got up and went out .
Parsing [sent. 3208 len. 29]: `` My wife , '' said Defarge aloud , addressing Madame Defarge : `` I have travelled certain leagues with this good mender of roads , called Jacques .
Parsing [sent. 3209 len. 17]: I met him -- by accident -- a day and half 's journey out of Paris .
Parsing [sent. 3210 len. 14]: He is a good child , this mender of roads , called Jacques .
Parsing [sent. 3211 len. 9]: Give him to drink , my wife ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3212 len. 9]: A second man got up and went out .
Parsing [sent. 3213 len. 24]: Madame Defarge set wine before the mender of roads called Jacques , who doffed his blue cap to the company , and drank .
Parsing [sent. 3214 len. 31]: In the breast of his blouse he carried some coarse dark bread ; he ate of this between whiles , and sat munching and drinking near Madame Defarge 's counter .
Parsing [sent. 3215 len. 9]: A third man got up and went out .
Parsing [sent. 3216 len. 44]: Defarge refreshed himself with a draught of wine -- but , he took less than was given to the stranger , as being himself a man to whom it was no rarity -- and stood waiting until the countryman had made his breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 3217 len. 32]: He looked at no one present , and no one now looked at him ; not even Madame Defarge , who had taken up her knitting , and was at work .
Parsing [sent. 3218 len. 10]: `` Have you finished your repast , friend ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3219 len. 7]: he asked , in due season .
Parsing [sent. 3220 len. 7]: `` Yes , thank you . ''
Parsing [sent. 3221 len. 5]: `` Come , then !
Parsing [sent. 3222 len. 13]: You shall see the apartment that I told you you could occupy .
Parsing [sent. 3223 len. 9]: It will suit you to a marvel . ''
Parsing [sent. 3224 len. 56]: Out of the wine-shop into the street , out of the street into a courtyard , out of the courtyard up a steep staircase , out of the staircase into a garret , -- formerly the garret where a white-haired man sat on a low bench , stooping forward and very busy , making shoes .
Parsing [sent. 3225 len. 23]: No white-haired man was there now ; but , the three men were there who had gone out of the wine-shop singly .
Parsing [sent. 3226 len. 31]: And between them and the white-haired man afar off , was the one small link , that they had once looked in at him through the chinks in the wall .
Parsing [sent. 3227 len. 23]: Defarge closed the door carefully , and spoke in a subdued voice : `` Jacques One , Jacques Two , Jacques Three !
Parsing [sent. 3228 len. 14]: This is the witness encountered by appointment , by me , Jacques Four .
Parsing [sent. 3229 len. 6]: He will tell you all .
Parsing [sent. 3230 len. 6]: Speak , Jacques Five ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3231 len. 29]: The mender of roads , blue cap in hand , wiped his swarthy forehead with it , and said , `` Where shall I commence , monsieur ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3232 len. 18]: `` Commence , '' was Monsieur Defarge 's not unreasonable reply , `` at the commencement . ''
Parsing [sent. 3233 len. 35]: `` I saw him then , messieurs , '' began the mender of roads , `` a year ago this running summer , underneath the carriage of the Marquis , hanging by the chain .
Parsing [sent. 3234 len. 6]: Behold the manner of it .
Parsing [sent. 3235 len. 34]: I leaving my work on the road , the sun going to bed , the carriage of the Marquis slowly ascending the hill , he hanging by the chain -- like this . ''
Parsing [sent. 3236 len. 42]: Again the mender of roads went through the whole performance ; in which he ought to have been perfect by that time , seeing that it had been the infallible resource and indispensable entertainment of his village during a whole year .
Parsing [sent. 3237 len. 16]: Jacques One struck in , and asked if he had ever seen the man before ?
Parsing [sent. 3238 len. 14]: `` Never , '' answered the mender of roads , recovering his perpendicular .
Parsing [sent. 3239 len. 10]: Jacques Three demanded how he afterwards recognised him then ?
Parsing [sent. 3240 len. 23]: `` By his tall figure , '' said the mender of roads , softly , and with his finger at his nose .
Parsing [sent. 3241 len. 18]: `` When Monsieur the Marquis demands that evening , ` Say , what is he like ? '
Parsing [sent. 3242 len. 12]: I make response , ` Tall as a spectre . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 3243 len. 16]: `` You should have said , short as a dwarf , '' returned Jacques Two .
Parsing [sent. 3244 len. 7]: `` But what did I know ?
Parsing [sent. 3245 len. 14]: The deed was not then accomplished , neither did he confide in me .
Parsing [sent. 3246 len. 2]: Observe !
Parsing [sent. 3247 len. 12]: Under those circumstances even , I do not offer my testimony .
Parsing [sent. 3248 len. 22]: Monsieur the Marquis indicates me with his finger , standing near our little fountain , and says , ` To me !
Parsing [sent. 3249 len. 5]: Bring that rascal ! '
Parsing [sent. 3250 len. 10]: My faith , messieurs , I offer nothing . ''
Parsing [sent. 3251 len. 18]: `` He is right there , Jacques , '' murmured Defarge , to him who had interrupted .
Parsing [sent. 3252 len. 5]: `` Go on ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3253 len. 4]: `` Good ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3254 len. 12]: said the mender of roads , with an air of mystery .
Parsing [sent. 3255 len. 16]: `` The tall man is lost , and he is sought -- how many months ?
Parsing [sent. 3256 len. 7]: Nine , ten , eleven ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3257 len. 11]: `` No matter , the number , '' said Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 3258 len. 14]: `` He is well hidden , but at last he is unluckily found .
Parsing [sent. 3259 len. 4]: Go on ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3260 len. 21]: `` I am again at work upon the hill-side , and the sun is again about to go to bed .
Parsing [sent. 3261 len. 37]: I am collecting my tools to descend to my cottage down in the village below , where it is already dark , when I raise my eyes , and see coming over the hill six soldiers .
Parsing [sent. 3262 len. 23]: In the midst of them is a tall man with his arms bound -- tied to his sides -- like this ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3263 len. 29]: With the aid of his indispensable cap , he represented a man with his elbows bound fast at his hips , with cords that were knotted behind him .
Parsing [sent. 3264 len. 95]: `` I stand aside , messieurs , by my heap of stones , to see the soldiers and their prisoner pass -LRB- for it is a solitary road , that , where any spectacle is well worth looking at -RRB- , and at first , as they approach , I see no more than that they are six soldiers with a tall man bound , and that they are almost black to my sight -- except on the side of the sun going to bed , where they have a red edge , messieurs .
Parsing [sent. 3265 len. 37]: Also , I see that their long shadows are on the hollow ridge on the opposite side of the road , and are on the hill above it , and are like the shadows of giants .
Parsing [sent. 3266 len. 26]: Also , I see that they are covered with dust , and that the dust moves with them as they come , tramp , tramp !
Parsing [sent. 3267 len. 20]: But when they advance quite near to me , I recognise the tall man , and he recognises me .
Parsing [sent. 3268 len. 35]: Ah , but he would be well content to precipitate himself over the hill-side once again , as on the evening when he and I first encountered , close to the same spot ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3269 len. 29]: He described it as if he were there , and it was evident that he saw it vividly ; perhaps he had not seen much in his life .
Parsing [sent. 3270 len. 38]: `` I do not show the soldiers that I recognise the tall man ; he does not show the soldiers that he recognises me ; we do it , and we know it , with our eyes .

Parsing [sent. 3277 len. 17]: He imitated the action of a man 's being impelled forward by the butt-ends of muskets .

Parsing [sent. 3282 len. 21]: He opened his mouth as wide as he could , and shut it with a sounding snap of his teeth .
Parsing [sent. 3283 len. 23]: Observant of his unwillingness to mar the effect by opening it again , Defarge said , `` Go on , Jacques . ''
Parsing [sent. 3284 len. 69]: `` All the village , '' pursued the mender of roads , on tiptoe and in a low voice , `` withdraws ; all the village whispers by the fountain ; all the village sleeps ; all the village dreams of that unhappy one , within the locks and bars of the prison on the crag , and never to come out of it , except to perish .

Parsing [sent. 3397 len. 112]: If he needed a King and Queen to restore him , he was fortunate in having his remedy at hand ; for , soon the large-faced King and the fair-faced Queen came in their golden coach , attended by the shining Bull 's Eye of their Court , a glittering multitude of laughing ladies and fine lords ; and in jewels and silks and powder and splendour and elegantly spurning figures and handsomely disdainful faces of both sexes , the mender of roads bathed himself , so much to his temporary intoxication , that he cried Long live the King , Long live the Queen , Long live everybody and everything !

Parsing [sent. 3426 len. 73]: XVI Still Knitting Madame Defarge and monsieur her husband returned amicably to the bosom of Saint Antoine , while a speck in a blue cap toiled through the darkness , and through the dust , and down the weary miles of avenue by the wayside , slowly tending towards that point of the compass where the chateau of Monsieur the Marquis , now in his grave , listened to the whispering trees .
Parsing [sent. 3427 len. 71]: Such ample leisure had the stone faces , now , for listening to the trees and to the fountain , that the few village scarecrows who , in their quest for herbs to eat and fragments of dead stick to burn , strayed within sight of the great stone courtyard and terrace staircase , had it borne in upon their starved fancy that the expression of the faces was altered .
Parsing [sent. 3428 len. 80]: A rumour just lived in the village -- had a faint and bare existence there , as its people had -- that when the knife struck home , the faces changed , from faces of pride to faces of anger and pain ; also , that when that dangling figure was hauled up forty feet above the fountain , they changed again , and bore a cruel look of being avenged , which they would henceforth bear for ever .
Parsing [sent. 3429 len. 102]: In the stone face over the great window of the bed-chamber where the murder was done , two fine dints were pointed out in the sculptured nose , which everybody recognised , and which nobody had seen of old ; and on the scarce occasions when two or three ragged peasants emerged from the crowd to take a hurried peep at Monsieur the Marquis petrified , a skinny finger would not have pointed to it for a minute , before they all started away among the moss and leaves , like the more fortunate hares who could find a living there .
Parsing [sent. 3430 len. 56]: Chateau and hut , stone face and dangling figure , the red stain on the stone floor , and the pure water in the village well -- thousands of acres of land -- a whole province of France -- all France itself -- lay under the night sky , concentrated into a faint hair-breadth line .
Parsing [sent. 3431 len. 19]: So does a whole world , with all its greatnesses and littlenesses , lie in a twinkling star .
Parsing [sent. 3432 len. 52]: And as mere human knowledge can split a ray of light and analyse the manner of its composition , so , sublimer intelligences may read in the feeble shining of this earth of ours , every thought and act , every vice and virtue , of every responsible creature on it .
Parsing [sent. 3433 len. 29]: The Defarges , husband and wife , came lumbering under the starlight , in their public vehicle , to that gate of Paris whereunto their journey naturally tended .

Parsing [sent. 3462 len. 75]: They turned into the wine-shop , which was closed -LRB- for it was midnight -RRB- , and where Madame Defarge immediately took her post at her desk , counted the small moneys that had been taken during her absence , examined the stock , went through the entries in the book , made other entries of her own , checked the serving man in every possible way , and finally dismissed him to bed .

Parsing [sent. 3464 len. 48]: All this while , Defarge , with his pipe in his mouth , walked up and down , complacently admiring , but never interfering ; in which condition , indeed , as to the business and his domestic affairs , he walked up and down through life .

Parsing [sent. 3721 len. 23]: It gave her a strange and new sensation while his words were in her ears ; and she remembered it long afterwards .
Parsing [sent. 3722 len. 4]: `` See ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3723 len. 13]: said the Doctor of Beauvais , raising his hand towards the moon .
Parsing [sent. 3724 len. 18]: `` I have looked at her from my prison-window , when I could not bear her light .
Parsing [sent. 3725 len. 34]: I have looked at her when it has been such torture to me to think of her shining upon what I had lost , that I have beaten my head against my prison-walls .
Parsing [sent. 3726 len. 49]: I have looked at her , in a state so dun and lethargic , that I have thought of nothing but the number of horizontal lines I could draw across her at the full , and the number of perpendicular lines with which I could intersect them . ''
Parsing [sent. 3727 len. 36]: He added in his inward and pondering manner , as he looked at the moon , `` It was twenty either way , I remember , and the twentieth was difficult to squeeze in . ''
Parsing [sent. 3728 len. 36]: The strange thrill with which she heard him go back to that time , deepened as he dwelt upon it ; but , there was nothing to shock her in the manner of his reference .
Parsing [sent. 3729 len. 18]: He only seemed to contrast his present cheerfulness and felicity with the dire endurance that was over .
Parsing [sent. 3730 len. 22]: `` I have looked at her , speculating thousands of times upon the unborn child from whom I had been rent .
Parsing [sent. 3731 len. 5]: Whether it was alive .
Parsing [sent. 3732 len. 17]: Whether it had been born alive , or the poor mother 's shock had killed it .
Parsing [sent. 3733 len. 13]: Whether it was a son who would some day avenge his father .
Parsing [sent. 3734 len. 18]: -LRB- There was a time in my imprisonment , when my desire for vengeance was unbearable . -RRB-
Parsing [sent. 3735 len. 35]: Whether it was a son who would never know his father 's story ; who might even live to weigh the possibility of his father 's having disappeared of his own will and act .
Parsing [sent. 3736 len. 14]: Whether it was a daughter who would grow to be a woman . ''
Parsing [sent. 3737 len. 14]: She drew closer to him , and kissed his cheek and his hand .
Parsing [sent. 3738 len. 28]: `` I have pictured my daughter , to myself , as perfectly forgetful of me -- rather , altogether ignorant of me , and unconscious of me .
Parsing [sent. 3739 len. 14]: I have cast up the years of her age , year after year .
Parsing [sent. 3740 len. 15]: I have seen her married to a man who knew nothing of my fate .
Parsing [sent. 3741 len. 23]: I have altogether perished from the remembrance of the living , and in the next generation my place was a blank . ''
Parsing [sent. 3742 len. 4]: `` My father !
Parsing [sent. 3743 len. 28]: Even to hear that you had such thoughts of a daughter who never existed , strikes to my heart as if I had been that child . ''
Parsing [sent. 3744 len. 5]: `` You , Lucie ?
Parsing [sent. 3745 len. 31]: It is out of the Consolation and restoration you have brought to me , that these remembrances arise , and pass between us and the moon on this last night .
Parsing [sent. 3746 len. 9]: -- What did I say just now ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3747 len. 7]: `` She knew nothing of you .
Parsing [sent. 3748 len. 7]: She cared nothing for you . ''
Parsing [sent. 3749 len. 3]: `` So !
Parsing [sent. 3750 len. 67]: But on other moonlight nights , when the sadness and the silence have touched me in a different way -- have affected me with something as like a sorrowful sense of peace , as any emotion that had pain for its foundations could -- I have imagined her as coming to me in my cell , and leading me out into the freedom beyond the fortress .
Parsing [sent. 3751 len. 37]: I have seen her image in the moonlight often , as I now see you ; except that I never held her in my arms ; it stood between the little grated window and the door .
Parsing [sent. 3752 len. 16]: But , you understand that that was not the child I am speaking of ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3753 len. 16]: `` The figure was not ; the -- the -- image ; the fancy ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3754 len. 3]: `` No .
Parsing [sent. 3755 len. 5]: That was another thing .
Parsing [sent. 3756 len. 14]: It stood before my disturbed sense of sight , but it never moved .
Parsing [sent. 3757 len. 14]: The phantom that my mind pursued , was another and more real child .
Parsing [sent. 3758 len. 16]: Of her outward appearance I know no more than that she was like her mother .
Parsing [sent. 3759 len. 17]: The other had that likeness too -- as you have -- but was not the same .
Parsing [sent. 3760 len. 7]: Can you follow me , Lucie ?
Parsing [sent. 3761 len. 5]: Hardly , I think ?
Parsing [sent. 3762 len. 16]: I doubt you must have been a solitary prisoner to understand these perplexed distinctions . ''
Parsing [sent. 3763 len. 24]: His collected and calm manner could not prevent her blood from running cold , as he thus tried to anatomise his old condition .
Parsing [sent. 3764 len. 44]: `` In that more peaceful state , I have imagined her , in the moonlight , coming to me and taking me out to show me that the home of her married life was full of her loving remembrance of her lost father .
Parsing [sent. 3765 len. 14]: My picture was in her room , and I was in her prayers .
Parsing [sent. 3766 len. 18]: Her life was active , cheerful , useful ; but my poor history pervaded it all . ''
Parsing [sent. 3767 len. 55]: `` I was that child , my father , I was not half so good , but in my love that was I. '' `` And she showed me her children , '' said the Doctor of Beauvais , `` and they had heard of me , and had been taught to pity me .

Parsing [sent. 3769 len. 20]: She could never deliver me ; I imagined that she always brought me back after showing me such things .

Parsing [sent. 3780 len. 14]: They were only three at table , and Miss Pross made the third .

Parsing [sent. 3784 len. 37]: All things , however , were in their places ; all was quiet ; and he lay asleep , his white hair picturesque on the untroubled pillow , and his hands lying quiet on the coverlet .

Parsing [sent. 3786 len. 38]: Into his handsome face , the bitter waters of captivity had worn ; but , he covered up their tracks with a determination so strong , that he held the mastery of them even in his sleep .
Parsing [sent. 3787 len. 34]: A more remarkable face in its quiet , resolute , and guarded struggle with an unseen assailant , was not to be beheld in all the wide dominions of sleep , that night .

Parsing [sent. 3789 len. 18]: Then , she withdrew her hand , and kissed his lips once more , and went away .
Parsing [sent. 3790 len. 32]: So , the sunrise came , and the shadows of the leaves of the plane-tree moved upon his face , as softly as her lips had moved in praying for him .
Parsing [sent. 3791 len. 31]: XVIII Nine Days The marriage-day was shining brightly , and they were ready outside the closed door of the Doctor 's room , where he was speaking with Charles Darnay .
Parsing [sent. 3792 len. 58]: They were ready to go to church ; the beautiful bride , Mr. Lorry , and Miss Pross -- to whom the event , through a gradual process of reconcilement to the inevitable , would have been one of absolute bliss , but for the yet lingering consideration that her brother Solomon should have been the bridegroom .

Parsing [sent. 3797 len. 3]: `` Really ?

Parsing [sent. 3838 len. 38]: The corner being out of the way of the idle and curious , and the preparations having been very simple and few , the Doctor , Mr. Lorry , and Miss Pross , were left quite alone .
Parsing [sent. 3839 len. 44]: It was when they turned into the welcome shade of the cool old hall , that Mr. Lorry observed a great change to have come over the Doctor ; as if the golden arm uplifted there , had struck him a poisoned blow .
Parsing [sent. 3840 len. 23]: He had naturally repressed much , and some revulsion might have been expected in him when the occasion for repression was gone .

Parsing [sent. 3881 len. 43]: Two things at once impressed themselves on Mr. Lorry , as important above all others ; the first , that this must be kept secret from Lucie ; the second , that it must be kept secret from all who knew him .
Parsing [sent. 3882 len. 34]: In conjunction with Miss Pross , he took immediate steps towards the latter precaution , by giving out that the Doctor was not well , and required a few days of complete rest .
Parsing [sent. 3883 len. 56]: In aid of the kind deception to be practised on his daughter , Miss Pross was to write , describing his having been called away professionally , and referring to an imaginary letter of two or three hurried lines in his own hand , represented to have been addressed to her by the same post .
Parsing [sent. 3884 len. 23]: These measures , advisable to be taken in any case , Mr. Lorry took in the hope of his coming to himself .
Parsing [sent. 3885 len. 33]: If that should happen soon , he kept another course in reserve ; which was , to have a certain opinion that he thought the best , on the Doctor 's case .
Parsing [sent. 3886 len. 37]: In the hope of his recovery , and of resort to this third course being thereby rendered practicable , Mr. Lorry resolved to watch him attentively , with as little appearance as possible of doing so .
Parsing [sent. 3887 len. 30]: He therefore made arrangements to absent himself from Tellson 's for the first time in his life , and took his post by the window in the same room .
Parsing [sent. 3888 len. 27]: He was not long in discovering that it was worse than useless to speak to him , since , on being pressed , he became worried .
Parsing [sent. 3889 len. 36]: He abandoned that attempt on the first day , and resolved merely to keep himself always before him , as a silent protest against the delusion into which he had fallen , or was falling .
Parsing [sent. 3890 len. 38]: He remained , therefore , in his seat near the window , reading and writing , and expressing in as many pleasant and natural ways as he could think of , that it was a free place .
Parsing [sent. 3891 len. 51]: Doctor Manette took what was given him to eat and drink , and worked on , that first day , until it was too dark to see -- worked on , half an hour after Mr. Lorry could not have seen , for his life , to read or write .
Parsing [sent. 3892 len. 27]: When he put his tools aside as useless , until morning , Mr. Lorry rose and said to him : `` Will you go out ? ''

Parsing [sent. 3895 len. 4]: Why not ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3896 len. 16]: He made no effort to say why not , and said not a word more .

Parsing [sent. 3898 len. 18]: The sagacity of the man of business perceived an advantage here , and determined to hold it .
Parsing [sent. 3899 len. 21]: Miss Pross and he divided the night into two watches , and observed him at intervals from the adjoining room .

Parsing [sent. 3901 len. 19]: In the morning , he was up betimes , and went straight to his bench and to work .

Parsing [sent. 3903 len. 26]: He returned no reply , but it was evident that he heard what was said , and that he thought about it , however confusedly .
Parsing [sent. 3904 len. 50]: This encouraged Mr. Lorry to have Miss Pross in with her work , several times during the day ; at those times , they quietly spoke of Lucie , and of her father then present , precisely in the usual manner , and as if there were nothing amiss .
Parsing [sent. 3905 len. 50]: This was done without any demonstrative accompaniment , not long enough , or often enough to harass him ; and it lightened Mr. Lorry 's friendly heart to believe that he looked up oftener , and that he appeared to be stirred by some perception of inconsistencies surrounding him .

Parsing [sent. 3912 len. 30]: The time went very slowly on , and Mr. Lorry 's hope darkened , and his heart grew heavier again , and grew yet heavier and heavier every day .
Parsing [sent. 3913 len. 13]: The third day came and went , the fourth , the fifth .
Parsing [sent. 3914 len. 15]: Five days , six days , seven days , eight days , nine days .
Parsing [sent. 3915 len. 24]: With a hope ever darkening , and with a heart always growing heavier and heavier , Mr. Lorry passed through this anxious time .
Parsing [sent. 3916 len. 72]: The secret was well kept , and Lucie was unconscious and happy ; but he could not fail to observe that the shoemaker , whose hand had been a little out at first , was growing dreadfully skilful , and that he had never been so intent on his work , and that his hands had never been so nimble and expert , as in the dusk of the ninth evening .
Parsing [sent. 3917 len. 17]: XIX An Opinion Worn out by anxious watching , Mr. Lorry fell asleep at his post .
Parsing [sent. 3918 len. 33]: On the tenth morning of his suspense , he was startled by the shining of the sun into the room where a heavy slumber had overtaken him when it was dark night .
Parsing [sent. 3919 len. 25]: He rubbed his eyes and roused himself ; but he doubted , when he had done so , whether he was not still asleep .
Parsing [sent. 3920 len. 40]: For , going to the door of the Doctor 's room and looking in , he perceived that the shoemaker 's bench and tools were put aside again , and that the Doctor himself sat reading at the window .
Parsing [sent. 3921 len. 31]: He was in his usual morning dress , and his face -LRB- which Mr. Lorry could distinctly see -RRB- , though still very pale , was calmly studious and attentive .
Parsing [sent. 3922 len. 82]: Even when he had satisfied himself that he was awake , Mr. Lorry felt giddily uncertain for some few moments whether the late shoemaking might not be a disturbed dream of his own ; for , did not his eyes show him his friend before him in his accustomed clothing and aspect , and employed as usual ; and was there any sign within their range , that the change of which he had so strong an impression had actually happened ?
Parsing [sent. 3923 len. 17]: It was but the inquiry of his first confusion and astonishment , the answer being obvious .
Parsing [sent. 3924 len. 23]: If the impression were not produced by a real corresponding and sufficient cause , how came he , Jarvis Lorry , there ?
Parsing [sent. 3925 len. 38]: How came he to have fallen asleep , in his clothes , on the sofa in Doctor Manette 's consulting-room , and to be debating these points outside the Doctor 's bedroom door in the early morning ?
Parsing [sent. 3926 len. 13]: Within a few minutes , Miss Pross stood whispering at his side .
Parsing [sent. 3927 len. 31]: If he had had any particle of doubt left , her talk would of necessity have resolved it ; but he was by that time clear-headed , and had none .
Parsing [sent. 3928 len. 28]: He advised that they should let the time go by until the regular breakfast-hour , and should then meet the Doctor as if nothing unusual had occurred .
Parsing [sent. 3929 len. 39]: If he appeared to be in his customary state of mind , Mr. Lorry would then cautiously proceed to seek direction and guidance from the opinion he had been , in his anxiety , so anxious to obtain .
Parsing [sent. 3930 len. 17]: Miss Pross , submitting herself to his judgment , the scheme was worked out with care .
Parsing [sent. 3931 len. 30]: Having abundance of time for his usual methodical toilette , Mr. Lorry presented himself at the breakfast-hour in his usual white linen , and with his usual neat leg .
Parsing [sent. 3932 len. 14]: The Doctor was summoned in the usual way , and came to breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 3933 len. 41]: So far as it was possible to comprehend him without overstepping those delicate and gradual approaches which Mr. Lorry felt to be the only safe advance , he at first supposed that his daughter 's marriage had taken place yesterday .
Parsing [sent. 3934 len. 34]: An incidental allusion , purposely thrown out , to the day of the week , and the day of the month , set him thinking and counting , and evidently made him uneasy .
Parsing [sent. 3935 len. 24]: In all other respects , however , he was so composedly himself , that Mr. Lorry determined to have the aid he sought .
Parsing [sent. 3936 len. 7]: And that aid was his own .
Parsing [sent. 3937 len. 79]: Therefore , when the breakfast was done and cleared away , and he and the Doctor were left together , Mr. Lorry said , feelingly : `` My dear Manette , I am anxious to have your opinion , in confidence , on a very curious case in which I am deeply interested ; that is to say , it is very curious to me ; perhaps , to your better information it may be less so . ''
Parsing [sent. 3938 len. 22]: Glancing at his hands , which were discoloured by his late work , the Doctor looked troubled , and listened attentively .
Parsing [sent. 3939 len. 11]: He had already glanced at his hands more than once .
Parsing [sent. 3940 len. 30]: `` Doctor Manette , '' said Mr. Lorry , touching him affectionately on the arm , `` the case is the case of a particularly dear friend of mine .
Parsing [sent. 3941 len. 33]: Pray give your mind to it , and advise me well for his sake -- and above all , for his daughter 's -- his daughter 's , my dear Manette . ''

Parsing [sent. 3943 len. 4]: `` Yes ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3944 len. 9]: `` Be explicit , '' said the Doctor .

Parsing [sent. 3948 len. 3]: The mind .
Parsing [sent. 3949 len. 45]: It is the case of a shock under which the sufferer was borne down , one can not say for how long , because I believe he can not calculate the time himself , and there are no other means of getting at it .
Parsing [sent. 3950 len. 35]: It is the case of a shock from which the sufferer recovered , by a process that he can not trace himself -- as I once heard him publicly relate in a striking manner .
Parsing [sent. 3951 len. 55]: It is the case of a shock from which he has recovered , so completely , as to be a highly intelligent man , capable of close application of mind , and great exertion of body , and of constantly making fresh additions to his stock of knowledge , which was already very large .
Parsing [sent. 3952 len. 23]: But , unfortunately , there has been , '' he paused and took a deep breath -- `` a slight relapse . ''

Parsing [sent. 4171 len. 21]: XXI Echoing Footsteps A wonderful corner for echoes , it has been remarked , that corner where the Doctor lived .
Parsing [sent. 4172 len. 52]: Ever busily winding the golden thread which bound her husband , and her father , and herself , and her old directress and companion , in a life of quiet bliss , Lucie sat in the still house in the tranquilly resounding corner , listening to the echoing footsteps of years .
Parsing [sent. 4173 len. 33]: At first , there were times , though she was a perfectly happy young wife , when her work would slowly fall from her hands , and her eyes would be dimmed .
Parsing [sent. 4174 len. 28]: For , there was something coming in the echoes , something light , afar off , and scarcely audible yet , that stirred her heart too much .
Parsing [sent. 4175 len. 34]: Fluttering hopes and doubts -- hopes , of a love as yet unknown to her : doubts , of her remaining upon earth , to enjoy that new delight -- divided her breast .
Parsing [sent. 4176 len. 49]: Among the echoes then , there would arise the sound of footsteps at her own early grave ; and thoughts of the husband who would be left so desolate , and who would mourn for her so much , swelled to her eyes , and broke like waves .
Parsing [sent. 4177 len. 13]: That time passed , and her little Lucie lay on her bosom .
Parsing [sent. 4178 len. 23]: Then , among the advancing echoes , there was the tread of her tiny feet and the sound of her prattling words .
Parsing [sent. 4179 len. 21]: Let greater echoes resound as they would , the young mother at the cradle side could always hear those coming .
Parsing [sent. 4180 len. 58]: They came , and the shady house was sunny with a child 's laugh , and the Divine friend of children , to whom in her trouble she had confided hers , seemed to take her child in his arms , as He took the child of old , and made it a sacred joy to her .
Parsing [sent. 4181 len. 47]: Ever busily winding the golden thread that bound them all together , weaving the service of her happy influence through the tissue of all their lives , and making it predominate nowhere , Lucie heard in the echoes of years none but friendly and soothing sounds .
Parsing [sent. 4182 len. 18]: Her husband 's step was strong and prosperous among them ; her father 's firm and equal .
Parsing [sent. 4183 len. 33]: Lo , Miss Pross , in harness of string , awakening the echoes , as an unruly charger , whip-corrected , snorting and pawing the earth under the plane-tree in the garden !
Parsing [sent. 4184 len. 18]: Even when there were sounds of sorrow among the rest , they were not harsh nor cruel .
Parsing [sent. 4185 len. 67]: Even when golden hair , like her own , lay in a halo on a pillow round the worn face of a little boy , and he said , with a radiant smile , `` Dear papa and mamma , I am very sorry to leave you both , and to leave my pretty sister ; but I am called , and I must go ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4186 len. 29]: those were not tears all of agony that wetted his young mother 's cheek , as the spirit departed from her embrace that had been entrusted to it .
Parsing [sent. 4187 len. 7]: Suffer them and forbid them not .
Parsing [sent. 4188 len. 7]: They see my Father 's face .
Parsing [sent. 4189 len. 6]: O Father , blessed words !
Parsing [sent. 4190 len. 33]: Thus , the rustling of an Angel 's wings got blended with the other echoes , and they were not wholly of earth , but had in them that breath of Heaven .
Parsing [sent. 4191 len. 80]: Sighs of the winds that blew over a little garden-tomb were mingled with them also , and both were audible to Lucie , in a hushed murmur -- like the breathing of a summer sea asleep upon a sandy shore -- as the little Lucie , comically studious at the task of the morning , or dressing a doll at her mother 's footstool , chattered in the tongues of the Two Cities that were blended in her life .
Parsing [sent. 4192 len. 12]: The Echoes rarely answered to the actual tread of Sydney Carton .
Parsing [sent. 4193 len. 34]: Some half-dozen times a year , at most , he claimed his privilege of coming in uninvited , and would sit among them through the evening , as he had once done often .
Parsing [sent. 4194 len. 8]: He never came there heated with wine .
Parsing [sent. 4195 len. 25]: And one other thing regarding him was whispered in the echoes , which has been whispered by all true echoes for ages and ages .
Parsing [sent. 4196 len. 49]: No man ever really loved a woman , lost her , and knew her with a blameless though an unchanged mind , when she was a wife and a mother , but her children had a strange sympathy with him -- an instinctive delicacy of pity for him .
Parsing [sent. 4197 len. 26]: What fine hidden sensibilities are touched in such a case , no echoes tell ; but it is so , and it was so here .
Parsing [sent. 4198 len. 26]: Carton was the first stranger to whom little Lucie held out her chubby arms , and he kept his place with her as she grew .
Parsing [sent. 4199 len. 13]: The little boy had spoken of him , almost at the last .
Parsing [sent. 4200 len. 4]: `` Poor Carton !
Parsing [sent. 4201 len. 6]: Kiss him for me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4202 len. 34]: Mr. Stryver shouldered his way through the law , like some great engine forcing itself through turbid water , and dragged his useful friend in his wake , like a boat towed astern .
Parsing [sent. 4203 len. 27]: As the boat so favoured is usually in a rough plight , and mostly under water , so , Sydney had a swamped life of it .
Parsing [sent. 4204 len. 64]: But , easy and strong custom , unhappily so much easier and stronger in him than any stimulating sense of desert or disgrace , made it the life he was to lead ; and he no more thought of emerging from his state of lion 's jackal , than any real jackal may be supposed to think of rising to be a lion .
Parsing [sent. 4205 len. 31]: Stryver was rich ; had married a florid widow with property and three boys , who had nothing particularly shining about them but the straight hair of their dumpling heads .
Parsing [sent. 4206 len. 48]: These three young gentlemen , Mr. Stryver , exuding patronage of the most offensive quality from every pore , had walked before him like three sheep to the quiet corner in Soho , and had offered as pupils to Lucie 's husband : delicately saying `` Halloa !
Parsing [sent. 4207 len. 14]: here are three lumps of bread-and-cheese towards your matrimonial picnic , Darnay ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4208 len. 46]: The polite rejection of the three lumps of bread-and-cheese had quite bloated Mr. Stryver with indignation , which he afterwards turned to account in the training of the young gentlemen , by directing them to beware of the pride of Beggars , like that tutor-fellow .
Parsing [sent. 4209 len. 54]: He was also in the habit of declaiming to Mrs. Stryver , over his full-bodied wine , on the arts Mrs. Darnay had once put in practice to `` catch '' him , and on the diamond-cut-diamond arts in himself , madam , which had rendered him `` not to be caught . ''
Parsing [sent. 4210 len. 78]: Some of his King 's Bench familiars , who were occasionally parties to the full-bodied wine and the lie , excused him for the latter by saying that he had told it so often , that he believed it himself -- which is surely such an incorrigible aggravation of an originally bad offence , as to justify any such offender 's being carried off to some suitably retired spot , and there hanged out of the way .
Parsing [sent. 4211 len. 32]: These were among the echoes to which Lucie , sometimes pensive , sometimes amused and laughing , listened in the echoing corner , until her little daughter was six years old .
Parsing [sent. 4212 len. 41]: How near to her heart the echoes of her child 's tread came , and those of her own dear father 's , always active and self-possessed , and those of her dear husband 's , need not be told .
Parsing [sent. 4213 len. 35]: Nor , how the lightest echo of their united home , directed by herself with such a wise and elegant thrift that it was more abundant than any waste , was music to her .
Parsing [sent. 4214 len. 118]: Nor , how there were echoes all about her , sweet in her ears , of the many times her father had told her that he found her more devoted to him married -LRB- if that could be -RRB- than single , and of the many times her husband had said to her that no cares and duties seemed to divide her love for him or her help to him , and asked her `` What is the magic secret , my darling , of your being everything to all of us , as if there were only one of us , yet never seeming to be hurried , or to have too much to do ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4215 len. 24]: But , there were other echoes , from a distance , that rumbled menacingly in the corner all through this space of time .
Parsing [sent. 4216 len. 34]: And it was now , about little Lucie 's sixth birthday , that they began to have an awful sound , as of a great storm in France with a dreadful sea rising .
Parsing [sent. 4217 len. 39]: On a night in mid -- July , one thousand seven hundred and eighty-nine , Mr. Lorry came in late , from Tellson 's , and sat himself down by Lucie and her husband in the dark window .
Parsing [sent. 4218 len. 31]: It was a hot , wild night , and they were all three reminded of the old Sunday night when they had looked at the lightning from the same place .
Parsing [sent. 4219 len. 30]: `` I began to think , '' said Mr. Lorry , pushing his brown wig back , `` that I should have to pass the night at Tellson 's .
Parsing [sent. 4220 len. 26]: We have been so full of business all day , that we have not known what to do first , or which way to turn .
Parsing [sent. 4221 len. 19]: There is such an uneasiness in Paris , that we have actually a run of confidence upon us !
Parsing [sent. 4222 len. 19]: Our customers over there , seem not to be able to confide their property to us fast enough .
Parsing [sent. 4223 len. 16]: There is positively a mania among some of them for sending it to England . ''
Parsing [sent. 4224 len. 23]: `` That has a bad look , '' said Darnay -- `` A bad look , you say , my dear Darnay ?
Parsing [sent. 4225 len. 14]: Yes , but we do n't know what reason there is in it .
Parsing [sent. 4226 len. 5]: People are so unreasonable !
Parsing [sent. 4227 len. 27]: Some of us at Tellson 's are getting old , and we really ca n't be troubled out of the ordinary course without due occasion . ''
Parsing [sent. 4228 len. 19]: `` Still , '' said Darnay , `` you know how gloomy and threatening the sky is . ''
Parsing [sent. 4229 len. 45]: `` I know that , to be sure , '' assented Mr. Lorry , trying to persuade himself that his sweet temper was soured , and that he grumbled , `` but I am determined to be peevish after my long day 's botheration .
Parsing [sent. 4230 len. 5]: Where is Manette ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4231 len. 18]: `` Here he is , '' said the Doctor , entering the dark room at the moment .
Parsing [sent. 4232 len. 32]: `` I am quite glad you are at home ; for these hurries and forebodings by which I have been surrounded all day long , have made me nervous without reason .
Parsing [sent. 4233 len. 10]: You are not going out , I hope ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4234 len. 21]: `` No ; I am going to play backgammon with you , if you like , '' said the Doctor .
Parsing [sent. 4235 len. 16]: `` I do n't think I do like , if I may speak my mind .
Parsing [sent. 4236 len. 11]: I am not fit to be pitted against you to-night .
Parsing [sent. 4237 len. 8]: Is the teaboard still there , Lucie ?
Parsing [sent. 4238 len. 6]: I ca n't see . ''
Parsing [sent. 4239 len. 12]: `` Of course , it has been kept for you . ''
Parsing [sent. 4240 len. 7]: `` Thank ye , my dear .
Parsing [sent. 4241 len. 9]: The precious child is safe in bed ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4242 len. 6]: `` And sleeping soundly . ''
Parsing [sent. 4243 len. 10]: `` That 's right ; all safe and well !
Parsing [sent. 4244 len. 38]: I do n't know why anything should be otherwise than safe and well here , thank God ; but I have been so put out all day , and I am not as young as I was !
Parsing [sent. 4245 len. 6]: My tea , my dear !
Parsing [sent. 4246 len. 3]: Thank ye .
Parsing [sent. 4247 len. 29]: Now , come and take your place in the circle , and let us sit quiet , and hear the echoes about which you have your theory . ''
Parsing [sent. 4248 len. 11]: `` Not a theory ; it was a fancy . ''
Parsing [sent. 4249 len. 19]: `` A fancy , then , my wise pet , '' said Mr. Lorry , patting her hand .
Parsing [sent. 4250 len. 15]: `` They are very numerous and very loud , though , are they not ?
Parsing [sent. 4251 len. 5]: Only hear them ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4252 len. 47]: Headlong , mad , and dangerous footsteps to force their way into anybody 's life , footsteps not easily made clean again if once stained red , the footsteps raging in Saint Antoine afar off , as the little circle sat in the dark London window .
Parsing [sent. 4253 len. 39]: Saint Antoine had been , that morning , a vast dusky mass of scarecrows heaving to and fro , with frequent gleams of light above the billowy heads , where steel blades and bayonets shone in the sun .
Parsing [sent. 4254 len. 59]: A tremendous roar arose from the throat of Saint Antoine , and a forest of naked arms struggled in the air like shrivelled branches of trees in a winter wind : all the fingers convulsively clutching at every weapon or semblance of a weapon that was thrown up from the depths below , no matter how far off .
Parsing [sent. 4255 len. 88]: Who gave them out , whence they last came , where they began , through what agency they crookedly quivered and jerked , scores at a time , over the heads of the crowd , like a kind of lightning , no eye in the throng could have told ; but , muskets were being distributed -- so were cartridges , powder , and ball , bars of iron and wood , knives , axes , pikes , every weapon that distracted ingenuity could discover or devise .
Parsing [sent. 4256 len. 26]: People who could lay hold of nothing else , set themselves with bleeding hands to force stones and bricks out of their places in walls .
Parsing [sent. 4257 len. 16]: Every pulse and heart in Saint Antoine was on high-fever strain and at high-fever heat .
Parsing [sent. 4258 len. 22]: Every living creature there held life as of no account , and was demented with a passionate readiness to sacrifice it .
Parsing [sent. 4259 len. 81]: As a whirlpool of boiling waters has a centre point , so , all this raging circled round Defarge 's wine-shop , and every human drop in the caldron had a tendency to be sucked towards the vortex where Defarge himself , already begrimed with gunpowder and sweat , issued orders , issued arms , thrust this man back , dragged this man forward , disarmed one to arm another , laboured and strove in the thickest of the uproar .
Parsing [sent. 4260 len. 40]: `` Keep near to me , Jacques Three , '' cried Defarge ; `` and do you , Jacques One and Two , separate and put yourselves at the head of as many of these patriots as you can .
Parsing [sent. 4261 len. 6]: Where is my wife ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4262 len. 5]: `` Eh , well !
Parsing [sent. 4263 len. 6]: Here you see me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4264 len. 12]: said madame , composed as ever , but not knitting to-day .
Parsing [sent. 4265 len. 31]: Madame 's resolute right hand was occupied with an axe , in place of the usual softer implements , and in her girdle were a pistol and a cruel knife .
Parsing [sent. 4266 len. 10]: `` Where do you go , my wife ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4267 len. 14]: `` I go , '' said madame , `` with you at present .
Parsing [sent. 4268 len. 13]: You shall see me at the head of women , by-and-bye . ''
Parsing [sent. 4269 len. 6]: `` Come , then ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4270 len. 8]: cried Defarge , in a resounding voice .
Parsing [sent. 4271 len. 9]: `` Patriots and friends , we are ready !
Parsing [sent. 4272 len. 4]: The Bastille ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4273 len. 41]: With a roar that sounded as if all the breath in France had been shaped into the detested word , the living sea rose , wave on wave , depth on depth , and overflowed the city to that point .
Parsing [sent. 4274 len. 20]: Alarm-bells ringing , drums beating , the sea raging and thundering on its new beach , the attack began .
Parsing [sent. 4275 len. 22]: Deep ditches , double drawbridge , massive stone walls , eight great towers , cannon , muskets , fire and smoke .
Parsing [sent. 4276 len. 49]: Through the fire and through the smoke -- in the fire and in the smoke , for the sea cast him up against a cannon , and on the instant he became a cannonier -- Defarge of the wine-shop worked like a manful soldier , Two fierce hours .
Parsing [sent. 4277 len. 22]: Deep ditch , single drawbridge , massive stone walls , eight great towers , cannon , muskets , fire and smoke .
Parsing [sent. 4278 len. 4]: One drawbridge down !
Parsing [sent. 4279 len. 8]: `` Work , comrades all , work !
Parsing [sent. 4280 len. 40]: Work , Jacques One , Jacques Two , Jacques One Thousand , Jacques Two Thousand , Jacques Five-and -- Twenty Thousand ; in the name of all the Angels or the Devils -- which you prefer -- work ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4281 len. 17]: Thus Defarge of the wine-shop , still at his gun , which had long grown hot .
Parsing [sent. 4282 len. 7]: `` To me , women ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4283 len. 5]: cried madame his wife .
Parsing [sent. 4284 len. 3]: `` What !
Parsing [sent. 4285 len. 15]: We can kill as well as the men when the place is taken ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4286 len. 24]: And to her , with a shrill thirsty cry , trooping women variously armed , but all armed alike in hunger and revenge .
Parsing [sent. 4287 len. 30]: Cannon , muskets , fire and smoke ; but , still the deep ditch , the single drawbridge , the massive stone walls , and the eight great towers .
Parsing [sent. 4288 len. 13]: Slight displacements of the raging sea , made by the falling wounded .
Parsing [sent. 4289 len. 90]: Flashing weapons , blazing torches , smoking waggonloads of wet straw , hard work at neighbouring barricades in all directions , shrieks , volleys , execrations , bravery without stint , boom smash and rattle , and the furious sounding of the living sea ; but , still the deep ditch , and the single drawbridge , and the massive stone walls , and the eight great towers , and still Defarge of the wine-shop at his gun , grown doubly hot by the service of Four fierce hours .
Parsing [sent. 4290 len. 60]: A white flag from within the fortress , and a parley -- this dimly perceptible through the raging storm , nothing audible in it -- suddenly the sea rose immeasurably wider and higher , and swept Defarge of the wine-shop over the lowered drawbridge , past the massive stone outer walls , in among the eight great towers surrendered !
Parsing [sent. 4291 len. 51]: So resistless was the force of the ocean bearing him on , that even to draw his breath or turn his head was as impracticable as if he had been struggling in the surf at the South Sea , until he was landed in the outer courtyard of the Bastille .
Parsing [sent. 4292 len. 18]: There , against an angle of a wall , he made a struggle to look about him .
Parsing [sent. 4293 len. 33]: Jacques Three was nearly at his side ; Madame Defarge , still heading some of her women , was visible in the inner distance , and her knife was in her hand .
Parsing [sent. 4294 len. 18]: Everywhere was tumult , exultation , deafening and maniacal bewilderment , astounding noise , yet furious dumb-show .
