Parsing [sent. 4296 len. 5]: `` The Records ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4297 len. 6]: `` The secret cells ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4298 len. 7]: `` The instruments of torture ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4299 len. 5]: `` The Prisoners ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4300 len. 15]: Of all these cries , and ten thousand incoherences , `` The Prisoners ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4301 len. 30]: was the cry most taken up by the sea that rushed in , as if there were an eternity of people , as well as of time and space .
Parsing [sent. 4302 len. 73]: When the foremost billows rolled past , bearing the prison officers with them , and threatening them all with instant death if any secret nook remained undisclosed , Defarge laid his strong hand on the breast of one of these men -- a man with a grey head , who had a lighted torch in his hand -- separated him from the rest , and got him between himself and the wall .
Parsing [sent. 4303 len. 8]: `` Show me the North Tower ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4304 len. 3]: said Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 4305 len. 4]: `` Quick ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4306 len. 18]: `` I will faithfully , '' replied the man , `` if you will come with me .
Parsing [sent. 4307 len. 8]: But there is no one there . ''
Parsing [sent. 4308 len. 15]: `` What is the meaning of One Hundred and Five , North Tower ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4309 len. 3]: asked Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 4310 len. 4]: `` Quick ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4311 len. 7]: `` The meaning , monsieur ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4312 len. 13]: `` Does it mean a captive , or a place of captivity ?
Parsing [sent. 4313 len. 12]: Or do you mean that I shall strike you dead ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4314 len. 5]: `` Kill him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4315 len. 10]: croaked Jacques Three , who had come close up .
Parsing [sent. 4316 len. 9]: `` Monsieur , it is a cell . ''
Parsing [sent. 4317 len. 6]: `` Show it me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4318 len. 8]: `` Pass this way , then . ''
Parsing [sent. 4319 len. 40]: Jacques Three , with his usual craving on him , and evidently disappointed by the dialogue taking a turn that did not seem to promise bloodshed , held by Defarge 's arm as he held by the turnkey 's .
Parsing [sent. 4320 len. 58]: Their three heads had been close together during this brief discourse , and it had been as much as they could do to hear one another , even then : so tremendous was the noise of the living ocean , in its irruption into the Fortress , and its inundation of the courts and passages and staircases .
Parsing [sent. 4321 len. 36]: All around outside , too , it beat the walls with a deep , hoarse roar , from which , occasionally , some partial shouts of tumult broke and leaped into the air like spray .
Parsing [sent. 4322 len. 68]: Through gloomy vaults where the light of day had never shone , past hideous doors of dark dens and cages , down cavernous flights of steps , and again up steep rugged ascents of stone and brick , more like dry waterfalls than staircases , Defarge , the turnkey , and Jacques Three , linked hand and arm , went with all the speed they could make .
Parsing [sent. 4323 len. 37]: Here and there , especially at first , the inundation started on them and swept by ; but when they had done descending , and were winding and climbing up a tower , they were alone .
Parsing [sent. 4324 len. 49]: Hemmed in here by the massive thickness of walls and arches , the storm within the fortress and without was only audible to them in a dull , subdued way , as if the noise out of which they had come had almost destroyed their sense of hearing .
Parsing [sent. 4325 len. 45]: The turnkey stopped at a low door , put a key in a clashing lock , swung the door slowly open , and said , as they all bent their heads and passed in : `` One hundred and five , North Tower ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4326 len. 36]: There was a small , heavily-grated , unglazed window high in the wall , with a stone screen before it , so that the sky could be only seen by stooping low and looking up .
Parsing [sent. 4327 len. 15]: There was a small chimney , heavily barred across , a few feet within .
Parsing [sent. 4328 len. 12]: There was a heap of old feathery wood-ashes on the hearth .
Parsing [sent. 4329 len. 13]: There was a stool , and table , and a straw bed .
Parsing [sent. 4330 len. 17]: There were the four blackened walls , and a rusted iron ring in one of them .
Parsing [sent. 4331 len. 22]: `` Pass that torch slowly along these walls , that I may see them , '' said Defarge to the turnkey .
Parsing [sent. 4332 len. 14]: The man obeyed , and Defarge followed the light closely with his eyes .
Parsing [sent. 4333 len. 3]: `` Stop !
Parsing [sent. 4334 len. 7]: -- Look here , Jacques ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4335 len. 5]: `` A. M. ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4336 len. 9]: croaked Jacques Three , as he read greedily .

Parsing [sent. 4339 len. 16]: And it was he , without doubt , who scratched a calendar on this stone .

Parsing [sent. 4341 len. 3]: A crowbar ?
Parsing [sent. 4342 len. 5]: Give it me ! ''

Parsing [sent. 4345 len. 7]: `` Hold the light higher ! ''

Parsing [sent. 4352 len. 55]: In a few minutes , some mortar and dust came dropping down , which he averted his face to avoid ; and in it , and in the old wood-ashes , and in a crevice in the chimney into which his weapon had slipped or wrought itself , he groped with a cautious touch .
Parsing [sent. 4353 len. 15]: `` Nothing in the wood , and nothing in the straw , Jacques ? ''

Parsing [sent. 4359 len. 45]: Stooping again to come out at the low-arched door , they left it burning , and retraced their way to the courtyard ; seeming to recover their sense of hearing as they came down , until they were in the raging flood once more .
Parsing [sent. 4360 len. 13]: They found it surging and tossing , in quest of Defarge himself .
Parsing [sent. 4361 len. 26]: Saint Antoine was clamorous to have its wine-shop keeper foremost in the guard upon the governor who had defended the Bastille and shot the people .
Parsing [sent. 4362 len. 16]: Otherwise , the governor would not be marched to the Hotel de Ville for judgment .
Parsing [sent. 4363 len. 27]: Otherwise , the governor would escape , and the people 's blood -LRB- suddenly of some value , after many years of worthlessness -RRB- be unavenged .
Parsing [sent. 4364 len. 40]: In the howling universe of passion and contention that seemed to encompass this grim old officer conspicuous in his grey coat and red decoration , there was but one quite steady figure , and that was a woman 's .
Parsing [sent. 4365 len. 9]: `` See , there is my husband ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4366 len. 7]: she cried , pointing him out .
Parsing [sent. 4367 len. 5]: `` See Defarge ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4368 len. 112]: She stood immovable close to the grim old officer , and remained immovable close to him ; remained immovable close to him through the streets , as Defarge and the rest bore him along ; remained immovable close to him when he was got near his destination , and began to be struck at from behind ; remained immovable close to him when the long-gathering rain of stabs and blows fell heavy ; was so close to him when he dropped dead under it , that , suddenly animated , she put her foot upon his neck , and with her cruel knife -- long ready -- hewed off his head .
Parsing [sent. 4369 len. 29]: The hour was come , when Saint Antoine was to execute his horrible idea of hoisting up men for lamps to show what he could be and do .
Parsing [sent. 4370 len. 60]: Saint Antoine 's blood was up , and the blood of tyranny and domination by the iron hand was down -- down on the steps of the Hotel de Ville where the governor 's body lay -- down on the sole of the shoe of Madame Defarge where she had trodden on the body to steady it for mutilation .
Parsing [sent. 4371 len. 7]: `` Lower the lamp yonder ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4372 len. 28]: cried Saint Antoine , after glaring round for a new means of death ; `` here is one of his soldiers to be left on guard ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4373 len. 12]: The swinging sentinel was posted , and the sea rushed on .
Parsing [sent. 4374 len. 29]: The sea of black and threatening waters , and of destructive upheaving of wave against wave , whose depths were yet unfathomed and whose forces were yet unknown .
Parsing [sent. 4375 len. 32]: The remorseless sea of turbulently swaying shapes , voices of vengeance , and faces hardened in the furnaces of suffering until the touch of pity could make no mark on them .
Parsing [sent. 4376 len. 50]: But , in the ocean of faces where every fierce and furious expression was in vivid life , there were two groups of faces -- each seven in number -- so fixedly contrasting with the rest , that never did sea roll which bore more memorable wrecks with it .
Parsing [sent. 4377 len. 50]: Seven faces of prisoners , suddenly released by the storm that had burst their tomb , were carried high overhead : all scared , all lost , all wondering and amazed , as if the Last Day were come , and those who rejoiced around them were lost spirits .
Parsing [sent. 4378 len. 24]: Other seven faces there were , carried higher , seven dead faces , whose drooping eyelids and half-seen eyes awaited the Last Day .
Parsing [sent. 4379 len. 51]: Impassive faces , yet with a suspended -- not an abolished -- expression on them ; faces , rather , in a fearful pause , as having yet to raise the dropped lids of the eyes , and bear witness with the bloodless lips , `` THOU DIDST IT ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4380 len. 72]: Seven prisoners released , seven gory heads on pikes , the keys of the accursed fortress of the eight strong towers , some discovered letters and other memorials of prisoners of old time , long dead of broken hearts , -- such , and such -- like , the loudly echoing footsteps of Saint Antoine escort through the Paris streets in mid -- July , one thousand seven hundred and eighty-nine .
Parsing [sent. 4381 len. 20]: Now , Heaven defeat the fancy of Lucie Darnay , and keep these feet far out of her life !
Parsing [sent. 4382 len. 39]: For , they are headlong , mad , and dangerous ; and in the years so long after the breaking of the cask at Defarge 's wine-shop door , they are not easily purified when once stained red .

Parsing [sent. 4435 len. 43]: The men were terrible , in the bloody-minded anger with which they looked from windows , caught up what arms they had , and came pouring down into the streets ; but , the women were a sight to chill the boldest .
Parsing [sent. 4436 len. 52]: From such household occupations as their bare poverty yielded , from their children , from their aged and their sick crouching on the bare ground famished and naked , they ran out with streaming hair , urging one another , and themselves , to madness with the wildest cries and actions .

Parsing [sent. 4445 len. 5]: O Heaven our suffering !

Parsing [sent. 4448 len. 48]: With these cries , numbers of the women , lashed into blind frenzy , whirled about , striking and tearing at their own friends until they dropped into a passionate swoon , and were only saved by the men belonging to them from being trampled under foot .

Parsing [sent. 4471 len. 194]: Down , and up , and head foremost on the steps of the building ; now , on his knees ; now , on his feet ; now , on his back ; dragged , and struck at , and stifled by the bunches of grass and straw that were thrust into his face by hundreds of hands ; torn , bruised , panting , bleeding , yet always entreating and beseeching for mercy ; now full of vehement agony of action , with a small clear space about him as the people drew one another back that they might see ; now , a log of dead wood drawn through a forest of legs ; he was hauled to the nearest street corner where one of the fatal lamps swung , and there Madame Defarge let him go -- as a cat might have done to a mouse -- and silently and composedly looked at him while they made ready , and while he besought her : the women passionately screeching at him all the time , and the men sternly calling out to have him killed with grass in his mouth .
Parsing [sent. 4472 len. 71]: Once , he went aloft , and the rope broke , and they caught him shrieking ; twice , he went aloft , and the rope broke , and they caught him shrieking ; then , the rope was merciful , and held him , and his head was soon upon a pike , with grass enough in the mouth for all Saint Antoine to dance at the sight of .

Parsing [sent. 4476 len. 54]: Then , the miserable bakers ' shops were beset by long files of them , patiently waiting to buy bad bread ; and while they waited with stomachs faint and empty , they beguiled the time by embracing one another on the triumphs of the day , and achieving them again in gossip .

Parsing [sent. 4488 len. 55]: XXIII Fire Rises There was a change on the village where the fountain fell , and where the mender of roads went forth daily to hammer out of the stones on the highway such morsels of bread as might serve for patches to hold his poor ignorant soul and his poor reduced body together .

Parsing [sent. 4502 len. 112]: For , in these times , as the mender of roads worked , solitary , in the dust , not often troubling himself to reflect that dust he was and to dust he must return , being for the most part too much occupied in thinking how little he had for supper and how much more he would eat if he had it -- in these times , as he raised his eyes from his lonely labour , and viewed the prospect , he would see some rough figure approaching on foot , the like of which was once a rarity in those parts , but was now a frequent presence .
Parsing [sent. 4503 len. 83]: As it advanced , the mender of roads would discern without surprise , that it was a shaggy-haired man , of almost barbarian aspect , tall , in wooden shoes that were clumsy even to the eyes of a mender of roads , grim , rough , swart , steeped in the mud and dust of many highways , dank with the marshy moisture of many low grounds , sprinkled with the thorns and leaves and moss of many byways through woods .
Parsing [sent. 4504 len. 43]: Such a man came upon him , like a ghost , at noon in the July weather , as he sat on his heap of stones under a bank , taking such shelter as he could get from a shower of hail .
Parsing [sent. 4505 len. 26]: The man looked at him , looked at the village in the hollow , at the mill , and at the prison on the crag .

Parsing [sent. 4507 len. 7]: `` All well , Jacques . ''

Parsing [sent. 4544 len. 62]: As the road-mender plied his dusty labour , and the hail-clouds , rolling away , revealed bright bars and streaks of sky which were responded to by silver gleams upon the landscape , the little man -LRB- who wore a red cap now , in place of his blue one -RRB- seemed fascinated by the figure on the heap of stones .
Parsing [sent. 4545 len. 28]: His eyes were so often turned towards it , that he used his tools mechanically , and , one would have said , to very poor account .
Parsing [sent. 4546 len. 58]: The bronze face , the shaggy black hair and beard , the coarse woollen red cap , the rough medley dress of home-spun stuff and hairy skins of beasts , the powerful frame attenuated by spare living , and the sullen and desperate compression of the lips in sleep , inspired the mender of roads with awe .
Parsing [sent. 4547 len. 55]: The traveller had travelled far , and his feet were footsore , and his ankles chafed and bleeding ; his great shoes , stuffed with leaves and grass , had been heavy to drag over the many long leagues , and his clothes were chafed into holes , as he himself was into sores .

Parsing [sent. 4577 len. 18]: The tocsin rang impatiently , but other help -LRB- if that were any -RRB- there was none .
Parsing [sent. 4578 len. 31]: The mender of roads , and two hundred and fifty particular friends , stood with folded arms at the fountain , looking at the pillar of fire in the sky .
Parsing [sent. 4579 len. 18]: `` It must be forty feet high , '' said they , grimly ; and never moved .
Parsing [sent. 4580 len. 33]: The rider from the chateau , and the horse in a foam , clattered away through the village , and galloped up the stony steep , to the prison on the crag .
Parsing [sent. 4581 len. 23]: At the gate , a group of officers were looking at the fire ; removed from them , a group of soldiers .
Parsing [sent. 4582 len. 7]: `` Help , gentlemen -- officers !
Parsing [sent. 4583 len. 18]: The chateau is on fire ; valuable objects may be saved from the flames by timely aid !
Parsing [sent. 4584 len. 5]: Help , help ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4585 len. 32]: The officers looked towards the soldiers who looked at the fire ; gave no orders ; and answered , with shrugs and biting of lips , `` It must burn . ''
Parsing [sent. 4586 len. 18]: As the rider rattled down the hill again and through the street , the village was illuminating .
Parsing [sent. 4587 len. 45]: The mender of roads , and the two hundred and fifty particular friends , inspired as one man and woman by the idea of lighting up , had darted into their houses , and were putting candles in every dull little pane of glass .
Parsing [sent. 4588 len. 62]: The general scarcity of everything , occasioned candles to be borrowed in a rather peremptory manner of Monsieur Gabelle ; and in a moment of reluctance and hesitation on that functionary 's part , the mender of roads , once so submissive to authority , had remarked that carriages were good to make bonfires with , and that post-horses would roast .
Parsing [sent. 4589 len. 11]: The chateau was left to itself to flame and burn .
Parsing [sent. 4590 len. 28]: In the roaring and raging of the conflagration , a red-hot wind , driving straight from the infernal regions , seemed to be blowing the edifice away .
Parsing [sent. 4591 len. 20]: With the rising and falling of the blaze , the stone faces showed as if they were in torment .
Parsing [sent. 4592 len. 50]: When great masses of stone and timber fell , the face with the two dints in the nose became obscured : anon struggled out of the smoke again , as if it were the face of the cruel Marquis , burning at the stake and contending with the fire .
Parsing [sent. 4593 len. 42]: The chateau burned ; the nearest trees , laid hold of by the fire , scorched and shrivelled ; trees at a distance , fired by the four fierce figures , begirt the blazing edifice with a new forest of smoke .
Parsing [sent. 4594 len. 41]: Molten lead and iron boiled in the marble basin of the fountain ; the water ran dry ; the extinguisher tops of the towers vanished like ice before the heat , and trickled down into four rugged wells of flame .
Parsing [sent. 4595 len. 57]: Great rents and splits branched out in the solid walls , like crystallisation ; stupefied birds wheeled about and dropped into the furnace ; four fierce figures trudged away , East , West , North , and South , along the night-enshrouded roads , guided by the beacon they had lighted , towards their next destination .
Parsing [sent. 4596 len. 21]: The illuminated village had seized hold of the tocsin , and , abolishing the lawful ringer , rang for joy .
Parsing [sent. 4597 len. 82]: Not only that ; but the village , light-headed with famine , fire , and bell-ringing , and bethinking itself that Monsieur Gabelle had to do with the collection of rent and taxes -- though it was but a small instalment of taxes , and no rent at all , that Gabelle had got in those latter days -- became impatient for an interview with him , and , surrounding his house , summoned him to come forth for personal conference .
Parsing [sent. 4598 len. 18]: Whereupon , Monsieur Gabelle did heavily bar his door , and retire to hold counsel with himself .
Parsing [sent. 4599 len. 60]: The result of that conference was , that Gabelle again withdrew himself to his housetop behind his stack of chimneys ; this time resolved , if his door were broken in -LRB- he was a small Southern man of retaliative temperament -RRB- , to pitch himself head foremost over the parapet , and crush a man or two below .
Parsing [sent. 4600 len. 65]: Probably , Monsieur Gabelle passed a long night up there , with the distant chateau for fire and candle , and the beating at his door , combined with the joy-ringing , for music ; not to mention his having an ill-omened lamp slung across the road before his posting-house gate , which the village showed a lively inclination to displace in his favour .
Parsing [sent. 4601 len. 33]: A trying suspense , to be passing a whole summer night on the brink of the black ocean , ready to take that plunge into it upon which Monsieur Gabelle had resolved !
Parsing [sent. 4602 len. 37]: But , the friendly dawn appearing at last , and the rush-candles of the village guttering out , the people happily dispersed , and Monsieur Gabelle came down bringing his life with him for that while .
Parsing [sent. 4603 len. 82]: Within a hundred miles , and in the light of other fires , there were other functionaries less fortunate , that night and other nights , whom the rising sun found hanging across once-peaceful streets , where they had been born and bred ; also , there were other villagers and townspeople less fortunate than the mender of roads and his fellows , upon whom the functionaries and soldiery turned with success , and whom they strung up in their turn .
Parsing [sent. 4604 len. 30]: But , the fierce figures were steadily wending East , West , North , and South , be that as it would ; and whosoever hung , fire burned .
Parsing [sent. 4605 len. 29]: The altitude of the gallows that would turn to water and quench it , no functionary , by any stretch of mathematics , was able to calculate successfully .
Parsing [sent. 4606 len. 63]: XXIV Drawn to the Loadstone Rock In such risings of fire and risings of sea -- the firm earth shaken by the rushes of an angry ocean which had now no ebb , but was always on the flow , higher and higher , to the terror and wonder of the beholders on the shore -- three years of tempest were consumed .
Parsing [sent. 4607 len. 24]: Three more birthdays of little Lucie had been woven by the golden thread into the peaceful tissue of the life of her home .
Parsing [sent. 4608 len. 30]: Many a night and many a day had its inmates listened to the echoes in the corner , with hearts that failed them when they heard the thronging feet .
Parsing [sent. 4609 len. 41]: For , the footsteps had become to their minds as the footsteps of a people , tumultuous under a red flag and with their country declared in danger , changed into wild beasts , by terrible enchantment long persisted in .
Parsing [sent. 4610 len. 44]: Monseigneur , as a class , had dissociated himself from the phenomenon of his not being appreciated : of his being so little wanted in France , as to incur considerable danger of receiving his dismissal from it , and this life together .
Parsing [sent. 4611 len. 80]: Like the fabled rustic who raised the Devil with infinite pains , and was so terrified at the sight of him that he could ask the Enemy no question , but immediately fled ; so , Monseigneur , after boldly reading the Lord 's Prayer backwards for a great number of years , and performing many other potent spells for compelling the Evil One , no sooner beheld him in his terrors than he took to his noble heels .
Parsing [sent. 4612 len. 25]: The shining Bull 's Eye of the Court was gone , or it would have been the mark for a hurricane of national bullets .
Parsing [sent. 4613 len. 44]: It had never been a good eye to see with -- had long had the mote in it of Lucifer 's pride , Sardana -- palus 's luxury , and a mole 's blindness -- but it had dropped out and was gone .
Parsing [sent. 4614 len. 26]: The Court , from that exclusive inner circle to its outermost rotten ring of intrigue , corruption , and dissimulation , was all gone together .
Parsing [sent. 4615 len. 22]: Royalty was gone ; had been besieged in its Palace and `` suspended , '' when the last tidings came over .
Parsing [sent. 4616 len. 25]: The August of the year one thousand seven hundred and ninety-two was come , and Monseigneur was by this time scattered far and wide .
Parsing [sent. 4617 len. 20]: As was natural , the head-quarters and great gathering-place of Monseigneur , in London , was Tellson 's Bank .
Parsing [sent. 4618 len. 28]: Spirits are supposed to haunt the places where their bodies most resorted , and Monseigneur without a guinea haunted the spot where his guineas used to be .
Parsing [sent. 4619 len. 22]: Moreover , it was the spot to which such French intelligence as was most to be relied upon , came quickest .
Parsing [sent. 4620 len. 24]: Again : Tellson 's was a munificent house , and extended great liberality to old customers who had fallen from their high estate .
Parsing [sent. 4621 len. 39]: Again : those nobles who had seen the coming storm in time , and anticipating plunder or confiscation , had made provident remittances to Tellson 's , were always to be heard of there by their needy brethren .
Parsing [sent. 4622 len. 27]: To which it must be added that every new-comer from France reported himself and his tidings at Tellson 's , almost as a matter of course .
Parsing [sent. 4623 len. 77]: For such variety of reasons , Tellson 's was at that time , as to French intelligence , a kind of High Exchange ; and this was so well known to the public , and the inquiries made there were in consequence so numerous , that Tellson 's sometimes wrote the latest news out in a line or so and posted it in the Bank windows , for all who ran through Temple Bar to read .
Parsing [sent. 4624 len. 30]: On a steaming , misty afternoon , Mr. Lorry sat at his desk , and Charles Darnay stood leaning on it , talking with him in a low voice .
Parsing [sent. 4625 len. 25]: The penitential den once set apart for interviews with the House , was now the news -- Exchange , and was filled to overflowing .
Parsing [sent. 4626 len. 14]: It was within half an hour or so of the time of closing .
Parsing [sent. 4627 len. 34]: `` But , although you are the youngest man that ever lived , '' said Charles Darnay , rather hesitating , `` I must still suggest to you -- '' `` I understand .
Parsing [sent. 4628 len. 7]: That I am too old ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4629 len. 4]: said Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 4630 len. 29]: `` Unsettled weather , a long journey , uncertain means of travelling , a disorganised country , a city that may not be even safe for you . ''
Parsing [sent. 4631 len. 31]: `` My dear Charles , '' said Mr. Lorry , with cheerful confidence , `` you touch some of the reasons for my going : not for my staying away .
Parsing [sent. 4632 len. 33]: It is safe enough for me ; nobody will care to interfere with an old fellow of hard upon fourscore when there are so many people there much better worth interfering with .
Parsing [sent. 4633 len. 50]: As to its being a disorganised city , if it were not a disorganised city there would be no occasion to send somebody from our House here to our House there , who knows the city and the business , of old , and is in Tellson 's confidence .
Parsing [sent. 4634 len. 45]: As to the uncertain travelling , the long journey , and the winter weather , if I were not prepared to submit myself to a few inconveniences for the sake of Tellson 's , after all these years , who ought to be ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4635 len. 22]: `` I wish I were going myself , '' said Charles Darnay , somewhat restlessly , and like one thinking aloud .
Parsing [sent. 4636 len. 3]: `` Indeed !
Parsing [sent. 4637 len. 11]: You are a pretty fellow to object and advise ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4638 len. 4]: exclaimed Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 4639 len. 8]: `` You wish you were going yourself ?
Parsing [sent. 4640 len. 6]: And you a Frenchman born ?
Parsing [sent. 4641 len. 7]: You are a wise counsellor . ''

Parsing [sent. 4643 len. 51]: One can not help thinking , having had some sympathy for the miserable people , and having abandoned something to them , '' he spoke here in his former thoughtful manner , `` that one might be listened to , and might have the power to persuade to some restraint .

Parsing [sent. 4645 len. 3]: `` Yes .
Parsing [sent. 4646 len. 13]: I wonder you are not ashamed to mention the name of Lucie !
Parsing [sent. 4647 len. 13]: Wishing you were going to France at this time of day ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4648 len. 17]: `` However , I am not going , '' said Charles Darnay , with a smile .
Parsing [sent. 4649 len. 14]: `` It is more to the purpose that you say you are . ''
Parsing [sent. 4650 len. 9]: `` And I am , in plain reality .
Parsing [sent. 4651 len. 53]: The truth is , my dear Charles , '' Mr. Lorry glanced at the distant House , and lowered his voice , `` you can have no conception of the difficulty with which our business is transacted , and of the peril in which our books and papers over yonder are involved .
Parsing [sent. 4652 len. 53]: The Lord above knows what the compromising consequences would be to numbers of people , if some of our documents were seized or destroyed ; and they might be , at any time , you know , for who can say that Paris is not set afire to-day , or sacked to-morrow !
Parsing [sent. 4653 len. 52]: Now , a judicious selection from these with the least possible delay , and the burying of them , or otherwise getting of them out of harm 's way , is within the power -LRB- without loss of precious time -RRB- of scarcely any one but myself , if any one .
Parsing [sent. 4654 len. 37]: And shall I hang back , when Tellson 's knows this and says this -- Tellson 's , whose bread I have eaten these sixty years -- because I am a little stiff about the joints ?
Parsing [sent. 4655 len. 18]: Why , I am a boy , sir , to half a dozen old codgers here ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4656 len. 15]: `` How I admire the gallantry of your youthful spirit , Mr. Lorry . ''
Parsing [sent. 4657 len. 3]: `` Tut !
Parsing [sent. 4658 len. 4]: Nonsense , sir !

Parsing [sent. 4660 len. 59]: Papers and precious matters were this very day brought to us here -LRB- I speak in strict confidence ; it is not business-like to whisper it , even to you -RRB- , by the strangest bearers you can imagine , every one of whom had his head hanging on by a single hair as he passed the Barriers .
Parsing [sent. 4661 len. 27]: At another time , our parcels would come and go , as easily as in business-like Old England ; but now , everything is stopped . ''

Parsing [sent. 4667 len. 20]: Jerry has been my bodyguard on Sunday nights for a long time past and I am used to him .

Parsing [sent. 4669 len. 15]: `` I must say again that I heartily admire your gallantry and youthfulness . ''
Parsing [sent. 4670 len. 10]: `` I must say again , nonsense , nonsense !
Parsing [sent. 4671 len. 25]: When I have executed this little commission , I shall , perhaps , accept Tellson 's proposal to retire and live at my ease .
Parsing [sent. 4672 len. 12]: Time enough , then , to think about growing old . ''
Parsing [sent. 4673 len. 38]: This dialogue had taken place at Mr. Lorry 's usual desk , with Monseigneur swarming within a yard or two of it , boastful of what he would do to avenge himself on the rascal-people before long .
Parsing [sent. 4674 len. 117]: It was too much the way of Monseigneur under his reverses as a refugee , and it was much too much the way of native British orthodoxy , to talk of this terrible Revolution as if it were the only harvest ever known under the skies that had not been sown -- as if nothing had ever been done , or omitted to be done , that had led to it -- as if observers of the wretched millions in France , and of the misused and perverted resources that should have made them prosperous , had not seen it inevitably coming , years before , and had not in plain words recorded what they saw .
Parsing [sent. 4675 len. 52]: Such vapouring , combined with the extravagant plots of Monseigneur for the restoration of a state of things that had utterly exhausted itself , and worn out Heaven and earth as well as itself , was hard to be endured without some remonstrance by any sane man who knew the truth .
Parsing [sent. 4676 len. 45]: And it was such vapouring all about his ears , like a troublesome confusion of blood in his own head , added to a latent uneasiness in his mind , which had already made Charles Darnay restless , and which still kept him so .
Parsing [sent. 4677 len. 82]: Among the talkers , was Stryver , of the King 's Bench Bar , far on his way to state promotion , and , therefore , loud on the theme : broaching to Monseigneur , his devices for blowing the people up and exterminating them from the face of the earth , and doing without them : and for accomplishing many similar objects akin in their nature to the abolition of eagles by sprinkling salt on the tails of the race .
Parsing [sent. 4678 len. 47]: Him , Darnay heard with a particular feeling of objection ; and Darnay stood divided between going away that he might hear no more , and remaining to interpose his word , when the thing that was to be , went on to shape itself out .
Parsing [sent. 4679 len. 33]: The House approached Mr. Lorry , and laying a soiled and unopened letter before him , asked if he had yet discovered any traces of the person to whom it was addressed ?
Parsing [sent. 4680 len. 27]: The House laid the letter down so close to Darnay that he saw the direction -- the more quickly because it was his own right name .
Parsing [sent. 4681 len. 13]: The address , turned into English , ran : `` Very pressing .
Parsing [sent. 4682 len. 11]: To Monsieur heretofore the Marquis St. Evremonde , of France .
Parsing [sent. 4683 len. 17]: Confided to the cares of Messrs. Tellson and Co. , Bankers , London , England . ''
Parsing [sent. 4684 len. 44]: On the marriage morning , Doctor Manette had made it his one urgent and express request to Charles Darnay , that the secret of this name should be -- unless he , the Doctor , dissolved the obligation -- kept inviolate between them .
Parsing [sent. 4685 len. 25]: Nobody else knew it to be his name ; his own wife had no suspicion of the fact ; Mr. Lorry could have none .
Parsing [sent. 4686 len. 43]: `` No , '' said Mr. Lorry , in reply to the House ; `` I have referred it , I think , to everybody now here , and no one can tell me where this gentleman is to be found . ''
Parsing [sent. 4687 len. 30]: The hands of the clock verging upon the hour of closing the Bank , there was a general set of the current of talkers past Mr. Lorry 's desk .
Parsing [sent. 4688 len. 70]: He held the letter out inquiringly ; and Monseigneur looked at it , in the person of this plotting and indignant refugee ; and Monseigneur looked at it in the person of that plotting and indignant refugee ; and This , That , and The Other , all had something disparaging to say , in French or in English , concerning the Marquis who was not to be found .
Parsing [sent. 4689 len. 25]: `` Nephew , I believe -- but in any case degenerate successor -- of the polished Marquis who was murdered , '' said one .
Parsing [sent. 4690 len. 11]: `` Happy to say , I never knew him . ''

Parsing [sent. 4692 len. 47]: `` Infected with the new doctrines , '' said a third , eyeing the direction through his glass in passing ; `` set himself in opposition to the last Marquis , abandoned the estates when he inherited them , and left them to the ruffian herd .
Parsing [sent. 4693 len. 14]: They will recompense him now , I hope , as he deserves . ''
Parsing [sent. 4694 len. 4]: `` Hey ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4695 len. 5]: cried the blatant Stryver .
Parsing [sent. 4696 len. 5]: `` Did he though ?
Parsing [sent. 4697 len. 7]: Is that the sort of fellow ?
Parsing [sent. 4698 len. 8]: Let us look at his infamous name .

Parsing [sent. 4700 len. 26]: Darnay , unable to restrain himself any longer , touched Mr. Stryver on the shoulder , and said : `` I know the fellow . ''
Parsing [sent. 4701 len. 8]: `` Do you , by Jupiter ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4702 len. 3]: said Stryver .
Parsing [sent. 4703 len. 8]: `` I am sorry for it . ''
Parsing [sent. 4704 len. 4]: `` Why ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4705 len. 6]: `` Why , Mr. Darnay ?

Parsing [sent. 4708 len. 8]: `` But I do ask why ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4709 len. 16]: `` Then I tell you again , Mr. Darnay , I am sorry for it .
Parsing [sent. 4710 len. 12]: I am sorry to hear you putting any such extraordinary questions .
Parsing [sent. 4711 len. 56]: Here is a fellow , who , infected by the most pestilent and blasphemous code of devilry that ever was known , abandoned his property to the vilest scum of the earth that ever did murder by wholesale , and you ask me why I am sorry that a man who instructs youth knows him ?
Parsing [sent. 4712 len. 8]: Well , but I 'll answer you .
Parsing [sent. 4713 len. 14]: I am sorry because I believe there is contamination in such a scoundrel .
Parsing [sent. 4714 len. 5]: That 's why . ''
Parsing [sent. 4715 len. 24]: Mindful of the secret , Darnay with great difficulty checked himself , and said : `` You may not understand the gentleman . ''
Parsing [sent. 4716 len. 26]: `` I understand how to put YOU in a corner , Mr. Darnay , '' said Bully Stryver , `` and I 'll do it .
Parsing [sent. 4717 len. 13]: If this fellow is a gentleman , I DO N'T understand him .
Parsing [sent. 4718 len. 10]: You may tell him so , with my compliments .
Parsing [sent. 4719 len. 33]: You may also tell him , from me , that after abandoning his worldly goods and position to this butcherly mob , I wonder he is not at the head of them .
Parsing [sent. 4720 len. 52]: But , no , gentlemen , '' said Stryver , looking all round , and snapping his fingers , `` I know something of human nature , and I tell you that you 'll never find a fellow like this fellow , trusting himself to the mercies of such precious PROTEGES .
Parsing [sent. 4721 len. 25]: No , gentlemen ; he 'll always show 'em a clean pair of heels very early in the scuffle , and sneak away . ''
Parsing [sent. 4722 len. 27]: With those words , and a final snap of his fingers , Mr. Stryver shouldered himself into Fleet-street , amidst the general approbation of his hearers .
Parsing [sent. 4723 len. 20]: Mr. Lorry and Charles Darnay were left alone at the desk , in the general departure from the Bank .

Parsing [sent. 4727 len. 5]: `` I do . ''

Parsing [sent. 4731 len. 8]: `` From here , at eight . ''
Parsing [sent. 4732 len. 12]: `` I will come back , to see you off . ''
Parsing [sent. 4733 len. 37]: Very ill at ease with himself , and with Stryver and most other men , Darnay made the best of his way into the quiet of the Temple , opened the letter , and read it .
Parsing [sent. 4734 len. 13]: These were its contents : `` Prison of the Abbaye , Paris .
Parsing [sent. 4735 len. 6]: `` June 21 , 1792 .
Parsing [sent. 4736 len. 6]: `` MONSIEUR HERETOFORE THE MARQUIS .
Parsing [sent. 4737 len. 38]: `` After having long been in danger of my life at the hands of the village , I have been seized , with great violence and indignity , and brought a long journey on foot to Paris .
Parsing [sent. 4738 len. 10]: On the road I have suffered a great deal .
Parsing [sent. 4739 len. 16]: Nor is that all ; my house has been destroyed -- razed to the ground .
Parsing [sent. 4740 len. 63]: `` The crime for which I am imprisoned , Monsieur heretofore the Marquis , and for which I shall be summoned before the tribunal , and shall lose my life -LRB- without your so generous help -RRB- , is , they tell me , treason against the majesty of the people , in that I have acted against them for an emigrant .
Parsing [sent. 4741 len. 22]: It is in vain I represent that I have acted for them , and not against , according to your commands .
Parsing [sent. 4742 len. 42]: It is in vain I represent that , before the sequestration of emigrant property , I had remitted the imposts they had ceased to pay ; that I had collected no rent ; that I had had recourse to no process .
Parsing [sent. 4743 len. 19]: The only response is , that I have acted for an emigrant , and where is that emigrant ?
Parsing [sent. 4744 len. 3]: `` Ah !
Parsing [sent. 4745 len. 12]: most gracious Monsieur heretofore the Marquis , where is that emigrant ?
Parsing [sent. 4746 len. 9]: I cry in my sleep where is he ?
Parsing [sent. 4747 len. 13]: I demand of Heaven , will he not come to deliver me ?
Parsing [sent. 4748 len. 3]: No answer .
Parsing [sent. 4749 len. 32]: Ah Monsieur heretofore the Marquis , I send my desolate cry across the sea , hoping it may perhaps reach your ears through the great bank of Tilson known at Paris !
Parsing [sent. 4750 len. 36]: `` For the love of Heaven , of justice , of generosity , of the honour of your noble name , I supplicate you , Monsieur heretofore the Marquis , to succour and release me .
Parsing [sent. 4751 len. 12]: My fault is , that I have been true to you .
Parsing [sent. 4752 len. 15]: Oh Monsieur heretofore the Marquis , I pray you be you true to me !
Parsing [sent. 4753 len. 37]: `` From this prison here of horror , whence I every hour tend nearer and nearer to destruction , I send you , Monsieur heretofore the Marquis , the assurance of my dolorous and unhappy service .
Parsing [sent. 4754 len. 8]: `` Your afflicted , `` Gabelle . ''
Parsing [sent. 4755 len. 16]: The latent uneasiness in Darnay 's mind was roused to vigourous life by this letter .
Parsing [sent. 4756 len. 55]: The peril of an old servant and a good one , whose only crime was fidelity to himself and his family , stared him so reproachfully in the face , that , as he walked to and fro in the Temple considering what to do , he almost hid his face from the passersby .
Parsing [sent. 4757 len. 59]: He knew very well , that in his horror of the deed which had culminated the bad deeds and bad reputation of the old family house , in his resentful suspicions of his uncle , and in the aversion with which his conscience regarded the crumbling fabric that he was supposed to uphold , he had acted imperfectly .
Parsing [sent. 4758 len. 35]: He knew very well , that in his love for Lucie , his renunciation of his social place , though by no means new to his own mind , had been hurried and incomplete .
Parsing [sent. 4759 len. 32]: He knew that he ought to have systematically worked it out and supervised it , and that he had meant to do it , and that it had never been done .
Parsing [sent. 4760 len. 89]: The happiness of his own chosen English home , the necessity of being always actively employed , the swift changes and troubles of the time which had followed on one another so fast , that the events of this week annihilated the immature plans of last week , and the events of the week following made all new again ; he knew very well , that to the force of these circumstances he had yielded : -- not without disquiet , but still without continuous and accumulating resistance .
Parsing [sent. 4761 len. 81]: That he had watched the times for a time of action , and that they had shifted and struggled until the time had gone by , and the nobility were trooping from France by every highway and byway , and their property was in course of confiscation and destruction , and their very names were blotting out , was as well known to himself as it could be to any new authority in France that might impeach him for it .
Parsing [sent. 4762 len. 61]: But , he had oppressed no man , he had imprisoned no man ; he was so far from having harshly exacted payment of his dues , that he had relinquished them of his own will , thrown himself on a world with no favour in it , won his own private place there , and earned his own bread .
Parsing [sent. 4763 len. 84]: Monsieur Gabelle had held the impoverished and involved estate on written instructions , to spare the people , to give them what little there was to give -- such fuel as the heavy creditors would let them have in the winter , and such produce as could be saved from the same grip in the summer -- and no doubt he had put the fact in plea and proof , for his own safety , so that it could not but appear now .
Parsing [sent. 4764 len. 19]: This favoured the desperate resolution Charles Darnay had begun to make , that he would go to Paris .
Parsing [sent. 4765 len. 2]: Yes .
Parsing [sent. 4766 len. 36]: Like the mariner in the old story , the winds and streams had driven him within the influence of the Loadstone Rock , and it was drawing him to itself , and he must go .
Parsing [sent. 4767 len. 24]: Everything that arose before his mind drifted him on , faster and faster , more and more steadily , to the terrible attraction .
Parsing [sent. 4768 len. 59]: His latent uneasiness had been , that bad aims were being worked out in his own unhappy land by bad instruments , and that he who could not fail to know that he was better than they , was not there , trying to do something to stay bloodshed , and assert the claims of mercy and humanity .
Parsing [sent. 4769 len. 72]: With this uneasiness half stifled , and half reproaching him , he had been brought to the pointed comparison of himself with the brave old gentleman in whom duty was so strong ; upon that comparison -LRB- injurious to himself -RRB- had instantly followed the sneers of Monseigneur , which had stung him bitterly , and those of Stryver , which above all were coarse and galling , for old reasons .
Parsing [sent. 4770 len. 31]: Upon those , had followed Gabelle 's letter : the appeal of an innocent prisoner , in danger of death , to his justice , honour , and good name .
Parsing [sent. 4771 len. 5]: His resolution was made .
Parsing [sent. 4772 len. 6]: He must go to Paris .
Parsing [sent. 4773 len. 2]: Yes .
Parsing [sent. 4774 len. 17]: The Loadstone Rock was drawing him , and he must sail on , until he struck .
Parsing [sent. 4775 len. 12]: He knew of no rock ; he saw hardly any danger .
Parsing [sent. 4776 len. 42]: The intention with which he had done what he had done , even although he had left it incomplete , presented it before him in an aspect that would be gratefully acknowledged in France on his presenting himself to assert it .
Parsing [sent. 4777 len. 49]: Then , that glorious vision of doing good , which is so often the sanguine mirage of so many good minds , arose before him , and he even saw himself in the illusion with some influence to guide this raging Revolution that was running so fearfully wild .
Parsing [sent. 4778 len. 28]: As he walked to and fro with his resolution made , he considered that neither Lucie nor her father must know of it until he was gone .
Parsing [sent. 4779 len. 50]: Lucie should be spared the pain of separation ; and her father , always reluctant to turn his thoughts towards the dangerous ground of old , should come to the knowledge of the step , as a step taken , and not in the balance of suspense and doubt .
Parsing [sent. 4780 len. 36]: How much of the incompleteness of his situation was referable to her father , through the painful anxiety to avoid reviving old associations of France in his mind , he did not discuss with himself .
Parsing [sent. 4781 len. 14]: But , that circumstance too , had had its influence in his course .
Parsing [sent. 4782 len. 27]: He walked to and fro , with thoughts very busy , until it was time to return to Tellson 's and take leave of Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 4783 len. 26]: As soon as he arrived in Paris he would present himself to this old friend , but he must say nothing of his intention now .
Parsing [sent. 4784 len. 18]: A carriage with post-horses was ready at the Bank door , and Jerry was booted and equipped .
Parsing [sent. 4785 len. 15]: `` I have delivered that letter , '' said Charles Darnay to Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 4786 len. 24]: `` I would not consent to your being charged with any written answer , but perhaps you will take a verbal one ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4787 len. 21]: `` That I will , and readily , '' said Mr. Lorry , `` if it is not dangerous . ''
Parsing [sent. 4788 len. 5]: `` Not at all .
Parsing [sent. 4789 len. 11]: Though it is to a prisoner in the Abbaye . ''
Parsing [sent. 4790 len. 7]: `` What is his name ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4791 len. 12]: said Mr. Lorry , with his open pocket-book in his hand .
Parsing [sent. 4792 len. 4]: `` Gabelle . ''
Parsing [sent. 4793 len. 3]: `` Gabelle .
Parsing [sent. 4794 len. 13]: And what is the message to the unfortunate Gabelle in prison ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4795 len. 17]: `` Simply , ` that he has received the letter , and will come . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 4796 len. 6]: `` Any time mentioned ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4797 len. 11]: `` He will start upon his journey to-morrow night . ''
Parsing [sent. 4798 len. 6]: `` Any person mentioned ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4799 len. 4]: `` No . ''
Parsing [sent. 4800 len. 36]: He helped Mr. Lorry to wrap himself in a number of coats and cloaks , and went out with him from the warm atmosphere of the old Bank , into the misty air of Fleet-street .
Parsing [sent. 4801 len. 31]: `` My love to Lucie , and to little Lucie , '' said Mr. Lorry at parting , `` and take precious care of them till I come back . ''
Parsing [sent. 4802 len. 15]: Charles Darnay shook his head and doubtfully smiled , as the carriage rolled away .
Parsing [sent. 4803 len. 93]: That night -- it was the fourteenth of August -- he sat up late , and wrote two fervent letters ; one was to Lucie , explaining the strong obligation he was under to go to Paris , and showing her , at length , the reasons that he had , for feeling confident that he could become involved in no personal danger there ; the other was to the Doctor , confiding Lucie and their dear child to his care , and dwelling on the same topics with the strongest assurances .
Parsing [sent. 4804 len. 21]: To both , he wrote that he would despatch letters in proof of his safety , immediately after his arrival .
Parsing [sent. 4805 len. 25]: It was a hard day , that day of being among them , with the first reservation of their joint lives on his mind .
Parsing [sent. 4806 len. 17]: It was a hard matter to preserve the innocent deceit of which they were profoundly unsuspicious .
Parsing [sent. 4807 len. 55]: But , an affectionate glance at his wife , so happy and busy , made him resolute not to tell her what impended -LRB- he had been half moved to do it , so strange it was to him to act in anything without her quiet aid -RRB- , and the day passed quickly .
Parsing [sent. 4808 len. 58]: Early in the evening he embraced her , and her scarcely less dear namesake , pretending that he would return by-and-bye -LRB- an imaginary engagement took him out , and he had secreted a valise of clothes ready -RRB- , and so he emerged into the heavy mist of the heavy streets , with a heavier heart .
Parsing [sent. 4809 len. 26]: The unseen force was drawing him fast to itself , now , and all the tides and winds were setting straight and strong towards it .
Parsing [sent. 4810 len. 33]: He left his two letters with a trusty porter , to be delivered half an hour before midnight , and no sooner ; took horse for Dover ; and began his journey .
Parsing [sent. 4811 len. 22]: `` For the love of Heaven , of justice , of generosity , of the honour of your noble name ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4812 len. 34]: was the poor prisoner 's cry with which he strengthened his sinking heart , as he left all that was dear on earth behind him , and floated away for the Loadstone Rock .
Parsing [sent. 4813 len. 7]: The end of the second book .
Parsing [sent. 4814 len. 39]: Book the Third -- the Track of a Storm I In Secret The traveller fared slowly on his way , who fared towards Paris from England in the autumn of the year one thousand seven hundred and ninety-two .
Parsing [sent. 4815 len. 53]: More than enough of bad roads , bad equipages , and bad horses , he would have encountered to delay him , though the fallen and unfortunate King of France had been upon his throne in all his glory ; but , the changed times were fraught with other obstacles than these .
Parsing [sent. 4816 len. 91]: Every town-gate and village taxing-house had its band of citizen-patriots , with their national muskets in a most explosive state of readiness , who stopped all comers and goers , cross-questioned them , inspected their papers , looked for their names in lists of their own , turned them back , or sent them on , or stopped them and laid them in hold , as their capricious judgment or fancy deemed best for the dawning Republic One and Indivisible , of Liberty , Equality , Fraternity , or Death .
Parsing [sent. 4817 len. 42]: A very few French leagues of his journey were accomplished , when Charles Darnay began to perceive that for him along these country roads there was no hope of return until he should have been declared a good citizen at Paris .
Parsing [sent. 4818 len. 14]: Whatever might befall now , he must on to his journey 's end .
Parsing [sent. 4819 len. 39]: Not a mean village closed upon him , not a common barrier dropped across the road behind him , but he knew it to be another iron door in the series that was barred between him and England .
Parsing [sent. 4820 len. 39]: The universal watchfulness so encompassed him , that if he had been taken in a net , or were being forwarded to his destination in a cage , he could not have felt his freedom more completely gone .
Parsing [sent. 4821 len. 53]: This universal watchfulness not only stopped him on the highway twenty times in a stage , but retarded his progress twenty times in a day , by riding after him and taking him back , riding before him and stopping him by anticipation , riding with him and keeping him in charge .
Parsing [sent. 4822 len. 35]: He had been days upon his journey in France alone , when he went to bed tired out , in a little town on the high road , still a long way from Paris .
Parsing [sent. 4823 len. 24]: Nothing but the production of the afflicted Gabelle 's letter from his prison of the Abbaye would have got him on so far .
Parsing [sent. 4824 len. 25]: His difficulty at the guard-house in this small place had been such , that he felt his journey to have come to a crisis .
Parsing [sent. 4825 len. 39]: And he was , therefore , as little surprised as a man could be , to find himself awakened at the small inn to which he had been remitted until morning , in the middle of the night .
Parsing [sent. 4826 len. 28]: Awakened by a timid local functionary and three armed patriots in rough red caps and with pipes in their mouths , who sat down on the bed .
Parsing [sent. 4827 len. 24]: `` Emigrant , '' said the functionary , `` I am going to send you on to Paris , under an escort . ''
Parsing [sent. 4828 len. 22]: `` Citizen , I desire nothing more than to get to Paris , though I could dispense with the escort . ''
Parsing [sent. 4829 len. 4]: `` Silence ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4830 len. 15]: growled a red-cap , striking at the coverlet with the butt-end of his musket .
Parsing [sent. 4831 len. 6]: `` Peace , aristocrat ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4832 len. 15]: `` It is as the good patriot says , '' observed the timid functionary .
Parsing [sent. 4833 len. 19]: `` You are an aristocrat , and must have an escort -- and must pay for it . ''
Parsing [sent. 4834 len. 11]: `` I have no choice , '' said Charles Darnay .
Parsing [sent. 4835 len. 3]: `` Choice !
Parsing [sent. 4836 len. 5]: Listen to him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4837 len. 6]: cried the same scowling red-cap .
Parsing [sent. 4838 len. 16]: `` As if it was not a favour to be protected from the lamp-iron ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4839 len. 15]: `` It is always as the good patriot says , '' observed the functionary .
Parsing [sent. 4840 len. 9]: `` Rise and dress yourself , emigrant . ''
Parsing [sent. 4841 len. 30]: Darnay complied , and was taken back to the guard-house , where other patriots in rough red caps were smoking , drinking , and sleeping , by a watch-fire .
Parsing [sent. 4842 len. 29]: Here he paid a heavy price for his escort , and hence he started with it on the wet , wet roads at three o'clock in the morning .
Parsing [sent. 4843 len. 29]: The escort were two mounted patriots in red caps and tri-coloured cockades , armed with national muskets and sabres , who rode one on either side of him .
Parsing [sent. 4844 len. 31]: The escorted governed his own horse , but a loose line was attached to his bridle , the end of which one of the patriots kept girded round his wrist .
Parsing [sent. 4845 len. 34]: In this state they set forth with the sharp rain driving in their faces : clattering at a heavy dragoon trot over the uneven town pavement , and out upon the mire-deep roads .
Parsing [sent. 4846 len. 26]: In this state they traversed without change , except of horses and pace , all the mire-deep leagues that lay between them and the capital .
Parsing [sent. 4847 len. 22]: They travelled in the night , halting an hour or two after daybreak , and lying by until the twilight fell .
Parsing [sent. 4848 len. 27]: The escort were so wretchedly clothed , that they twisted straw round their bare legs , and thatched their ragged shoulders to keep the wet off .
Parsing [sent. 4849 len. 100]: Apart from the personal discomfort of being so attended , and apart from such considerations of present danger as arose from one of the patriots being chronically drunk , and carrying his musket very recklessly , Charles Darnay did not allow the restraint that was laid upon him to awaken any serious fears in his breast ; for , he reasoned with himself that it could have no reference to the merits of an individual case that was not yet stated , and of representations , confirmable by the prisoner in the Abbaye , that were not yet made .
Parsing [sent. 4850 len. 39]: But when they came to the town of Beauvais -- which they did at eventide , when the streets were filled with people -- he could not conceal from himself that the aspect of affairs was very alarming .
Parsing [sent. 4851 len. 26]: An ominous crowd gathered to see him dismount of the posting-yard , and many voices called out loudly , `` Down with the emigrant ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4852 len. 30]: He stopped in the act of swinging himself out of his saddle , and , resuming it as his safest place , said : `` Emigrant , my friends !
Parsing [sent. 4853 len. 16]: Do you not see me here , in France , of my own will ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4854 len. 36]: `` You are a cursed emigrant , '' cried a farrier , making at him in a furious manner through the press , hammer in hand ; `` and you are a cursed aristocrat ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4855 len. 34]: The postmaster interposed himself between this man and the rider 's bridle -LRB- at which he was evidently making -RRB- , and soothingly said , `` Let him be ; let him be !
Parsing [sent. 4856 len. 8]: He will be judged at Paris . ''
Parsing [sent. 4857 len. 4]: `` Judged ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4858 len. 8]: repeated the farrier , swinging his hammer .
Parsing [sent. 4859 len. 3]: `` Ay !
Parsing [sent. 4860 len. 7]: and condemned as a traitor . ''
Parsing [sent. 4861 len. 7]: At this the crowd roared approval .
Parsing [sent. 4862 len. 60]: Checking the postmaster , who was for turning his horse 's head to the yard -LRB- the drunken patriot sat composedly in his saddle looking on , with the line round his wrist -RRB- , Darnay said , as soon as he could make his voice heard : `` Friends , you deceive yourselves , or you are deceived .
Parsing [sent. 4863 len. 7]: I am not a traitor . ''
Parsing [sent. 4864 len. 5]: `` He lies ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4865 len. 4]: cried the smith .
Parsing [sent. 4866 len. 9]: `` He is a traitor since the decree .
Parsing [sent. 4867 len. 8]: His life is forfeit to the people .
Parsing [sent. 4868 len. 9]: His cursed life is not his own ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4869 len. 55]: At the instant when Darnay saw a rush in the eyes of the crowd , which another instant would have brought upon him , the postmaster turned his horse into the yard , the escort rode in close upon his horse 's flanks , and the postmaster shut and barred the crazy double gates .
Parsing [sent. 4870 len. 23]: The farrier struck a blow upon them with his hammer , and the crowd groaned ; but , no more was done .
Parsing [sent. 4871 len. 12]: `` What is this decree that the smith spoke of ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4872 len. 19]: Darnay asked the postmaster , when he had thanked him , and stood beside him in the yard .
Parsing [sent. 4873 len. 13]: `` Truly , a decree for selling the property of emigrants . ''
Parsing [sent. 4874 len. 5]: `` When passed ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4875 len. 6]: `` On the fourteenth . ''
Parsing [sent. 4876 len. 8]: `` The day I left England ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4877 len. 33]: `` Everybody says it is but one of several , and that there will be others -- if there are not already-banishing all emigrants , and condemning all to death who return .
Parsing [sent. 4878 len. 16]: That is what he meant when he said your life was not your own . ''
Parsing [sent. 4879 len. 10]: `` But there are no such decrees yet ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4880 len. 7]: `` What do I know ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4881 len. 18]: said the postmaster , shrugging his shoulders ; `` there may be , or there will be .
Parsing [sent. 4882 len. 6]: It is all the same .
Parsing [sent. 4883 len. 6]: What would you have ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4884 len. 27]: They rested on some straw in a loft until the middle of the night , and then rode forward again when all the town was asleep .
Parsing [sent. 4885 len. 26]: Among the many wild changes observable on familiar things which made this wild ride unreal , not the least was the seeming rarity of sleep .
Parsing [sent. 4886 len. 68]: After long and lonely spurring over dreary roads , they would come to a cluster of poor cottages , not steeped in darkness , but all glittering with lights , and would find the people , in a ghostly manner in the dead of the night , circling hand in hand round a shrivelled tree of Liberty , or all drawn up together singing a Liberty song .
Parsing [sent. 4887 len. 86]: Happily , however , there was sleep in Beauvais that night to help them out of it and they passed on once more into solitude and loneliness : jingling through the untimely cold and wet , among impoverished fields that had yielded no fruits of the earth that year , diversified by the blackened remains of burnt houses , and by the sudden emergence from ambuscade , and sharp reining up across their way , of patriot patrols on the watch on all the roads .
Parsing [sent. 4888 len. 11]: Daylight at last found them before the wall of Paris .
Parsing [sent. 4889 len. 14]: The barrier was closed and strongly guarded when they rode up to it .
Parsing [sent. 4890 len. 10]: `` Where are the papers of this prisoner ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4891 len. 15]: demanded a resolute-looking man in authority , who was summoned out by the guard .
Parsing [sent. 4892 len. 49]: Naturally struck by the disagreeable word , Charles Darnay requested the speaker to take notice that he was a free traveller and French citizen , in charge of an escort which the disturbed state of the country had imposed upon him , and which he had paid for .
Parsing [sent. 4893 len. 26]: `` Where , '' repeated the same personage , without taking any heed of him whatever , `` are the papers of this prisoner ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4894 len. 13]: The drunken patriot had them in his cap , and produced them .
Parsing [sent. 4895 len. 28]: Casting his eyes over Gabelle 's letter , the same personage in authority showed some disorder and surprise , and looked at Darnay with a close attention .
Parsing [sent. 4896 len. 29]: He left escort and escorted without saying a word , however , and went into the guard-room ; meanwhile , they sat upon their horses outside the gate .
Parsing [sent. 4897 len. 72]: Looking about him while in this state of suspense , Charles Darnay observed that the gate was held by a mixed guard of soldiers and patriots , the latter far outnumbering the former ; and that while ingress into the city for peasants ' carts bringing in supplies , and for similar traffic and traffickers , was easy enough , egress , even for the homeliest people , was very difficult .
Parsing [sent. 4898 len. 42]: A numerous medley of men and women , not to mention beasts and vehicles of various sorts , was waiting to issue forth ; but , the previous identification was so strict , that they filtered through the barrier very slowly .
Parsing [sent. 4899 len. 36]: Some of these people knew their turn for examination to be so far off , that they lay down on the ground to sleep or smoke , while others talked together , or loitered about .
Parsing [sent. 4900 len. 15]: The red cap and tri-colour cockade were universal , both among men and women .
Parsing [sent. 4901 len. 36]: When he had sat in his saddle some half-hour , taking note of these things , Darnay found himself confronted by the same man in authority , who directed the guard to open the barrier .
Parsing [sent. 4902 len. 23]: Then he delivered to the escort , drunk and sober , a receipt for the escorted , and requested him to dismount .
Parsing [sent. 4903 len. 23]: He did so , and the two patriots , leading his tired horse , turned and rode away without entering the city .
Parsing [sent. 4904 len. 49]: He accompanied his conductor into a guard-room , smelling of common wine and tobacco , where certain soldiers and patriots , asleep and awake , drunk and sober , and in various neutral states between sleeping and waking , drunkenness and sobriety , were standing and lying about .
Parsing [sent. 4905 len. 30]: The light in the guard-house , half derived from the waning oil-lamps of the night , and half from the overcast day , was in a correspondingly uncertain condition .
Parsing [sent. 4906 len. 23]: Some registers were lying open on a desk , and an officer of a coarse , dark aspect , presided over these .
Parsing [sent. 4907 len. 23]: `` Citizen Defarge , '' said he to Darnay 's conductor , as he took a slip of paper to write on .
Parsing [sent. 4908 len. 8]: `` Is this the emigrant Evremonde ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4909 len. 7]: `` This is the man . ''
Parsing [sent. 4910 len. 7]: `` Your age , Evremonde ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4911 len. 4]: `` Thirty-seven . ''
Parsing [sent. 4912 len. 6]: `` Married , Evremonde ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4913 len. 4]: `` Yes . ''
Parsing [sent. 4914 len. 5]: `` Where married ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4915 len. 5]: `` In England . ''
Parsing [sent. 4916 len. 4]: `` Without doubt .
Parsing [sent. 4917 len. 8]: Where is your wife , Evremonde ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4918 len. 5]: `` In England . ''
Parsing [sent. 4919 len. 4]: `` Without doubt .
Parsing [sent. 4920 len. 14]: You are consigned , Evremonde , to the prison of La Force . ''
Parsing [sent. 4921 len. 5]: `` Just Heaven ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4922 len. 3]: exclaimed Darnay .
Parsing [sent. 4923 len. 11]: `` Under what law , and for what offence ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4924 len. 13]: The officer looked up from his slip of paper for a moment .
Parsing [sent. 4925 len. 18]: `` We have new laws , Evremonde , and new offences , since you were here . ''
Parsing [sent. 4926 len. 13]: He said it with a hard smile , and went on writing .
Parsing [sent. 4927 len. 27]: `` I entreat you to observe that I have come here voluntarily , in response to that written appeal of a fellow-countryman which lies before you .
Parsing [sent. 4928 len. 13]: I demand no more than the opportunity to do so without delay .
Parsing [sent. 4929 len. 7]: Is not that my right ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4930 len. 14]: `` Emigrants have no rights , Evremonde , '' was the stolid reply .
Parsing [sent. 4931 len. 34]: The officer wrote until he had finished , read over to himself what he had written , sanded it , and handed it to Defarge , with the words `` In secret . ''
Parsing [sent. 4932 len. 14]: Defarge motioned with the paper to the prisoner that he must accompany him .
Parsing [sent. 4933 len. 14]: The prisoner obeyed , and a guard of two armed patriots attended them .
Parsing [sent. 4934 len. 47]: `` Is it you , '' said Defarge , in a low voice , as they went down the guardhouse steps and turned into Paris , `` who married the daughter of Doctor Manette , once a prisoner in the Bastille that is no more ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4935 len. 13]: `` Yes , '' replied Darnay , looking at him with surprise .
Parsing [sent. 4936 len. 17]: `` My name is Defarge , and I keep a wine-shop in the Quarter Saint Antoine .
Parsing [sent. 4937 len. 8]: Possibly you have heard of me . ''
Parsing [sent. 4938 len. 12]: `` My wife came to your house to reclaim her father ?
Parsing [sent. 4939 len. 3]: Yes ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4940 len. 44]: The word `` wife '' seemed to serve as a gloomy reminder to Defarge , to say with sudden impatience , `` In the name of that sharp female newly-born , and called La Guillotine , why did you come to France ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4941 len. 11]: `` You heard me say why , a minute ago .
Parsing [sent. 4942 len. 10]: Do you not believe it is the truth ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4943 len. 22]: `` A bad truth for you , '' said Defarge , speaking with knitted brows , and looking straight before him .
Parsing [sent. 4944 len. 7]: `` Indeed I am lost here .
Parsing [sent. 4945 len. 20]: All here is so unprecedented , so changed , so sudden and unfair , that I am absolutely lost .
Parsing [sent. 4946 len. 9]: Will you render me a little help ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4947 len. 4]: `` None . ''
Parsing [sent. 4948 len. 9]: Defarge spoke , always looking straight before him .
Parsing [sent. 4949 len. 10]: `` Will you answer me a single question ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4950 len. 3]: `` Perhaps .
Parsing [sent. 4951 len. 5]: According to its nature .
Parsing [sent. 4952 len. 8]: You can say what it is . ''
Parsing [sent. 4953 len. 24]: `` In this prison that I am going to so unjustly , shall I have some free communication with the world outside ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4954 len. 6]: `` You will see . ''
Parsing [sent. 4955 len. 21]: `` I am not to be buried there , prejudged , and without any means of presenting my case ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4956 len. 5]: `` You will see .
Parsing [sent. 4957 len. 5]: But , what then ?
Parsing [sent. 4958 len. 14]: Other people have been similarly buried in worse prisons , before now . ''
Parsing [sent. 4959 len. 10]: `` But never by me , Citizen Defarge . ''
Parsing [sent. 4960 len. 18]: Defarge glanced darkly at him for answer , and walked on in a steady and set silence .
Parsing [sent. 4961 len. 27]: The deeper he sank into this silence , the fainter hope there was -- or so Darnay thought -- of his softening in any slight degree .
Parsing [sent. 4962 len. 78]: He , therefore , made haste to say : `` It is of the utmost importance to me -LRB- you know , Citizen , even better than I , of how much importance -RRB- , that I should be able to communicate to Mr. Lorry of Tellson 's Bank , an English gentleman who is now in Paris , the simple fact , without comment , that I have been thrown into the prison of La Force .
Parsing [sent. 4963 len. 11]: Will you cause that to be done for me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 4964 len. 15]: `` I will do , '' Defarge doggedly rejoined , `` nothing for you .
Parsing [sent. 4965 len. 10]: My duty is to my country and the People .
Parsing [sent. 4966 len. 11]: I am the sworn servant of both , against you .
Parsing [sent. 4967 len. 8]: I will do nothing for you . ''
Parsing [sent. 4968 len. 17]: Charles Darnay felt it hopeless to entreat him further , and his pride was touched besides .
Parsing [sent. 4969 len. 27]: As they walked on in silence , he could not but see how used the people were to the spectacle of prisoners passing along the streets .
Parsing [sent. 4970 len. 7]: The very children scarcely noticed him .
Parsing [sent. 4971 len. 50]: A few passers turned their heads , and a few shook their fingers at him as an aristocrat ; otherwise , that a man in good clothes should be going to prison , was no more remarkable than that a labourer in working clothes should be going to work .
Parsing [sent. 4972 len. 43]: In one narrow , dark , and dirty street through which they passed , an excited orator , mounted on a stool , was addressing an excited audience on the crimes against the people , of the king and the royal family .
Parsing [sent. 4973 len. 38]: The few words that he caught from this man 's lips , first made it known to Charles Darnay that the king was in prison , and that the foreign ambassadors had one and all left Paris .
Parsing [sent. 4974 len. 14]: On the road -LRB- except at Beauvais -RRB- he had heard absolutely nothing .
Parsing [sent. 4975 len. 11]: The escort and the universal watchfulness had completely isolated him .
Parsing [sent. 4976 len. 25]: That he had fallen among far greater dangers than those which had developed themselves when he left England , he of course knew now .
Parsing [sent. 4977 len. 22]: That perils had thickened about him fast , and might thicken faster and faster yet , he of course knew now .
Parsing [sent. 4978 len. 28]: He could not but admit to himself that he might not have made this journey , if he could have foreseen the events of a few days .
Parsing [sent. 4979 len. 23]: And yet his misgivings were not so dark as , imagined by the light of this later time , they would appear .
Parsing [sent. 4980 len. 21]: Troubled as the future was , it was the unknown future , and in its obscurity there was ignorant hope .
Parsing [sent. 4981 len. 53]: The horrible massacre , days and nights long , which , within a few rounds of the clock , was to set a great mark of blood upon the blessed garnering time of harvest , was as far out of his knowledge as if it had been a hundred thousand years away .
Parsing [sent. 4982 len. 28]: The `` sharp female newly-born , and called La Guillotine , '' was hardly known to him , or to the generality of people , by name .
Parsing [sent. 4983 len. 23]: The frightful deeds that were to be soon done , were probably unimagined at that time in the brains of the doers .
Parsing [sent. 4984 len. 15]: How could they have a place in the shadowy conceptions of a gentle mind ?
Parsing [sent. 4985 len. 37]: Of unjust treatment in detention and hardship , and in cruel separation from his wife and child , he foreshadowed the likelihood , or the certainty ; but , beyond this , he dreaded nothing distinctly .
Parsing [sent. 4986 len. 26]: With this on his mind , which was enough to carry into a dreary prison courtyard , he arrived at the prison of La Force .

Parsing [sent. 4988 len. 5]: `` What the Devil !
Parsing [sent. 4989 len. 7]: How many more of them ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4990 len. 8]: exclaimed the man with the bloated face .

Parsing [sent. 4992 len. 10]: `` What the Devil , I say again ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4993 len. 9]: exclaimed the gaoler , left with his wife .
Parsing [sent. 4994 len. 6]: `` How many more ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4995 len. 27]: The gaoler 's wife , being provided with no answer to the question , merely replied , `` One must have patience , my dear ! ''
Parsing [sent. 4996 len. 37]: Three turnkeys who entered responsive to a bell she rang , echoed the sentiment , and one added , `` For the love of Liberty ; '' which sounded in that place like an inappropriate conclusion .
Parsing [sent. 4997 len. 25]: The prison of La Force was a gloomy prison , dark and filthy , and with a horrible smell of foul sleep in it .
Parsing [sent. 4998 len. 22]: Extraordinary how soon the noisome flavour of imprisoned sleep , becomes manifest in all such places that are ill cared for !
Parsing [sent. 4999 len. 17]: `` In secret , too , '' grumbled the gaoler , looking at the written paper .
Parsing [sent. 5000 len. 12]: `` As if I was not already full to bursting ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5001 len. 61]: He stuck the paper on a file , in an ill-humour , and Charles Darnay awaited his further pleasure for half an hour : sometimes , pacing to and fro in the strong arched room : sometimes , resting on a stone seat : in either case detained to be imprinted on the memory of the chief and his subordinates .
Parsing [sent. 5002 len. 4]: `` Come ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5003 len. 19]: said the chief , at length taking up his keys , `` come with me , emigrant . ''
Parsing [sent. 5004 len. 43]: Through the dismal prison twilight , his new charge accompanied him by corridor and staircase , many doors clanging and locking behind them , until they came into a large , low , vaulted chamber , crowded with prisoners of both sexes .
Parsing [sent. 5005 len. 40]: The women were seated at a long table , reading and writing , knitting , sewing , and embroidering ; the men were for the most part standing behind their chairs , or lingering up and down the room .
Parsing [sent. 5006 len. 19]: In the instinctive association of prisoners with shameful crime and disgrace , the new-comer recoiled from this company .
Parsing [sent. 5007 len. 42]: But the crowning unreality of his long unreal ride , was , their all at once rising to receive him , with every refinement of manner known to the time , and with all the engaging graces and courtesies of life .
Parsing [sent. 5008 len. 43]: So strangely clouded were these refinements by the prison manners and gloom , so spectral did they become in the inappropriate squalor and misery through which they were seen , that Charles Darnay seemed to stand in a company of the dead .
Parsing [sent. 5009 len. 3]: Ghosts all !
Parsing [sent. 5010 len. 67]: The ghost of beauty , the ghost of stateliness , the ghost of elegance , the ghost of pride , the ghost of frivolity , the ghost of wit , the ghost of youth , the ghost of age , all waiting their dismissal from the desolate shore , all turning on him eyes that were changed by the death they had died in coming there .
Parsing [sent. 5011 len. 5]: It struck him motionless .
Parsing [sent. 5012 len. 85]: The gaoler standing at his side , and the other gaolers moving about , who would have been well enough as to appearance in the ordinary exercise of their functions , looked so extravagantly coarse contrasted with sorrowing mothers and blooming daughters who were there -- with the apparitions of the coquette , the young beauty , and the mature woman delicately bred -- that the inversion of all experience and likelihood which the scene of shadows presented , was heightened to its utmost .
Parsing [sent. 5013 len. 5]: Surely , ghosts all .
Parsing [sent. 5014 len. 19]: Surely , the long unreal ride some progress of disease that had brought him to these gloomy shades !
Parsing [sent. 5015 len. 52]: `` In the name of the assembled companions in misfortune , '' said a gentleman of courtly appearance and address , coming forward , `` I have the honour of giving you welcome to La Force , and of condoling with you on the calamity that has brought you among us .
Parsing [sent. 5016 len. 6]: May it soon terminate happily !
Parsing [sent. 5017 len. 22]: It would be an impertinence elsewhere , but it is not so here , to ask your name and condition ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5018 len. 20]: Charles Darnay roused himself , and gave the required information , in words as suitable as he could find .
Parsing [sent. 5019 len. 33]: `` But I hope , '' said the gentleman , following the chief gaoler with his eyes , who moved across the room , `` that you are not in secret ? ''

Parsing [sent. 5024 len. 20]: Then he added , raising his voice , `` I grieve to inform the society -- in secret . ''
Parsing [sent. 5025 len. 46]: There was a murmur of commiseration as Charles Darnay crossed the room to a grated door where the gaoler awaited him , and many voices -- among which , the soft and compassionate voices of women were conspicuous -- gave him good wishes and encouragement .

Parsing [sent. 5027 len. 11]: The wicket opened on a stone staircase , leading upward .

Parsing [sent. 5029 len. 11]: It struck cold and damp , but was not dark .
