Parsing [sent. 5036 len. 14]: At present , you may buy your food , and nothing more . ''
Parsing [sent. 5037 len. 17]: There were in the cell , a chair , a table , and a straw mattress .
Parsing [sent. 5038 len. 68]: As the gaoler made a general inspection of these objects , and of the four walls , before going out , a wandering fancy wandered through the mind of the prisoner leaning against the wall opposite to him , that this gaoler was so unwholesomely bloated , both in face and person , as to look like a man who had been drowned and filled with water .
Parsing [sent. 5039 len. 27]: When the gaoler was gone , he thought in the same wandering way , `` Now am I left , as if I were dead . ''
Parsing [sent. 5040 len. 40]: Stopping then , to look down at the mattress , he turned from it with a sick feeling , and thought , `` And here in these crawling creatures is the first condition of the body after death . ''
Parsing [sent. 5041 len. 26]: `` Five paces by four and a half , five paces by four and a half , five paces by four and a half . ''
Parsing [sent. 5042 len. 34]: The prisoner walked to and fro in his cell , counting its measurement , and the roar of the city arose like muffled drums with a wild swell of voices added to them .
Parsing [sent. 5043 len. 14]: `` He made shoes , he made shoes , he made shoes . ''
Parsing [sent. 5044 len. 22]: The prisoner counted the measurement again , and paced faster , to draw his mind with him from that latter repetition .

Parsing [sent. 5048 len. 64]: With such scraps tossing and rolling upward from the depths of his mind , the prisoner walked faster and faster , obstinately counting and counting ; and the roar of the city changed to this extent -- that it still rolled in like muffled drums , but with the wail of voices that he knew , in the swell that rose above them .
Parsing [sent. 5049 len. 44]: II The Grindstone Tellson 's Bank , established in the Saint Germain Quarter of Paris , was in a wing of a large house , approached by a courtyard and shut off from the street by a high wall and a strong gate .
Parsing [sent. 5050 len. 34]: The house belonged to a great nobleman who had lived in it until he made a flight from the troubles , in his own cook 's dress , and got across the borders .
Parsing [sent. 5051 len. 43]: A mere beast of the chase flying from hunters , he was still in his metempsychosis no other than the same Monseigneur , the preparation of whose chocolate for whose lips had once occupied three strong men besides the cook in question .
Parsing [sent. 5052 len. 63]: Monseigneur gone , and the three strong men absolving themselves from the sin of having drawn his high wages , by being more than ready and willing to cut his throat on the altar of the dawning Republic one and indivisible of Liberty , Equality , Fraternity , or Death , Monseigneur 's house had been first sequestrated , and then confiscated .
Parsing [sent. 5053 len. 60]: For , all things moved so fast , and decree followed decree with that fierce precipitation , that now upon the third night of the autumn month of September , patriot emissaries of the law were in possession of Monseigneur 's house , and had marked it with the tri-colour , and were drinking brandy in its state apartments .
Parsing [sent. 5054 len. 30]: A place of business in London like Tellson 's place of business in Paris , would soon have driven the House out of its mind and into the Gazette .
Parsing [sent. 5055 len. 29]: For , what would staid British responsibility and respectability have said to orange-trees in boxes in a Bank courtyard , and even to a Cupid over the counter ?
Parsing [sent. 5056 len. 5]: Yet such things were .
Parsing [sent. 5057 len. 38]: Tellson 's had whitewashed the Cupid , but he was still to be seen on the ceiling , in the coolest linen , aiming -LRB- as he very often does -RRB- at money from morning to night .
Parsing [sent. 5058 len. 57]: Bankruptcy must inevitably have come of this young Pagan , in Lombard-street , London , and also of a curtained alcove in the rear of the immortal boy , and also of a looking-glass let into the wall , and also of clerks not at all old , who danced in public on the slightest provocation .
Parsing [sent. 5059 len. 39]: Yet , a French Tellson 's could get on with these things exceedingly well , and , as long as the times held together , no man had taken fright at them , and drawn out his money .
Parsing [sent. 5060 len. 94]: What money would be drawn out of Tellson 's henceforth , and what would lie there , lost and forgotten ; what plate and jewels would tarnish in Tellson 's hiding-places , while the depositors rusted in prisons , and when they should have violently perished ; how many accounts with Tellson 's never to be balanced in this world , must be carried over into the next ; no man could have said , that night , any more than Mr. Jarvis Lorry could , though he thought heavily of these questions .
Parsing [sent. 5061 len. 51]: He sat by a newly-lighted wood fire -LRB- the blighted and unfruitful year was prematurely cold -RRB- , and on his honest and courageous face there was a deeper shade than the pendent lamp could throw , or any object in the room distortedly reflect -- a shade of horror .
Parsing [sent. 5062 len. 27]: He occupied rooms in the Bank , in his fidelity to the House of which he had grown to be a part , lie strong root-ivy .
Parsing [sent. 5063 len. 28]: it chanced that they derived a kind of security from the patriotic occupation of the main building , but the true-hearted old gentleman never calculated about that .
Parsing [sent. 5064 len. 15]: All such circumstances were indifferent to him , so that he did his duty .
Parsing [sent. 5065 len. 30]: On the opposite side of the courtyard , under a colonnade , was extensive standing -- for carriages -- where , indeed , some carriages of Monseigneur yet stood .
Parsing [sent. 5066 len. 52]: Against two of the pillars were fastened two great flaring flambeaux , and in the light of these , standing out in the open air , was a large grindstone : a roughly mounted thing which appeared to have hurriedly been brought there from some neighbouring smithy , or other workshop .
Parsing [sent. 5067 len. 24]: Rising and looking out of window at these harmless objects , Mr. Lorry shivered , and retired to his seat by the fire .
Parsing [sent. 5068 len. 31]: He had opened , not only the glass window , but the lattice blind outside it , and he had closed both again , and he shivered through his frame .
Parsing [sent. 5069 len. 51]: From the streets beyond the high wall and the strong gate , there came the usual night hum of the city , with now and then an indescribable ring in it , weird and unearthly , as if some unwonted sounds of a terrible nature were going up to Heaven .
Parsing [sent. 5070 len. 29]: `` Thank God , '' said Mr. Lorry , clasping his hands , `` that no one near and dear to me is in this dreadful town to-night .
Parsing [sent. 5071 len. 12]: May He have mercy on all who are in danger ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5072 len. 22]: Soon afterwards , the bell at the great gate sounded , and he thought , `` They have come back ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5073 len. 4]: and sat listening .
Parsing [sent. 5074 len. 29]: But , there was no loud irruption into the courtyard , as he had expected , and he heard the gate clash again , and all was quiet .

Parsing [sent. 5120 len. 4]: `` La Force !
Parsing [sent. 5121 len. 51]: Lucie , my child , if ever you were brave and serviceable in your life -- and you were always both -- you will compose yourself now , to do exactly as I bid you ; for more depends upon it than you can think , or I can say .

Parsing [sent. 5130 len. 56]: The old man kissed her , and hurried her into his room , and turned the key ; then , came hurrying back to the Doctor , and opened the window and partly opened the blind , and put his hand upon the Doctor 's arm , and looked out with him into the courtyard .
Parsing [sent. 5131 len. 33]: Looked out upon a throng of men and women : not enough in number , or near enough , to fill the courtyard : not more than forty or fifty in all .
Parsing [sent. 5132 len. 45]: The people in possession of the house had let them in at the gate , and they had rushed in to work at the grindstone ; it had evidently been set up there for their purpose , as in a convenient and retired spot .
Parsing [sent. 5133 len. 11]: But , such awful workers , and such awful work !
Parsing [sent. 5134 len. 55]: The grindstone had a double handle , and , turning at it madly were two men , whose faces , as their long hair Rapped back when the whirlings of the grindstone brought their faces up , were more horrible and cruel than the visages of the wildest savages in their most barbarous disguise .
Parsing [sent. 5135 len. 39]: False eyebrows and false moustaches were stuck upon them , and their hideous countenances were all bloody and sweaty , and all awry with howling , and all staring and glaring with beastly excitement and want of sleep .
Parsing [sent. 5136 len. 70]: As these ruffians turned and turned , their matted locks now flung forward over their eyes , now flung backward over their necks , some women held wine to their mouths that they might drink ; and what with dropping blood , and what with dropping wine , and what with the stream of sparks struck out of the stone , all their wicked atmosphere seemed gore and fire .
Parsing [sent. 5137 len. 17]: The eye could not detect one creature in the group free from the smear of blood .
Parsing [sent. 5138 len. 66]: Shouldering one another to get next at the sharpening-stone , were men stripped to the waist , with the stain all over their limbs and bodies ; men in all sorts of rags , with the stain upon those rags ; men devilishly set off with spoils of women 's lace and silk and ribbon , with the stain dyeing those trifles through and through .
Parsing [sent. 5139 len. 20]: Hatchets , knives , bayonets , swords , all brought to be sharpened , were all red with it .
Parsing [sent. 5140 len. 38]: Some of the hacked swords were tied to the wrists of those who carried them , with strips of linen and fragments of dress : ligatures various in kind , but all deep of the one colour .
Parsing [sent. 5141 len. 54]: And as the frantic wielders of these weapons snatched them from the stream of sparks and tore away into the streets , the same red hue was red in their frenzied eyes ; -- eyes which any unbrutalised beholder would have given twenty years of life , to petrify with a well-directed gun .
Parsing [sent. 5142 len. 36]: All this was seen in a moment , as the vision of a drowning man , or of any human creature at any very great pass , could see a world if it were there .
Parsing [sent. 5143 len. 20]: They drew back from the window , and the Doctor looked for explanation in his friend 's ashy face .
Parsing [sent. 5144 len. 24]: `` They are , '' Mr. Lorry whispered the words , glancing fearfully round at the locked room , `` murdering the prisoners .
Parsing [sent. 5145 len. 40]: If you are sure of what you say ; if you really have the power you think you have -- as I believe you have -- make yourself known to these devils , and get taken to La Force .
Parsing [sent. 5146 len. 21]: It may be too late , I do n't know , but let it not be a minute later ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5147 len. 25]: Doctor Manette pressed his hand , hastened bareheaded out of the room , and was in the courtyard when Mr. Lorry regained the blind .
Parsing [sent. 5148 len. 41]: His streaming white hair , his remarkable face , and the impetuous confidence of his manner , as he put the weapons aside like water , carried him in an instant to the heart of the concourse at the stone .
Parsing [sent. 5149 len. 71]: For a few moments there was a pause , and a hurry , and a murmur , and the unintelligible sound of his voice ; and then Mr. Lorry saw him , surrounded by all , and in the midst of a line of twenty men long , all linked shoulder to shoulder , and hand to shoulder , hurried out with cries of -- `` Live the Bastille prisoner !

Parsing [sent. 5152 len. 9]: Save the prisoner Evremonde at La Force ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5153 len. 6]: and a thousand answering shouts .
Parsing [sent. 5154 len. 41]: He closed the lattice again with a fluttering heart , closed the window and the curtain , hastened to Lucie , and told her that her father was assisted by the people , and gone in search of her husband .
Parsing [sent. 5155 len. 42]: He found her child and Miss Pross with her ; but , it never occurred to him to be surprised by their appearance until a long time afterwards , when he sat watching them in such quiet as the night knew .
Parsing [sent. 5156 len. 23]: Lucie had , by that time , fallen into a stupor on the floor at his feet , clinging to his hand .
Parsing [sent. 5157 len. 26]: Miss Pross had laid the child down on his own bed , and her head had gradually fallen on the pillow beside her pretty charge .
Parsing [sent. 5158 len. 15]: O the long , long night , with the moans of the poor wife !
Parsing [sent. 5159 len. 18]: And O the long , long night , with no return of her father and no tidings !

Parsing [sent. 5162 len. 5]: cried Lucie , affrighted .
Parsing [sent. 5163 len. 3]: `` Hush !

Parsing [sent. 5165 len. 20]: `` The place is national property now , and used as a kind of armoury , my love . ''
Parsing [sent. 5166 len. 17]: Twice more in all ; but , the last spell of work was feeble and fitful .
Parsing [sent. 5167 len. 24]: Soon afterwards the day began to dawn , and he softly detached himself from the clasping hand , and cautiously looked out again .
Parsing [sent. 5168 len. 45]: A man , so besmeared that he might have been a sorely wounded soldier creeping back to consciousness on a field of slain , was rising from the pavement by the side of the grindstone , and looking about him with a vacant air .
Parsing [sent. 5169 len. 44]: Shortly , this worn-out murderer descried in the imperfect light one of the carriages of Monseigneur , and , staggering to that gorgeous vehicle , climbed in at the door , and shut himself up to take his rest on its dainty cushions .

Parsing [sent. 5171 len. 32]: But , the lesser grindstone stood alone there in the calm morning air , with a red upon it that the sun had never given , and would never take away .
Parsing [sent. 5172 len. 98]: III The Shadow One of the first considerations which arose in the business mind of Mr. Lorry when business hours came round , was this : -- that he had no right to imperil Tellson 's by sheltering the wife of an emigrant prisoner under the Bank roof , His own possessions , safety , life , he would have hazarded for Lucie and her child , without a moment 's demur ; but the great trust he held was not his own , and as to that business charge he was a strict man of business .
Parsing [sent. 5173 len. 38]: At first , his mind reverted to Defarge , and he thought of finding out the wine-shop again and taking counsel with its master in reference to the safest dwelling-place in the distracted state of the city .
Parsing [sent. 5174 len. 33]: But , the same consideration that suggested him , repudiated him ; he lived in the most violent Quarter , and doubtless was influential there , and deep in its dangerous workings .
Parsing [sent. 5175 len. 26]: Noon coming , and the Doctor not returning , and every minute 's delay tending to compromise Tellson 's , Mr. Lorry advised with Lucie .
Parsing [sent. 5176 len. 24]: She said that her father had spoken of hiring a lodging for a short term , in that Quarter , near the Banking-house .
Parsing [sent. 5177 len. 82]: As there was no business objection to this , and as he foresaw that even if it were all well with Charles , and he were to be released , he could not hope to leave the city , Mr. Lorry went out in quest of such a lodging , and found a suitable one , high up in a removed by-street where the closed blinds in all the other windows of a high melancholy square of buildings marked deserted homes .
Parsing [sent. 5178 len. 31]: To this lodging he at once removed Lucie and her child , and Miss Pross : giving them what comfort he could , and much more than he had himself .
Parsing [sent. 5179 len. 29]: He left Jerry with them , as a figure to fill a doorway that would bear considerable knocking on the head , and retained to his own occupations .
Parsing [sent. 5180 len. 23]: A disturbed and doleful mind he brought to bear upon them , and slowly and heavily the day lagged on with him .
Parsing [sent. 5181 len. 17]: It wore itself out , and wore him out with it , until the Bank closed .
Parsing [sent. 5182 len. 27]: He was again alone in his room of the previous night , considering what to do next , when he heard a foot upon the stair .
Parsing [sent. 5183 len. 28]: In a few moments , a man stood in his presence , who , with a keenly observant look at him , addressed him by his name .
Parsing [sent. 5184 len. 9]: `` Your servant , '' said Mr. Lorry .
Parsing [sent. 5185 len. 7]: `` Do you know me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5186 len. 19]: He was a strongly made man with dark curling hair , from forty-five to fifty years of age .
Parsing [sent. 5187 len. 21]: For answer he repeated , without any change of emphasis , the words : `` Do you know me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5188 len. 8]: `` I have seen you somewhere . ''
Parsing [sent. 5189 len. 7]: `` Perhaps at my wine-shop ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5190 len. 17]: Much interested and agitated , Mr. Lorry said : `` You come from Doctor Manette ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5191 len. 3]: `` Yes .
Parsing [sent. 5192 len. 7]: I come from Doctor Manette . ''
Parsing [sent. 5193 len. 6]: `` And what says he ?
Parsing [sent. 5194 len. 7]: What does he send me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5195 len. 13]: Defarge gave into his anxious hand , an open scrap of paper .
Parsing [sent. 5196 len. 25]: It bore the words in the Doctor 's writing : `` Charles is safe , but I can not safely leave this place yet .
Parsing [sent. 5197 len. 18]: I have obtained the favour that the bearer has a short note from Charles to his wife .
Parsing [sent. 5198 len. 8]: Let the bearer see his wife . ''
Parsing [sent. 5199 len. 11]: It was dated from La Force , within an hour .
Parsing [sent. 5200 len. 27]: `` Will you accompany me , '' said Mr. Lorry , joyfully relieved after reading this note aloud , `` to where his wife resides ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5201 len. 7]: `` Yes , '' returned Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 5202 len. 30]: Scarcely noticing as yet , in what a curiously reserved and mechanical way Defarge spoke , Mr. Lorry put on his hat and they went down into the courtyard .
Parsing [sent. 5203 len. 11]: There , they found two women ; one , knitting .
Parsing [sent. 5204 len. 7]: `` Madame Defarge , surely ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5205 len. 18]: said Mr. Lorry , who had left her in exactly the same attitude some seventeen years ago .
Parsing [sent. 5206 len. 10]: `` It is she , '' observed her husband .
Parsing [sent. 5207 len. 8]: `` Does Madame go with us ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5208 len. 12]: inquired Mr. Lorry , seeing that she moved as they moved .
Parsing [sent. 5209 len. 3]: `` Yes .
Parsing [sent. 5210 len. 14]: That she may be able to recognise the faces and know the persons .
Parsing [sent. 5211 len. 7]: It is for their safety . ''
Parsing [sent. 5212 len. 21]: Beginning to be struck by Defarge 's manner , Mr. Lorry looked dubiously at him , and led the way .
Parsing [sent. 5213 len. 12]: Both the women followed ; the second woman being The Vengeance .
Parsing [sent. 5214 len. 32]: They passed through the intervening streets as quickly as they might , ascended the staircase of the new domicile , were admitted by Jerry , and found Lucie weeping , alone .
Parsing [sent. 5215 len. 52]: She was thrown into a transport by the tidings Mr. Lorry gave her of her husband , and clasped the hand that delivered his note -- little thinking what it had been doing near him in the night , and might , but for a chance , have done to him .
Parsing [sent. 5216 len. 7]: `` DEAREST , -- Take courage .
Parsing [sent. 5217 len. 12]: I am well , and your father has influence around me .
Parsing [sent. 5218 len. 6]: You can not answer this .
Parsing [sent. 5219 len. 7]: Kiss our child for me . ''
Parsing [sent. 5220 len. 6]: That was all the writing .
Parsing [sent. 5221 len. 31]: It was so much , however , to her who received it , that she turned from Defarge to his wife , and kissed one of the hands that knitted .
Parsing [sent. 5222 len. 31]: It was a passionate , loving , thankful , womanly action , but the hand made no response -- dropped cold and heavy , and took to its knitting again .
Parsing [sent. 5223 len. 12]: There was something in its touch that gave Lucie a check .
Parsing [sent. 5224 len. 29]: She stopped in the act of putting the note in her bosom , and , with her hands yet at her neck , looked terrified at Madame Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 5225 len. 15]: Madame Defarge met the lifted eyebrows and forehead with a cold , impassive stare .
Parsing [sent. 5226 len. 68]: `` My dear , '' said Mr. Lorry , striking in to explain ; `` there are frequent risings in the streets ; and , although it is not likely they will ever trouble you , Madame Defarge wishes to see those whom she has the power to protect at such times , to the end that she may know them -- that she may identify them .
Parsing [sent. 5227 len. 41]: I believe , '' said Mr. Lorry , rather halting in his reassuring words , as the stony manner of all the three impressed itself upon him more and more , `` I state the case , Citizen Defarge ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5228 len. 19]: Defarge looked gloomily at his wife , and gave no other answer than a gruff sound of acquiescence .
Parsing [sent. 5229 len. 36]: `` You had better , Lucie , '' said Mr. Lorry , doing all he could to propitiate , by tone and manner , `` have the dear child here , and our good Pross .
Parsing [sent. 5230 len. 17]: Our good Pross , Defarge , is an English lady , and knows no French . ''
Parsing [sent. 5231 len. 58]: The lady in question , whose rooted conviction that she was more than a match for any foreigner , was not to be shaken by distress and , danger , appeared with folded arms , and observed in English to The Vengeance , whom her eyes first encountered , `` Well , I am sure , Boldface !
Parsing [sent. 5232 len. 8]: I hope YOU are pretty well ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5233 len. 22]: She also bestowed a British cough on Madame Defarge ; but , neither of the two took much heed of her .
Parsing [sent. 5234 len. 7]: `` Is that his child ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5235 len. 29]: said Madame Defarge , stopping in her work for the first time , and pointing her knitting-needle at little Lucie as if it were the finger of Fate .
Parsing [sent. 5236 len. 25]: `` Yes , madame , '' answered Mr. Lorry ; `` this is our poor prisoner 's darling daughter , and only child . ''
Parsing [sent. 5237 len. 38]: The shadow attendant on Madame Defarge and her party seemed to fall so threatening and dark on the child , that her mother instinctively kneeled on the ground beside her , and held her to her breast .
Parsing [sent. 5238 len. 26]: The shadow attendant on Madame Defarge and her party seemed then to fall , threatening and dark , on both the mother and the child .
Parsing [sent. 5239 len. 13]: `` It is enough , my husband , '' said Madame Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 5240 len. 6]: `` I have seen them .
Parsing [sent. 5241 len. 5]: We may go . ''
Parsing [sent. 5242 len. 50]: But , the suppressed manner had enough of menace in it -- not visible and presented , but indistinct and withheld -- to alarm Lucie into saying , as she laid her appealing hand on Madame Defarge 's dress : `` You will be good to my poor husband .
Parsing [sent. 5243 len. 7]: You will do him no harm .
Parsing [sent. 5244 len. 12]: You will help me to see him if you can ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5245 len. 22]: `` Your husband is not my business here , '' returned Madame Defarge , looking down at her with perfect composure .
Parsing [sent. 5246 len. 15]: `` It is the daughter of your father who is my business here . ''
Parsing [sent. 5247 len. 13]: `` For my sake , then , be merciful to my husband .
Parsing [sent. 5248 len. 6]: For my child 's sake !
Parsing [sent. 5249 len. 13]: She will put her hands together and pray you to be merciful .
Parsing [sent. 5250 len. 12]: We are more afraid of you than of these others . ''
Parsing [sent. 5251 len. 14]: Madame Defarge received it as a compliment , and looked at her husband .
Parsing [sent. 5252 len. 22]: Defarge , who had been uneasily biting his thumb-nail and looking at her , collected his face into a sterner expression .
Parsing [sent. 5253 len. 14]: `` What is it that your husband says in that little letter ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5254 len. 9]: asked Madame Defarge , with a lowering smile .
Parsing [sent. 5255 len. 10]: `` Influence ; he says something touching influence ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5256 len. 38]: `` That my father , '' said Lucie , hurriedly taking the paper from her breast , but with her alarmed eyes on her questioner and not on it , `` has much influence around him . ''
Parsing [sent. 5257 len. 8]: `` Surely it will release him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5258 len. 4]: said Madame Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 5259 len. 7]: `` Let it do so . ''
Parsing [sent. 5260 len. 46]: `` As a wife and mother , '' cried Lucie , most earnestly , `` I implore you to have pity on me and not to exercise any power that you possess , against my innocent husband , but to use it in his behalf .
Parsing [sent. 5261 len. 7]: O sister-woman , think of me .
Parsing [sent. 5262 len. 7]: As a wife and mother ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5263 len. 53]: Madame Defarge looked , coldly as ever , at the suppliant , and said , turning to her friend The Vengeance : `` The wives and mothers we have been used to see , since we were as little as this child , and much less , have not been greatly considered ?
Parsing [sent. 5264 len. 18]: We have known THEIR husbands and fathers laid in prison and kept from them , often enough ?
Parsing [sent. 5265 len. 38]: All our lives , we have seen our sister-women suffer , in themselves and in their children , poverty , nakedness , hunger , thirst , sickness , misery , oppression and neglect of all kinds ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5266 len. 12]: `` We have seen nothing else , '' returned The Vengeance .
Parsing [sent. 5267 len. 21]: `` We have borne this a long time , '' said Madame Defarge , turning her eyes again upon Lucie .
Parsing [sent. 5268 len. 4]: `` Judge you !
Parsing [sent. 5269 len. 19]: Is it likely that the trouble of one wife and mother would be much to us now ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5270 len. 8]: She resumed her knitting and went out .
Parsing [sent. 5271 len. 4]: The Vengeance followed .
Parsing [sent. 5272 len. 9]: Defarge went last , and closed the door .
Parsing [sent. 5273 len. 17]: `` Courage , my dear Lucie , '' said Mr. Lorry , as he raised her .
Parsing [sent. 5274 len. 5]: `` Courage , courage !
Parsing [sent. 5275 len. 23]: So far all goes well with us -- much , much better than it has of late gone with many poor souls .
Parsing [sent. 5276 len. 10]: Cheer up , and have a thankful heart . ''
Parsing [sent. 5277 len. 27]: `` I am not thankless , I hope , but that dreadful woman seems to throw a shadow on me and on all my hopes . ''
Parsing [sent. 5278 len. 6]: `` Tut , tut ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5279 len. 15]: said Mr. Lorry ; `` what is this despondency in the brave little breast ?
Parsing [sent. 5280 len. 4]: A shadow indeed !
Parsing [sent. 5281 len. 8]: No substance in it , Lucie . ''
Parsing [sent. 5282 len. 28]: But the shadow of the manner of these Defarges was dark upon himself , for all that , and in his secret mind it troubled him greatly .
Parsing [sent. 5283 len. 20]: IV Calm in Storm Doctor Manette did not return until the morning of the fourth day of his absence .
Parsing [sent. 5284 len. 88]: So much of what had happened in that dreadful time as could be kept from the knowledge of Lucie was so well concealed from her , that not until long afterwards , when France and she were far apart , did she know that eleven hundred defenceless prisoners of both sexes and all ages had been killed by the populace ; that four days and nights had been darkened by this deed of horror ; and that the air around her had been tainted by the slain .
Parsing [sent. 5285 len. 35]: She only knew that there had been an attack upon the prisons , that all political prisoners had been in danger , and that some had been dragged out by the crowd and murdered .
Parsing [sent. 5286 len. 39]: To Mr. Lorry , the Doctor communicated under an injunction of secrecy on which he had no need to dwell , that the crowd had taken him through a scene of carnage to the prison of La Force .
Parsing [sent. 5287 len. 56]: That , in the prison he had found a self-appointed Tribunal sitting , before which the prisoners were brought singly , and by which they were rapidly ordered to be put forth to be massacred , or to be released , or -LRB- in a few cases -RRB- to be sent back to their cells .
Parsing [sent. 5288 len. 56]: That , presented by his conductors to this Tribunal , he had announced himself by name and profession as having been for eighteen years a secret and unaccused prisoner in the Bastille ; that , one of the body so sitting in judgment had risen and identified him , and that this man was Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 5289 len. 61]: That , hereupon he had ascertained , through the registers on the table , that his son-in-law was among the living prisoners , and had pleaded hard to the Tribunal -- of whom some members were asleep and some awake , some dirty with murder and some clean , some sober and some not -- for his life and liberty .
Parsing [sent. 5290 len. 38]: That , in the first frantic greetings lavished on himself as a notable sufferer under the overthrown system , it had been accorded to him to have Charles Darnay brought before the lawless Court , and examined .
Parsing [sent. 5291 len. 42]: That , he seemed on the point of being at once released , when the tide in his favour met with some unexplained check -LRB- not intelligible to the Doctor -RRB- , which led to a few words of secret conference .
Parsing [sent. 5292 len. 34]: That , the man sitting as President had then informed Doctor Manette that the prisoner must remain in custody , but should , for his sake , be held inviolate in safe custody .
Parsing [sent. 5293 len. 88]: That , immediately , on a signal , the prisoner was removed to the interior of the prison again ; but , that he , the Doctor , had then so strongly pleaded for permission to remain and assure himself that his son-in-law was , through no malice or mischance , delivered to the concourse whose murderous yells outside the gate had often drowned the proceedings , that he had obtained the permission , and had remained in that Hall of Blood until the danger was over .
Parsing [sent. 5294 len. 21]: The sights he had seen there , with brief snatches of food and sleep by intervals , shall remain untold .
Parsing [sent. 5295 len. 27]: The mad joy over the prisoners who were saved , had astounded him scarcely less than the mad ferocity against those who were cut to pieces .
Parsing [sent. 5296 len. 32]: One prisoner there was , he said , who had been discharged into the street free , but at whom a mistaken savage had thrust a pike as he passed out .
Parsing [sent. 5297 len. 44]: Being besought to go to him and dress the wound , the Doctor had passed out at the same gate , and had found him in the arms of a company of Samaritans , who were seated on the bodies of their victims .
Parsing [sent. 5298 len. 77]: With an inconsistency as monstrous as anything in this awful nightmare , they had helped the healer , and tended the wounded man with the gentlest solicitude -- had made a litter for him and escorted him carefully from the spot -- had then caught up their weapons and plunged anew into a butchery so dreadful , that the Doctor had covered his eyes with his hands , and swooned away in the midst of it .
Parsing [sent. 5299 len. 37]: As Mr. Lorry received these confidences , and as he watched the face of his friend now sixty-two years of age , a misgiving arose within him that such dread experiences would revive the old danger .
Parsing [sent. 5300 len. 25]: But , he had never seen his friend in his present aspect : he had never at all known him in his present character .
Parsing [sent. 5301 len. 18]: For the first time the Doctor felt , now , that his suffering was strength and power .
Parsing [sent. 5302 len. 34]: For the first time he felt that in that sharp fire , he had slowly forged the iron which could break the prison door of his daughter 's husband , and deliver him .
Parsing [sent. 5303 len. 20]: `` It all tended to a good end , my friend ; it was not mere waste and ruin .
Parsing [sent. 5304 len. 38]: As my beloved child was helpful in restoring me to myself , I will be helpful now in restoring the dearest part of herself to her ; by the aid of Heaven I will do it ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5305 len. 5]: Thus , Doctor Manette .
Parsing [sent. 5306 len. 64]: And when Jarvis Lorry saw the kindled eyes , the resolute face , the calm strong look and bearing of the man whose life always seemed to him to have been stopped , like a clock , for so many years , and then set going again with an energy which had lain dormant during the cessation of its usefulness , he believed .
Parsing [sent. 5307 len. 21]: Greater things than the Doctor had at that time to contend with , would have yielded before his persevering purpose .
Parsing [sent. 5308 len. 59]: While he kept himself in his place , as a physician , whose business was with all degrees of mankind , bond and free , rich and poor , bad and good , he used his personal influence so wisely , that he was soon the inspecting physician of three prisons , and among them of La Force .
Parsing [sent. 5309 len. 103]: He could now assure Lucie that her husband was no longer confined alone , but was mixed with the general body of prisoners ; he saw her husband weekly , and brought sweet messages to her , straight from his lips ; sometimes her husband himself sent a letter to her -LRB- though never by the Doctor 's hand -RRB- , but she was not permitted to write to him : for , among the many wild suspicions of plots in the prisons , the wildest of all pointed at emigrants who were known to have made friends or permanent connections abroad .
Parsing [sent. 5310 len. 32]: This new life of the Doctor 's was an anxious life , no doubt ; still , the sagacious Mr. Lorry saw that there was a new sustaining pride in it .
Parsing [sent. 5311 len. 22]: Nothing unbecoming tinged the pride ; it was a natural and worthy one ; but he observed it as a curiosity .
Parsing [sent. 5312 len. 35]: The Doctor knew , that up to that time , his imprisonment had been associated in the minds of his daughter and his friend , with his personal affliction , deprivation , and weakness .
Parsing [sent. 5313 len. 64]: Now that this was changed , and he knew himself to be invested through that old trial with forces to which they both looked for Charles 's ultimate safety and deliverance , he became so far exalted by the change , that he took the lead and direction , and required them as the weak , to trust to him as the strong .
Parsing [sent. 5314 len. 45]: The preceding relative positions of himself and Lucie were reversed , yet only as the liveliest gratitude and affection could reverse them , for he could have had no pride but in rendering some service to her who had rendered so much to him .
Parsing [sent. 5315 len. 47]: `` All curious to see , '' thought Mr. Lorry , in his amiably shrewd way , `` but all natural and right ; so , take the lead , my dear friend , and keep it ; it could n't be in better hands . ''
Parsing [sent. 5316 len. 45]: But , though the Doctor tried hard , and never ceased trying , to get Charles Darnay set at liberty , or at least to get him brought to trial , the public current of the time set too strong and fast for him .
Parsing [sent. 5317 len. 163]: The new era began ; the king was tried , doomed , and beheaded ; the Republic of Liberty , Equality , Fraternity , or Death , declared for victory or death against the world in arms ; the black flag waved night and day from the great towers of Notre Dame ; three hundred thousand men , summoned to rise against the tyrants of the earth , rose from all the varying soils of France , as if the dragon 's teeth had been sown broadcast , and had yielded fruit equally on hill and plain , on rock , in gravel , and alluvial mud , under the bright sky of the South and under the clouds of the North , in fell and forest , in the vineyards and the olive-grounds and among the cropped grass and the stubble of the corn , along the fruitful banks of the broad rivers , and in the sand of the sea-shore .
Parsing [sent. 5318 len. 38]: What private solicitude could rear itself against the deluge of the Year One of Liberty -- the deluge rising from below , not falling from above , and with the windows of Heaven shut , not opened !
Parsing [sent. 5319 len. 22]: There was no pause , no pity , no peace , no interval of relenting rest , no measurement of time .
Parsing [sent. 5320 len. 31]: Though days and nights circled as regularly as when time was young , and the evening and morning were the first day , other count of time there was none .
Parsing [sent. 5321 len. 23]: Hold of it was lost in the raging fever of a nation , as it is in the fever of one patient .
Parsing [sent. 5322 len. 56]: Now , breaking the unnatural silence of a whole city , the executioner showed the people the head of the king -- and now , it seemed almost in the same breath , the head of his fair wife which had had eight weary months of imprisoned widowhood and misery , to turn it grey .
Parsing [sent. 5323 len. 28]: And yet , observing the strange law of contradiction which obtains in all such cases , the time was long , while it flamed by so fast .
Parsing [sent. 5324 len. 91]: A revolutionary tribunal in the capital , and forty or fifty thousand revolutionary committees all over the land ; a law of the Suspected , which struck away all security for liberty or life , and delivered over any good and innocent person to any bad and guilty one ; prisons gorged with people who had committed no offence , and could obtain no hearing ; these things became the established order and nature of appointed things , and seemed to be ancient usage before they were many weeks old .
Parsing [sent. 5325 len. 35]: Above all , one hideous figure grew as familiar as if it had been before the general gaze from the foundations of the world -- the figure of the sharp female called La Guillotine .
Parsing [sent. 5326 len. 59]: It was the popular theme for jests ; it was the best cure for headache , it infallibly prevented the hair from turning grey , it imparted a peculiar delicacy to the complexion , it was the National Razor which shaved close : who kissed La Guillotine , looked through the little window and sneezed into the sack .
Parsing [sent. 5327 len. 12]: It was the sign of the regeneration of the human race .
Parsing [sent. 5328 len. 5]: It superseded the Cross .
Parsing [sent. 5329 len. 29]: Models of it were worn on breasts from which the Cross was discarded , and it was bowed down to and believed in where the Cross was denied .
Parsing [sent. 5330 len. 22]: It sheared off heads so many , that it , and the ground it most polluted , were a rotten red .
Parsing [sent. 5331 len. 25]: It was taken to pieces , like a toy-puzzle for a young Devil , and was put together again when the occasion wanted it .
Parsing [sent. 5332 len. 16]: It hushed the eloquent , struck down the powerful , abolished the beautiful and good .
Parsing [sent. 5333 len. 29]: Twenty-two friends of high public mark , twenty-one living and one dead , it had lopped the heads off , in one morning , in as many minutes .
Parsing [sent. 5334 len. 47]: The name of the strong man of Old Scripture had descended to the chief functionary who worked it ; but , so armed , he was stronger than his namesake , and blinder , and tore away the gates of God 's own Temple every day .
Parsing [sent. 5335 len. 42]: Among these terrors , and the brood belonging to them , the Doctor walked with a steady head : confident in his power , cautiously persistent in his end , never doubting that he would save Lucie 's husband at last .
Parsing [sent. 5336 len. 42]: Yet the current of the time swept by , so strong and deep , and carried the time away so fiercely , that Charles had lain in prison one year and three months when the Doctor was thus steady and confident .
Parsing [sent. 5337 len. 47]: So much more wicked and distracted had the Revolution grown in that December month , that the rivers of the South were encumbered with the bodies of the violently drowned by night , and prisoners were shot in lines and squares under the southern wintry sun .
Parsing [sent. 5338 len. 13]: Still , the Doctor walked among the terrors with a steady head .
Parsing [sent. 5339 len. 20]: No man better known than he , in Paris at that day ; no man in a stranger situation .
Parsing [sent. 5340 len. 25]: Silent , humane , indispensable in hospital and prison , using his art equally among assassins and victims , he was a man apart .
Parsing [sent. 5341 len. 23]: In the exercise of his skill , the appearance and the story of the Bastille Captive removed him from all other men .
Parsing [sent. 5342 len. 33]: He was not suspected or brought in question , any more than if he had indeed been recalled to life some eighteen years before , or were a Spirit moving among mortals .
Parsing [sent. 5343 len. 11]: V The Wood -- Sawyer One year and three months .
Parsing [sent. 5344 len. 28]: During all that time Lucie was never sure , from hour to hour , but that the Guillotine would strike off her husband 's head next day .
Parsing [sent. 5345 len. 18]: Every day , through the stony streets , the tumbrils now jolted heavily , filled with Condemned .
Parsing [sent. 5346 len. 60]: Lovely girls ; bright women , brown-haired , black-haired , and grey ; youths ; stalwart men and old ; gentle born and peasant born ; all red wine for La Guillotine , all daily brought into light from the dark cellars of the loathsome prisons , and carried to her through the streets to slake her devouring thirst .
Parsing [sent. 5347 len. 22]: Liberty , equality , fraternity , or death ; -- the last , much the easiest to bestow , O Guillotine !
Parsing [sent. 5348 len. 42]: If the suddenness of her calamity , and the whirling wheels of the time , had stunned the Doctor 's daughter into awaiting the result in idle despair , it would but have been with her as it was with many .
Parsing [sent. 5349 len. 32]: But , from the hour when she had taken the white head to her fresh young bosom in the garret of Saint Antoine , she had been true to her duties .
Parsing [sent. 5350 len. 22]: She was truest to them in the season of trial , as all the quietly loyal and good will always be .
Parsing [sent. 5351 len. 38]: As soon as they were established in their new residence , and her father had entered on the routine of his avocations , she arranged the little household as exactly as if her husband had been there .
Parsing [sent. 5352 len. 10]: Everything had its appointed place and its appointed time .
Parsing [sent. 5353 len. 20]: Little Lucie she taught , as regularly , as if they had all been united in their English home .
Parsing [sent. 5354 len. 77]: The slight devices with which she cheated herself into the show of a belief that they would soon be reunited -- the little preparations for his speedy return , the setting aside of his chair and his books -- these , and the solemn prayer at night for one dear prisoner especially , among the many unhappy souls in prison and the shadow of death -- were almost the only outspoken reliefs of her heavy mind .
Parsing [sent. 5355 len. 8]: She did not greatly alter in appearance .
Parsing [sent. 5356 len. 33]: The plain dark dresses , akin to mourning dresses , which she and her child wore , were as neat and as well attended to as the brighter clothes of happy days .
Parsing [sent. 5357 len. 30]: She lost her colour , and the old and intent expression was a constant , not an occasional , thing ; otherwise , she remained very pretty and comely .
Parsing [sent. 5358 len. 36]: Sometimes , at night on kissing her father , she would burst into the grief she had repressed all day , and would say that her sole reliance , under Heaven , was on him .
Parsing [sent. 5359 len. 27]: He always resolutely answered : `` Nothing can happen to him without my knowledge , and I know that I can save him , Lucie . ''
Parsing [sent. 5360 len. 52]: They had not made the round of their changed life many weeks , when her father said to her , on coming home one evening : `` My dear , there is an upper window in the prison , to which Charles can sometimes gain access at three in the afternoon .
Parsing [sent. 5361 len. 39]: When he can get to it -- which depends on many uncertainties and incidents -- he might see you in the street , he thinks , if you stood in a certain place that I can show you .
Parsing [sent. 5362 len. 34]: But you will not be able to see him , my poor child , and even if you could , it would be unsafe for you to make a sign of recognition . ''
Parsing [sent. 5363 len. 19]: `` O show me the place , my father , and I will go there every day . ''
Parsing [sent. 5364 len. 14]: From that time , in all weathers , she waited there two hours .
Parsing [sent. 5365 len. 18]: As the clock struck two , she was there , and at four she turned resignedly away .
Parsing [sent. 5366 len. 36]: When it was not too wet or inclement for her child to be with her , they went together ; at other times she was alone ; but , she never missed a single day .
Parsing [sent. 5367 len. 13]: It was the dark and dirty corner of a small winding street .
Parsing [sent. 5368 len. 25]: The hovel of a cutter of wood into lengths for burning , was the only house at that end ; all else was wall .
Parsing [sent. 5369 len. 13]: On the third day of her being there , he noticed her .
Parsing [sent. 5370 len. 7]: `` Good day , citizeness . ''
Parsing [sent. 5371 len. 7]: `` Good day , citizen . ''
Parsing [sent. 5372 len. 10]: This mode of address was now prescribed by decree .
Parsing [sent. 5373 len. 23]: It had been established voluntarily some time ago , among the more thorough patriots ; but , was now law for everybody .
Parsing [sent. 5374 len. 8]: `` Walking here again , citizeness ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5375 len. 8]: `` You see me , citizen ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5376 len. 53]: The wood-sawyer , who was a little man with a redundancy of gesture -LRB- he had once been a mender of roads -RRB- , cast a glance at the prison , pointed at the prison , and putting his ten fingers before his face to represent bars , peeped through them jocosely .
Parsing [sent. 5377 len. 12]: `` But it 's not my business , '' said he .
Parsing [sent. 5378 len. 7]: And went on sawing his wood .
Parsing [sent. 5379 len. 17]: Next day he was looking out for her , and accosted her the moment she appeared .
Parsing [sent. 5380 len. 3]: `` What ?
Parsing [sent. 5381 len. 7]: Walking here again , citizeness ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5382 len. 6]: `` Yes , citizen . ''
Parsing [sent. 5383 len. 3]: `` Ah !
Parsing [sent. 5384 len. 4]: A child too !
Parsing [sent. 5385 len. 12]: Your mother , is it not , my little citizeness ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5386 len. 9]: `` Do I say yes , mamma ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5387 len. 9]: whispered little Lucie , drawing close to her .
Parsing [sent. 5388 len. 6]: `` Yes , dearest . ''
Parsing [sent. 5389 len. 6]: `` Yes , citizen . ''
Parsing [sent. 5390 len. 3]: `` Ah !
Parsing [sent. 5391 len. 7]: But it 's not my business .
Parsing [sent. 5392 len. 6]: My work is my business .
Parsing [sent. 5393 len. 4]: See my saw !
Parsing [sent. 5394 len. 7]: I call it my Little Guillotine .
Parsing [sent. 5395 len. 12]: La , la , la ; La , la , la !
Parsing [sent. 5396 len. 7]: And off his head comes ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5397 len. 15]: The billet fell as he spoke , and he threw it into a basket .
Parsing [sent. 5398 len. 11]: `` I call myself the Samson of the firewood guillotine .
Parsing [sent. 5399 len. 4]: See here again !
Parsing [sent. 5400 len. 12]: Loo , loo , loo ; Loo , loo , loo !
Parsing [sent. 5401 len. 6]: And off HER head comes !
Parsing [sent. 5402 len. 5]: Now , a child .
Parsing [sent. 5403 len. 8]: Tickle , tickle ; Pickle , pickle !
Parsing [sent. 5404 len. 6]: And off ITS head comes .
Parsing [sent. 5405 len. 5]: All the family ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5406 len. 33]: Lucie shuddered as he threw two more billets into his basket , but it was impossible to be there while the wood-sawyer was at work , and not be in his sight .
Parsing [sent. 5407 len. 26]: Thenceforth , to secure his good will , she always spoke to him first , and often gave him drink-money , which he readily received .
Parsing [sent. 5408 len. 59]: He was an inquisitive fellow , and sometimes when she had quite forgotten him in gazing at the prison roof and grates , and in lifting her heart up to her husband , she would come to herself to find him looking at her , with his knee on his bench and his saw stopped in its work .
Parsing [sent. 5409 len. 9]: `` But it 's not my business ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5410 len. 17]: he would generally say at those times , and would briskly fall to his sawing again .
Parsing [sent. 5411 len. 66]: In all weathers , in the snow and frost of winter , in the bitter winds of spring , in the hot sunshine of summer , in the rains of autumn , and again in the snow and frost of winter , Lucie passed two hours of every day at this place ; and every day on leaving it , she kissed the prison wall .
Parsing [sent. 5412 len. 43]: Her husband saw her -LRB- so she learned from her father -RRB- it might be once in five or six times : it might be twice or thrice running : it might be , not for a week or a fortnight together .
Parsing [sent. 5413 len. 32]: It was enough that he could and did see her when the chances served , and on that possibility she would have waited out the day , seven days a week .
Parsing [sent. 5414 len. 22]: These occupations brought her round to the December month , wherein her father walked among the terrors with a steady head .
Parsing [sent. 5415 len. 11]: On a lightly-snowing afternoon she arrived at the usual corner .
Parsing [sent. 5416 len. 13]: It was a day of some wild rejoicing , and a festival .
Parsing [sent. 5417 len. 50]: She had seen the houses , as she came along , decorated with little pikes , and with little red caps stuck upon them ; also , with tricoloured ribbons ; also , with the standard inscription -LRB- tricoloured letters were the favourite -RRB- , Republic One and Indivisible .
Parsing [sent. 5418 len. 9]: Liberty , Equality , Fraternity , or Death !
Parsing [sent. 5419 len. 22]: The miserable shop of the wood-sawyer was so small , that its whole surface furnished very indifferent space for this legend .
Parsing [sent. 5420 len. 23]: He had got somebody to scrawl it up for him , however , who had squeezed Death in with most inappropriate difficulty .
Parsing [sent. 5421 len. 46]: On his house-top , he displayed pike and cap , as a good citizen must , and in a window he had stationed his saw inscribed as his `` Little Sainte Guillotine '' -- for the great sharp female was by that time popularly canonised .
Parsing [sent. 5422 len. 23]: His shop was shut and he was not there , which was a relief to Lucie , and left her quite alone .
Parsing [sent. 5423 len. 27]: But , he was not far off , for presently she heard a troubled movement and a shouting coming along , which filled her with fear .
Parsing [sent. 5424 len. 34]: A moment afterwards , and a throng of people came pouring round the corner by the prison wall , in the midst of whom was the wood-sawyer hand in hand with The Vengeance .
Parsing [sent. 5425 len. 19]: There could not be fewer than five hundred people , and they were dancing like five thousand demons .
Parsing [sent. 5426 len. 10]: There was no other music than their own singing .
Parsing [sent. 5427 len. 22]: They danced to the popular Revolution song , keeping a ferocious time that was like a gnashing of teeth in unison .
Parsing [sent. 5428 len. 21]: Men and women danced together , women danced together , men danced together , as hazard had brought them together .
Parsing [sent. 5429 len. 45]: At first , they were a mere storm of coarse red caps and coarse woollen rags ; but , as they filled the place , and stopped to dance about Lucie , some ghastly apparition of a dance-figure gone raving mad arose among them .
Parsing [sent. 5430 len. 38]: They advanced , retreated , struck at one another 's hands , clutched at one another 's heads , spun round alone , caught one another and spun round in pairs , until many of them dropped .
Parsing [sent. 5431 len. 65]: While those were down , the rest linked hand in hand , and all spun round together : then the ring broke , and in separate rings of two and four they turned and turned until they all stopped at once , began again , struck , clutched , and tore , and then reversed the spin , and all spun round another way .
Parsing [sent. 5432 len. 40]: Suddenly they stopped again , paused , struck out the time afresh , formed into lines the width of the public way , and , with their heads low down and their hands high up , swooped screaming off .
Parsing [sent. 5433 len. 12]: No fight could have been half so terrible as this dance .
Parsing [sent. 5434 len. 41]: It was so emphatically a fallen sport -- a something , once innocent , delivered over to all devilry -- a healthy pastime changed into a means of angering the blood , bewildering the senses , and steeling the heart .
Parsing [sent. 5435 len. 26]: Such grace as was visible in it , made it the uglier , showing how warped and perverted all things good by nature were become .
Parsing [sent. 5436 len. 34]: The maidenly bosom bared to this , the pretty almost-child 's head thus distracted , the delicate foot mincing in this slough of blood and dirt , were types of the disjointed time .
Parsing [sent. 5437 len. 5]: This was the Carmagnole .
Parsing [sent. 5438 len. 38]: As it passed , leaving Lucie frightened and bewildered in the doorway of the wood-sawyer 's house , the feathery snow fell as quietly and lay as white and soft , as if it had never been .
Parsing [sent. 5439 len. 6]: `` O my father ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5440 len. 28]: for he stood before her when she lifted up the eyes she had momentarily darkened with her hand ; `` such a cruel , bad sight . ''
Parsing [sent. 5441 len. 10]: `` I know , my dear , I know .
Parsing [sent. 5442 len. 7]: I have seen it many times .
Parsing [sent. 5443 len. 5]: Do n't be frightened !
Parsing [sent. 5444 len. 9]: Not one of them would harm you . ''
Parsing [sent. 5445 len. 11]: `` I am not frightened for myself , my father .
Parsing [sent. 5446 len. 27]: But when I think of my husband , and the mercies of these people -- '' `` We will set him above their mercies very soon .
Parsing [sent. 5447 len. 15]: I left him climbing to the window , and I came to tell you .
Parsing [sent. 5448 len. 8]: There is no one here to see .
Parsing [sent. 5449 len. 12]: You may kiss your hand towards that highest shelving roof . ''
Parsing [sent. 5450 len. 17]: `` I do so , father , and I send him my Soul with it ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5451 len. 12]: `` You can not see him , my poor dear ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5452 len. 22]: `` No , father , '' said Lucie , yearning and weeping as she kissed her hand , `` no . ''
Parsing [sent. 5453 len. 6]: A footstep in the snow .
Parsing [sent. 5454 len. 3]: Madame Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 5455 len. 12]: `` I salute you , citizeness , '' from the Doctor .
Parsing [sent. 5456 len. 8]: `` I salute you , citizen . ''
Parsing [sent. 5457 len. 4]: This in passing .
Parsing [sent. 5458 len. 3]: Nothing more .
Parsing [sent. 5459 len. 12]: Madame Defarge gone , like a shadow over the white road .
Parsing [sent. 5460 len. 9]: `` Give me your arm , my love .
Parsing [sent. 5461 len. 15]: Pass from here with an air of cheerfulness and courage , for his sake .
Parsing [sent. 5462 len. 20]: That was well done ; '' they had left the spot ; `` it shall not be in vain .

Parsing [sent. 5464 len. 5]: `` For to-morrow ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5465 len. 8]: `` There is no time to lose .
Parsing [sent. 5466 len. 27]: I am well prepared , but there are precautions to be taken , that could not be taken until he was actually summoned before the Tribunal .
Parsing [sent. 5467 len. 31]: He has not received the notice yet , but I know that he will presently be summoned for to-morrow , and removed to the Conciergerie ; I have timely information .
Parsing [sent. 5468 len. 6]: You are not afraid ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5469 len. 12]: She could scarcely answer , `` I trust in you . ''
Parsing [sent. 5470 len. 6]: `` Do so , implicitly .
Parsing [sent. 5471 len. 28]: Your suspense is nearly ended , my darling ; he shall be restored to you within a few hours ; I have encompassed him with every protection .
Parsing [sent. 5472 len. 6]: I must see Lorry . ''
Parsing [sent. 5473 len. 3]: He stopped .
Parsing [sent. 5474 len. 10]: There was a heavy lumbering of wheels within hearing .
Parsing [sent. 5475 len. 9]: They both knew too well what it meant .
Parsing [sent. 5476 len. 2]: One .
Parsing [sent. 5477 len. 2]: Two .
Parsing [sent. 5478 len. 2]: Three .
Parsing [sent. 5479 len. 13]: Three tumbrils faring away with their dread loads over the hushing snow .
Parsing [sent. 5480 len. 16]: `` I must see Lorry , '' the Doctor repeated , turning her another way .
Parsing [sent. 5481 len. 15]: The staunch old gentleman was still in his trust ; had never left it .
Parsing [sent. 5482 len. 16]: He and his books were in frequent requisition as to property confiscated and made national .
Parsing [sent. 5483 len. 11]: What he could save for the owners , he saved .
Parsing [sent. 5484 len. 21]: No better man living to hold fast by what Tellson 's had in keeping , and to hold his peace .
Parsing [sent. 5485 len. 21]: A murky red and yellow sky , and a rising mist from the Seine , denoted the approach of darkness .
Parsing [sent. 5486 len. 11]: It was almost dark when they arrived at the Bank .
Parsing [sent. 5487 len. 11]: The stately residence of Monseigneur was altogether blighted and deserted .
Parsing [sent. 5488 len. 18]: Above a heap of dust and ashes in the court , ran the letters : National Property .
Parsing [sent. 5489 len. 5]: Republic One and Indivisible .
Parsing [sent. 5490 len. 9]: Liberty , Equality , Fraternity , or Death !
Parsing [sent. 5491 len. 23]: Who could that be with Mr. Lorry -- the owner of the riding-coat upon the chair -- who must not be seen ?
Parsing [sent. 5492 len. 22]: From whom newly arrived , did he come out , agitated and surprised , to take his favourite in his arms ?
Parsing [sent. 5493 len. 47]: To whom did he appear to repeat her faltering words , when , raising his voice and turning his head towards the door of the room from which he had issued , he said : `` Removed to the Conciergerie , and summoned for to-morrow ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5494 len. 20]: VI Triumph The dread tribunal of five Judges , Public Prosecutor , and determined Jury , sat every day .
Parsing [sent. 5495 len. 22]: Their lists went forth every evening , and were read out by the gaolers of the various prisons to their prisoners .
Parsing [sent. 5496 len. 20]: The standard gaoler-joke was , `` Come out and listen to the Evening Paper , you inside there ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5497 len. 8]: `` Charles Evremonde , called Darnay ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5498 len. 11]: So at last began the Evening Paper at La Force .
Parsing [sent. 5499 len. 25]: When a name was called , its owner stepped apart into a spot reserved for those who were announced as being thus fatally recorded .
Parsing [sent. 5500 len. 21]: Charles Evremonde , called Darnay , had reason to know the usage ; he had seen hundreds pass away so .
Parsing [sent. 5501 len. 39]: His bloated gaoler , who wore spectacles to read with , glanced over them to assure himself that he had taken his place , and went through the list , making a similar short pause at each name .
Parsing [sent. 5502 len. 36]: There were twenty-three names , but only twenty were responded to ; for one of the prisoners so summoned had died in gaol and been forgotten , and two had already been guillotined and forgotten .
Parsing [sent. 5503 len. 23]: The list was read , in the vaulted chamber where Darnay had seen the associated prisoners on the night of his arrival .
Parsing [sent. 5504 len. 28]: Every one of those had perished in the massacre ; every human creature he had since cared for and parted with , had died on the scaffold .
Parsing [sent. 5505 len. 16]: There were hurried words of farewell and kindness , but the parting was soon over .
Parsing [sent. 5506 len. 33]: It was the incident of every day , and the society of La Force were engaged in the preparation of some games of forfeits and a little concert , for that evening .
Parsing [sent. 5507 len. 59]: They crowded to the grates and shed tears there ; but , twenty places in the projected entertainments had to be refilled , and the time was , at best , short to the lock-up hour , when the common rooms and corridors would be delivered over to the great dogs who kept watch there through the night .
Parsing [sent. 5508 len. 20]: The prisoners were far from insensible or unfeeling ; their ways arose out of the condition of the time .
Parsing [sent. 5509 len. 53]: Similarly , though with a subtle difference , a species of fervour or intoxication , known , without doubt , to have led some persons to brave the guillotine unnecessarily , and to die by it , was not mere boastfulness , but a wild infection of the wildly shaken public mind .
Parsing [sent. 5510 len. 26]: In seasons of pestilence , some of us will have a secret attraction to the disease -- a terrible passing inclination to die of it .
Parsing [sent. 5511 len. 19]: And all of us have like wonders hidden in our breasts , only needing circumstances to evoke them .
Parsing [sent. 5512 len. 21]: The passage to the Conciergerie was short and dark ; the night in its vermin-haunted cells was long and cold .
Parsing [sent. 5513 len. 18]: Next day , fifteen prisoners were put to the bar before Charles Darnay 's name was called .
Parsing [sent. 5514 len. 19]: All the fifteen were condemned , and the trials of the whole occupied an hour and a half .
Parsing [sent. 5515 len. 13]: `` Charles Evremonde , called Darnay , '' was at length arraigned .
Parsing [sent. 5516 len. 24]: His judges sat upon the Bench in feathered hats ; but the rough red cap and tricoloured cockade was the head-dress otherwise prevailing .
Parsing [sent. 5517 len. 32]: Looking at the Jury and the turbulent audience , he might have thought that the usual order of things was reversed , and that the felons were trying the honest men .
Parsing [sent. 5518 len. 50]: The lowest , cruelest , and worst populace of a city , never without its quantity of low , cruel , and bad , were the directing spirits of the scene : noisily commenting , applauding , disapproving , anticipating , and precipitating the result , without a check .
Parsing [sent. 5519 len. 36]: Of the men , the greater part were armed in various ways ; of the women , some wore knives , some daggers , some ate and drank as they looked on , many knitted .
Parsing [sent. 5520 len. 20]: Among these last , was one , with a spare piece of knitting under her arm as she worked .
Parsing [sent. 5521 len. 33]: She was in a front row , by the side of a man whom he had never seen since his arrival at the Barrier , but whom he directly remembered as Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 5522 len. 53]: He noticed that she once or twice whispered in his ear , and that she seemed to be his wife ; but , what he most noticed in the two figures was , that although they were posted as close to himself as they could be , they never looked towards him .
Parsing [sent. 5523 len. 24]: They seemed to be waiting for something with a dogged determination , and they looked at the Jury , but at nothing else .
Parsing [sent. 5524 len. 13]: Under the President sat Doctor Manette , in his usual quiet dress .
Parsing [sent. 5525 len. 40]: As well as the prisoner could see , he and Mr. Lorry were the only men there , unconnected with the Tribunal , who wore their usual clothes , and had not assumed the coarse garb of the Carmagnole .
Parsing [sent. 5526 len. 36]: Charles Evremonde , called Darnay , was accused by the public prosecutor as an emigrant , whose life was forfeit to the Republic , under the decree which banished all emigrants on pain of Death .
Parsing [sent. 5527 len. 14]: It was nothing that the decree bore date since his return to France .
Parsing [sent. 5528 len. 23]: There he was , and there was the decree ; he had been taken in France , and his head was demanded .
Parsing [sent. 5529 len. 7]: `` Take off his head ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5530 len. 4]: cried the audience .
Parsing [sent. 5531 len. 8]: `` An enemy to the Republic ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5532 len. 28]: The President rang his bell to silence those cries , and asked the prisoner whether it was not true that he had lived many years in England ?
Parsing [sent. 5533 len. 4]: Undoubtedly it was .
Parsing [sent. 5534 len. 7]: Was he not an emigrant then ?
Parsing [sent. 5535 len. 6]: What did he call himself ?
Parsing [sent. 5536 len. 16]: Not an emigrant , he hoped , within the sense and spirit of the law .
Parsing [sent. 5537 len. 3]: Why not ?
Parsing [sent. 5538 len. 6]: the President desired to know .
Parsing [sent. 5539 len. 66]: Because he had voluntarily relinquished a title that was distasteful to him , and a station that was distasteful to him , and had left his country -- he submitted before the word emigrant in the present acceptation by the Tribunal was in use -- to live by his own industry in England , rather than on the industry of the overladen people of France .
Parsing [sent. 5540 len. 7]: What proof had he of this ?
Parsing [sent. 5541 len. 16]: He handed in the names of two witnesses ; Theophile Gabelle , and Alexandre Manette .
Parsing [sent. 5542 len. 7]: But he had married in England ?
Parsing [sent. 5543 len. 5]: the President reminded him .
Parsing [sent. 5544 len. 8]: True , but not an English woman .
Parsing [sent. 5545 len. 5]: A citizeness of France ?
Parsing [sent. 5546 len. 2]: Yes .
Parsing [sent. 5547 len. 3]: By birth .
Parsing [sent. 5548 len. 5]: Her name and family ?
Parsing [sent. 5549 len. 18]: `` Lucie Manette , only daughter of Doctor Manette , the good physician who sits there . ''
Parsing [sent. 5550 len. 10]: This answer had a happy effect upon the audience .
Parsing [sent. 5551 len. 12]: Cries in exaltation of the well-known good physician rent the hall .
Parsing [sent. 5552 len. 41]: So capriciously were the people moved , that tears immediately rolled down several ferocious countenances which had been glaring at the prisoner a moment before , as if with impatience to pluck him out into the streets and kill him .
Parsing [sent. 5553 len. 23]: On these few steps of his dangerous way , Charles Darnay had set his foot according to Doctor Manette 's reiterated instructions .
Parsing [sent. 5554 len. 21]: The same cautious counsel directed every step that lay before him , and had prepared every inch of his road .
Parsing [sent. 5555 len. 18]: The President asked , why had he returned to France when he did , and not sooner ?
Parsing [sent. 5556 len. 43]: He had not returned sooner , he replied , simply because he had no means of living in France , save those he had resigned ; whereas , in England , he lived by giving instruction in the French language and literature .
Parsing [sent. 5557 len. 29]: He had returned when he did , on the pressing and written entreaty of a French citizen , who represented that his life was endangered by his absence .
Parsing [sent. 5558 len. 27]: He had come back , to save a citizen 's life , and to bear his testimony , at whatever personal hazard , to the truth .
Parsing [sent. 5559 len. 10]: Was that criminal in the eyes of the Republic ?
Parsing [sent. 5560 len. 9]: The populace cried enthusiastically , `` No ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5561 len. 10]: and the President rang his bell to quiet them .
Parsing [sent. 5562 len. 14]: Which it did not , for they continued to cry `` No ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5563 len. 10]: until they left off , of their own will .
Parsing [sent. 5564 len. 9]: The President required the name of that citizen .
Parsing [sent. 5565 len. 11]: The accused explained that the citizen was his first witness .
Parsing [sent. 5566 len. 38]: He also referred with confidence to the citizen 's letter , which had been taken from him at the Barrier , but which he did not doubt would be found among the papers then before the President .
Parsing [sent. 5567 len. 33]: The Doctor had taken care that it should be there -- had assured him that it would be there -- and at this stage of the proceedings it was produced and read .
Parsing [sent. 5568 len. 12]: Citizen Gabelle was called to confirm it , and did so .
Parsing [sent. 5569 len. 110]: Citizen Gabelle hinted , with infinite delicacy and politeness , that in the pressure of business imposed on the Tribunal by the multitude of enemies of the Republic with which it had to deal , he had been slightly overlooked in his prison of the Abbaye -- in fact , had rather passed out of the Tribunal 's patriotic remembrance -- until three days ago ; when he had been summoned before it , and had been set at liberty on the Jury 's declaring themselves satisfied that the accusation against him was answered , as to himself , by the surrender of the citizen Evremonde , called Darnay .
Parsing [sent. 5570 len. 6]: Doctor Manette was next questioned .
Parsing [sent. 5571 len. 130]: His high personal popularity , and the clearness of his answers , made a great impression ; but , as he proceeded , as he showed that the Accused was his first friend on his release from his long imprisonment ; that , the accused had remained in England , always faithful and devoted to his daughter and himself in their exile ; that , so far from being in favour with the Aristocrat government there , he had actually been tried for his life by it , as the foe of England and friend of the United States -- as he brought these circumstances into view , with the greatest discretion and with the straightforward force of truth and earnestness , the Jury and the populace became one .
Parsing [sent. 5572 len. 67]: At last , when he appealed by name to Monsieur Lorry , an English gentleman then and there present , who , like himself , had been a witness on that English trial and could corroborate his account of it , the Jury declared that they had heard enough , and that they were ready with their votes if the President were content to receive them .
Parsing [sent. 5573 len. 21]: At every vote -LRB- the Jurymen voted aloud and individually -RRB- , the populace set up a shout of applause .
Parsing [sent. 5574 len. 17]: All the voices were in the prisoner 's favour , and the President declared him free .
Parsing [sent. 5575 len. 41]: Then , began one of those extraordinary scenes with which the populace sometimes gratified their fickleness , or their better impulses towards generosity and mercy , or which they regarded as some set-off against their swollen account of cruel rage .
Parsing [sent. 5576 len. 33]: No man can decide now to which of these motives such extraordinary scenes were referable ; it is probable , to a blending of all the three , with the second predominating .
Parsing [sent. 5577 len. 99]: No sooner was the acquittal pronounced , than tears were shed as freely as blood at another time , and such fraternal embraces were bestowed upon the prisoner by as many of both sexes as could rush at him , that after his long and unwholesome confinement he was in danger of fainting from exhaustion ; none the less because he knew very well , that the very same people , carried by another current , would have rushed at him with the very same intensity , to rend him to pieces and strew him over the streets .
Parsing [sent. 5578 len. 25]: His removal , to make way for other accused persons who were to be tried , rescued him from these caresses for the moment .
Parsing [sent. 5579 len. 27]: Five were to be tried together , next , as enemies of the Republic , forasmuch as they had not assisted it by word or deed .
Parsing [sent. 5580 len. 36]: So quick was the Tribunal to compensate itself and the nation for a chance lost , that these five came down to him before he left the place , condemned to die within twenty-four hours .
Parsing [sent. 5581 len. 34]: The first of them told him so , with the customary prison sign of Death -- a raised finger -- and they all added in words , `` Long live the Republic ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5582 len. 59]: The five had had , it is true , no audience to lengthen their proceedings , for when he and Doctor Manette emerged from the gate , there was a great crowd about it , in which there seemed to be every face he had seen in Court -- except two , for which he looked in vain .
Parsing [sent. 5583 len. 56]: On his coming out , the concourse made at him anew , weeping , embracing , and shouting , all by turns and all together , until the very tide of the river on the bank of which the mad scene was acted , seemed to run mad , like the people on the shore .
Parsing [sent. 5584 len. 32]: They put him into a great chair they had among them , and which they had taken either out of the Court itself , or one of its rooms or passages .
Parsing [sent. 5585 len. 29]: Over the chair they had thrown a red flag , and to the back of it they had bound a pike with a red cap on its top .
Parsing [sent. 5586 len. 76]: In this car of triumph , not even the Doctor 's entreaties could prevent his being carried to his home on men 's shoulders , with a confused sea of red caps heaving about him , and casting up to sight from the stormy deep such wrecks of faces , that he more than once misdoubted his mind being in confusion , and that he was in the tumbril on his way to the Guillotine .
Parsing [sent. 5587 len. 19]: In wild dreamlike procession , embracing whom they met and pointing him out , they carried him on .
Parsing [sent. 5588 len. 44]: Reddening the snowy streets with the prevailing Republican colour , in winding and tramping through them , as they had reddened them below the snow with a deeper dye , they carried him thus into the courtyard of the building where he lived .
Parsing [sent. 5589 len. 27]: Her father had gone on before , to prepare her , and when her husband stood upon his feet , she dropped insensible in his arms .
Parsing [sent. 5590 len. 41]: As he held her to his heart and turned her beautiful head between his face and the brawling crowd , so that his tears and her lips might come together unseen , a few of the people fell to dancing .
Parsing [sent. 5591 len. 17]: Instantly , all the rest fell to dancing , and the courtyard overflowed with the Carmagnole .
Parsing [sent. 5592 len. 57]: Then , they elevated into the vacant chair a young woman from the crowd to be carried as the Goddess of Liberty , and then swelling and overflowing out into the adjacent streets , and along the river 's bank , and over the bridge , the Carmagnole absorbed them every one and whirled them away .
Parsing [sent. 5593 len. 85]: After grasping the Doctor 's hand , as he stood victorious and proud before him ; after grasping the hand of Mr. Lorry , who came panting in breathless from his struggle against the waterspout of the Carmagnole ; after kissing little Lucie , who was lifted up to clasp her arms round his neck ; and after embracing the ever zealous and faithful Pross who lifted her ; he took his wife in his arms , and carried her up to their rooms .
Parsing [sent. 5594 len. 3]: `` Lucie !
Parsing [sent. 5595 len. 3]: My own !
Parsing [sent. 5596 len. 5]: I am safe . ''
Parsing [sent. 5597 len. 22]: `` O dearest Charles , let me thank God for this on my knees as I have prayed to Him . ''
Parsing [sent. 5598 len. 9]: They all reverently bowed their heads and hearts .

Parsing [sent. 5608 len. 89]: All the air round was so thick and dark , the people were so passionately revengeful and fitful , the innocent were so constantly put to death on vague suspicion and black malice , it was so impossible to forget that many as blameless as her husband and as dear to others as he was to her , every day shared the fate from which he had been clutched , that her heart could not be as lightened of its load as she felt it ought to be .

Parsing [sent. 5615 len. 66]: Their housekeeping was of a very frugal kind : not only because that was the safest way of life , involving the least offence to the people , but because they were not rich , and Charles , throughout his imprisonment , had had to pay heavily for his bad food , and for his guard , and towards the living of the poorer prisoners .

Parsing [sent. 5929 len. 83]: Thrown out of his honourable employment in England , through too much unsuccessful hard swearing there -- not because he was not wanted there ; our English reasons for vaunting our superiority to secrecy and spies are of very modern date -- he knew that he had crossed the Channel , and accepted service in France : first , as a tempter and an eavesdropper among his own countrymen there : gradually , as a tempter and an eavesdropper among the natives .

Parsing [sent. 5933 len. 61]: He knew , as every one employed as he was did , that he was never safe ; that flight was impossible ; that he was tied fast under the shadow of the axe ; and that in spite of his utmost tergiversation and treachery in furtherance of the reigning terror , a word might bring it down upon him .
Parsing [sent. 5934 len. 51]: Once denounced , and on such grave grounds as had just now been suggested to his mind , he foresaw that the dreadful woman of whose unrelenting character he had seen many proofs , would produce against him that fatal register , and would quash his last chance of life .
