Parsing [sent. 6248 len. 79]: In a city dominated by the axe , alone at night , with natural sorrow rising in him for the sixty-three who had been that day put to death , and for to-morrow 's victims then awaiting their doom in the prisons , and still of to-morrow 's and to-morrow 's , the chain of association that brought the words home , like a rusty old ship 's anchor from the deep , might have been easily found .
Parsing [sent. 6249 len. 13]: He did not seek it , but repeated them and went on .
Parsing [sent. 6250 len. 162]: With a solemn interest in the lighted windows where the people were going to rest , forgetful through a few calm hours of the horrors surrounding them ; in the towers of the churches , where no prayers were said , for the popular revulsion had even travelled that length of self-destruction from years of priestly impostors , plunderers , and profligates ; in the distant burial-places , reserved , as they wrote upon the gates , for Eternal Sleep ; in the abounding gaols ; and in the streets along which the sixties rolled to a death which had become so common and material , that no sorrowful story of a haunting Spirit ever arose among the people out of all the working of the Guillotine ; with a solemn interest in the whole life and death of the city settling down to its short nightly pause in fury ; Sydney Carton crossed the Seine again for the lighter streets .
Parsing [sent. 6251 len. 33]: Few coaches were abroad , for riders in coaches were liable to be suspected , and gentility hid its head in red nightcaps , and put on heavy shoes , and trudged .
Parsing [sent. 6252 len. 24]: But , the theatres were all well filled , and the people poured cheerfully out as he passed , and went chatting home .
Parsing [sent. 6253 len. 27]: At one of the theatre doors , there was a little girl with a mother , looking for a way across the street through the mud .
Parsing [sent. 6254 len. 23]: He carried the child over , and before , the timid arm was loosed from his neck asked her for a kiss .
Parsing [sent. 6255 len. 42]: `` I am the resurrection and the life , saith the Lord : he that believeth in me , though he were dead , yet shall he live : and whosoever liveth and believeth in me , shall never die . ''
Parsing [sent. 6256 len. 30]: Now , that the streets were quiet , and the night wore on , the words were in the echoes of his feet , and were in the air .
Parsing [sent. 6257 len. 22]: Perfectly calm and steady , he sometimes repeated them to himself as he walked ; but , he heard them always .
Parsing [sent. 6258 len. 60]: The night wore out , and , as he stood upon the bridge listening to the water as it splashed the river-walls of the Island of Paris , where the picturesque confusion of houses and cathedral shone bright in the light of the moon , the day came coldly , looking like a dead face out of the sky .
Parsing [sent. 6259 len. 35]: Then , the night , with the moon and the stars , turned pale and died , and for a little while it seemed as if Creation were delivered over to Death 's dominion .
Parsing [sent. 6260 len. 32]: But , the glorious sun , rising , seemed to strike those words , that burden of the night , straight and warm to his heart in its long bright rays .
Parsing [sent. 6261 len. 32]: And looking along them , with reverently shaded eyes , a bridge of light appeared to span the air between him and the sun , while the river sparkled under it .
Parsing [sent. 6262 len. 24]: The strong tide , so swift , so deep , and certain , was like a congenial friend , in the morning stillness .
Parsing [sent. 6263 len. 26]: He walked by the stream , far from the houses , and in the light and warmth of the sun fell asleep on the bank .
Parsing [sent. 6264 len. 39]: When he awoke and was afoot again , he lingered there yet a little longer , watching an eddy that turned and turned purposeless , until the stream absorbed it , and carried it on to the sea .
Parsing [sent. 6265 len. 6]: -- `` Like me . ''

Parsing [sent. 6275 len. 23]: Before that unjust Tribunal , there was little or no order of procedure , ensuring to any accused person any reasonable hearing .

Parsing [sent. 6307 len. 7]: `` Citizen Manette , be tranquil .
Parsing [sent. 6308 len. 19]: To fail in submission to the authority of the Tribunal would be to put yourself out of Law .
Parsing [sent. 6309 len. 24]: As to what is dearer to you than life , nothing can be so dear to a good citizen as the Republic . ''
Parsing [sent. 6310 len. 6]: Loud acclamations hailed this rebuke .
Parsing [sent. 6311 len. 11]: The President rang his bell , and with warmth resumed .
Parsing [sent. 6312 len. 25]: `` If the Republic should demand of you the sacrifice of your child herself , you would have no duty but to sacrifice her .
Parsing [sent. 6313 len. 7]: Listen to what is to follow .
Parsing [sent. 6314 len. 8]: In the meanwhile , be silent ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6315 len. 6]: Frantic acclamations were again raised .
Parsing [sent. 6316 len. 23]: Doctor Manette sat down , with his eyes looking around , and his lips trembling ; his daughter drew closer to him .
Parsing [sent. 6317 len. 20]: The craving man on the jury rubbed his hands together , and restored the usual hand to his mouth .
Parsing [sent. 6318 len. 59]: Defarge was produced , when the court was quiet enough to admit of his being heard , and rapidly expounded the story of the imprisonment , and of his having been a mere boy in the Doctor 's service , and of the release , and of the state of the prisoner when released and delivered to him .
Parsing [sent. 6319 len. 14]: This short examination followed , for the court was quick with its work .
Parsing [sent. 6320 len. 15]: `` You did good service at the taking of the Bastille , citizen ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6321 len. 6]: `` I believe so . ''
Parsing [sent. 6322 len. 20]: Here , an excited woman screeched from the crowd : `` You were one of the best patriots there .
Parsing [sent. 6323 len. 5]: Why not say so ?
Parsing [sent. 6324 len. 23]: You were a cannoneer that day there , and you were among the first to enter the accursed fortress when it fell .
Parsing [sent. 6325 len. 8]: Patriots , I speak the truth ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6326 len. 19]: It was The Vengeance who , amidst the warm commendations of the audience , thus assisted the proceedings .
Parsing [sent. 6327 len. 24]: The President rang his bell ; but , The Vengeance , warming with encouragement , shrieked , `` I defy that bell ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6328 len. 7]: wherein she was likewise much commended .
Parsing [sent. 6329 len. 17]: `` Inform the Tribunal of what you did that day within the Bastille , citizen . ''
Parsing [sent. 6330 len. 62]: `` I knew , '' said Defarge , looking down at his wife , who stood at the bottom of the steps on which he was raised , looking steadily up at him ; `` I knew that this prisoner , of whom I speak , had been confined in a cell known as One Hundred and Five , North Tower .
Parsing [sent. 6331 len. 6]: I knew it from himself .
Parsing [sent. 6332 len. 24]: He knew himself by no other name than One Hundred and Five , North Tower , when he made shoes under my care .
Parsing [sent. 6333 len. 22]: As I serve my gun that day , I resolve , when the place shall fall , to examine that cell .
Parsing [sent. 6334 len. 3]: It falls .
Parsing [sent. 6335 len. 21]: I mount to the cell , with a fellow-citizen who is one of the Jury , directed by a gaoler .
Parsing [sent. 6336 len. 7]: I examine it , very closely .
Parsing [sent. 6337 len. 23]: In a hole in the chimney , where a stone has been worked out and replaced , I find a written paper .
Parsing [sent. 6338 len. 6]: This is that written paper .
Parsing [sent. 6339 len. 17]: I have made it my business to examine some specimens of the writing of Doctor Manette .
Parsing [sent. 6340 len. 8]: This is the writing of Doctor Manette .
Parsing [sent. 6341 len. 20]: I confide this paper , in the writing of Doctor Manette , to the hands of the President . ''
Parsing [sent. 6342 len. 7]: `` Let it be read . ''
Parsing [sent. 6343 len. 84]: In a dead silence and stillness -- the prisoner under trial looking lovingly at his wife , his wife only looking from him to look with solicitude at her father , Doctor Manette keeping his eyes fixed on the reader , Madame Defarge never taking hers from the prisoner , Defarge never taking his from his feasting wife , and all the other eyes there intent upon the Doctor , who saw none of them -- the paper was read , as follows .
Parsing [sent. 6344 len. 47]: X The Substance of the Shadow `` I , Alexandre Manette , unfortunate physician , native of Beauvais , and afterwards resident in Paris , write this melancholy paper in my doleful cell in the Bastille , during the last month of the year , 1767 .
Parsing [sent. 6345 len. 11]: I write it at stolen intervals , under every difficulty .
Parsing [sent. 6346 len. 26]: I design to secrete it in the wall of the chimney , where I have slowly and laboriously made a place of concealment for it .
Parsing [sent. 6347 len. 16]: Some pitying hand may find it there , when I and my sorrows are dust .
Parsing [sent. 6348 len. 42]: `` These words are formed by the rusty iron point with which I write with difficulty in scrapings of soot and charcoal from the chimney , mixed with blood , in the last month of the tenth year of my captivity .
Parsing [sent. 6349 len. 8]: Hope has quite departed from my breast .
Parsing [sent. 6350 len. 77]: I know from terrible warnings I have noted in myself that my reason will not long remain unimpaired , but I solemnly declare that I am at this time in the possession of my right mind -- that my memory is exact and circumstantial -- and that I write the truth as I shall answer for these my last recorded words , whether they be ever read by men or not , at the Eternal Judgment-seat .
Parsing [sent. 6351 len. 78]: `` One cloudy moonlight night , in the third week of December -LRB- I think the twenty-second of the month -RRB- in the year 1757 , I was walking on a retired part of the quay by the Seine for the refreshment of the frosty air , at an hour 's distance from my place of residence in the Street of the School of Medicine , when a carriage came along behind me , driven very fast .
Parsing [sent. 6352 len. 38]: As I stood aside to let that carriage pass , apprehensive that it might otherwise run me down , a head was put out at the window , and a voice called to the driver to stop .
Parsing [sent. 6353 len. 26]: `` The carriage stopped as soon as the driver could rein in his horses , and the same voice called to me by my name .
Parsing [sent. 6354 len. 3]: I answered .
Parsing [sent. 6355 len. 28]: The carriage was then so far in advance of me that two gentlemen had time to open the door and alight before I came up with it .
Parsing [sent. 6356 len. 16]: I observed that they were both wrapped in cloaks , and appeared to conceal themselves .
Parsing [sent. 6357 len. 55]: As they stood side by side near the carriage door , I also observed that they both looked of about my own age , or rather younger , and that they were greatly alike , in stature , manner , voice , and -LRB- as far as I could see -RRB- face too . ''
Parsing [sent. 6358 len. 7]: ` You are Doctor Manette ? '
Parsing [sent. 6359 len. 3]: said one .
Parsing [sent. 6360 len. 6]: `` I am . '' ''
Parsing [sent. 6361 len. 40]: ` Doctor Manette , formerly of Beauvais , ' said the other ; ` the young physician , originally an expert surgeon , who within the last year or two has made a rising reputation in Paris ? ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6362 len. 22]: ` Gentlemen , ' I returned , ` I am that Doctor Manette of whom you speak so graciously . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6363 len. 47]: ` We have been to your residence , ' said the first , ` and not being so fortunate as to find you there , and being informed that you were probably walking in this direction , we followed , in the hope of overtaking you .
Parsing [sent. 6364 len. 9]: Will you please to enter the carriage ? '
Parsing [sent. 6365 len. 31]: `` The manner of both was imperious , and they both moved , as these words were spoken , so as to place me between themselves and the carriage door .
Parsing [sent. 6366 len. 4]: They were armed .
Parsing [sent. 6367 len. 5]: I was not . ''
Parsing [sent. 6368 len. 40]: ` Gentlemen , ' said I , ` pardon me ; but I usually inquire who does me the honour to seek my assistance , and what is the nature of the case to which I am summoned . '
Parsing [sent. 6369 len. 14]: `` The reply to this was made by him who had spoken second .
Parsing [sent. 6370 len. 10]: ` Doctor , your clients are people of condition .
Parsing [sent. 6371 len. 29]: As to the nature of the case , our confidence in your skill assures us that you will ascertain it for yourself better than we can describe it .
Parsing [sent. 6372 len. 2]: Enough .
Parsing [sent. 6373 len. 9]: Will you please to enter the carriage ? '
Parsing [sent. 6374 len. 15]: `` I could do nothing but comply , and I entered it in silence .
Parsing [sent. 6375 len. 17]: They both entered after me -- the last springing in , after putting up the steps .
Parsing [sent. 6376 len. 13]: The carriage turned about , and drove on at its former speed .
Parsing [sent. 6377 len. 10]: `` I repeat this conversation exactly as it occurred .
Parsing [sent. 6378 len. 15]: I have no doubt that it is , word for word , the same .
Parsing [sent. 6379 len. 19]: I describe everything exactly as it took place , constraining my mind not to wander from the task .
Parsing [sent. 6380 len. 25]: Where I make the broken marks that follow here , I leave off for the time , and put my paper in its hiding-place .
Parsing [sent. 6381 len. 21]: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- `` The carriage left the streets behind , passed the North Barrier , and emerged upon the country road .
Parsing [sent. 6382 len. 72]: At two-thirds of a league from the Barrier -- I did not estimate the distance at that time , but afterwards when I traversed it -- it struck out of the main avenue , and presently stopped at a solitary house , We all three alighted , and walked , by a damp soft footpath in a garden where a neglected fountain had overflowed , to the door of the house .
Parsing [sent. 6383 len. 38]: It was not opened immediately , in answer to the ringing of the bell , and one of my two conductors struck the man who opened it , with his heavy riding glove , across the face .
Parsing [sent. 6384 len. 25]: `` There was nothing in this action to attract my particular attention , for I had seen common people struck more commonly than dogs .
Parsing [sent. 6385 len. 46]: But , the other of the two , being angry likewise , struck the man in like manner with his arm ; the look and bearing of the brothers were then so exactly alike , that I then first perceived them to be twin brothers .
Parsing [sent. 6386 len. 44]: `` From the time of our alighting at the outer gate -LRB- which we found locked , and which one of the brothers had opened to admit us , and had relocked -RRB- , I had heard cries proceeding from an upper chamber .
Parsing [sent. 6387 len. 36]: I was conducted to this chamber straight , the cries growing louder as we ascended the stairs , and I found a patient in a high fever of the brain , lying on a bed .
Parsing [sent. 6388 len. 19]: `` The patient was a woman of great beauty , and young ; assuredly not much past twenty .
Parsing [sent. 6389 len. 20]: Her hair was torn and ragged , and her arms were bound to her sides with sashes and handkerchiefs .
Parsing [sent. 6390 len. 14]: I noticed that these bonds were all portions of a gentleman 's dress .
Parsing [sent. 6391 len. 83]: On one of them , which was a fringed scarf for a dress of ceremony , I saw the armorial bearings of a Noble , and the letter E. `` I saw this , within the first minute of my contemplation of the patient ; for , in her restless strivings she had turned over on her face on the edge of the bed , had drawn the end of the scarf into her mouth , and was in danger of suffocation .
Parsing [sent. 6392 len. 30]: My first act was to put out my hand to relieve her breathing ; and in moving the scarf aside , the embroidery in the corner caught my sight .
Parsing [sent. 6393 len. 27]: `` I turned her gently over , placed my hands upon her breast to calm her and keep her down , and looked into her face .
Parsing [sent. 6394 len. 31]: Her eyes were dilated and wild , and she constantly uttered piercing shrieks , and repeated the words , ` My husband , my father , and my brother ! '
Parsing [sent. 6395 len. 14]: and then counted up to twelve , and said , ` Hush ! '
Parsing [sent. 6396 len. 42]: For an instant , and no more , she would pause to listen , and then the piercing shrieks would begin again , and she would repeat the cry , ` My husband , my father , and my brother ! '
Parsing [sent. 6397 len. 14]: and would count up to twelve , and say , ` Hush ! '
Parsing [sent. 6398 len. 12]: There was no variation in the order , or the manner .
Parsing [sent. 6399 len. 20]: There was no cessation , but the regular moment 's pause , in the utterance of these sounds . ''
Parsing [sent. 6400 len. 14]: ` How long , ' I asked , ` has this lasted ? '
Parsing [sent. 6401 len. 29]: `` To distinguish the brothers , I will call them the elder and the younger ; by the elder , I mean him who exercised the most authority .
Parsing [sent. 6402 len. 17]: It was the elder who replied , ` Since about this hour last night . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6403 len. 15]: ` She has a husband , a father , and a brother ? ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6404 len. 6]: ` A brother . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6405 len. 9]: ` I do not address her brother ? '
Parsing [sent. 6406 len. 12]: `` He answered with great contempt , ` No . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6407 len. 12]: ` She has some recent association with the number twelve ? '
Parsing [sent. 6408 len. 14]: `` The younger brother impatiently rejoined , ` With twelve o'clock ? ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6409 len. 29]: ` See , gentlemen , ' said I , still keeping my hands upon her breast , ` how useless I am , as you have brought me !
Parsing [sent. 6410 len. 17]: If I had known what I was coming to see , I could have come provided .
Parsing [sent. 6411 len. 9]: As it is , time must be lost .
Parsing [sent. 6412 len. 13]: There are no medicines to be obtained in this lonely place . '
Parsing [sent. 6413 len. 37]: `` The elder brother looked to the younger , who said haughtily , ` There is a case of medicines here ; ' and brought it from a closet , and put it on the table .
Parsing [sent. 6414 len. 20]: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- `` I opened some of the bottles , smelt them , and put the stoppers to my lips .
Parsing [sent. 6415 len. 26]: If I had wanted to use anything save narcotic medicines that were poisons in themselves , I would not have administered any of those . ''
Parsing [sent. 6416 len. 7]: ` Do you doubt them ? '
Parsing [sent. 6417 len. 6]: asked the younger brother . ''
Parsing [sent. 6418 len. 22]: ` You see , monsieur , I am going to use them , ' I replied , and said no more .
Parsing [sent. 6419 len. 24]: `` I made the patient swallow , with great difficulty , and after many efforts , the dose that I desired to give .
Parsing [sent. 6420 len. 31]: As I intended to repeat it after a while , and as it was necessary to watch its influence , I then sat down by the side of the bed .
Parsing [sent. 6421 len. 24]: There was a timid and suppressed woman in attendance -LRB- wife of the man down-stairs -RRB- , who had retreated into a corner .
Parsing [sent. 6422 len. 18]: The house was damp and decayed , indifferently furnished -- evidently , recently occupied and temporarily used .
Parsing [sent. 6423 len. 20]: Some thick old hangings had been nailed up before the windows , to deaden the sound of the shrieks .
Parsing [sent. 6424 len. 26]: They continued to be uttered in their regular succession , with the cry , ` My husband , my father , and my brother ! '
Parsing [sent. 6425 len. 11]: the counting up to twelve , and ` Hush ! '
Parsing [sent. 6426 len. 33]: The frenzy was so violent , that I had not unfastened the bandages restraining the arms ; but , I had looked to them , to see that they were not painful .
Parsing [sent. 6427 len. 36]: The only spark of encouragement in the case , was , that my hand upon the sufferer 's breast had this much soothing influence , that for minutes at a time it tranquillised the figure .
Parsing [sent. 6428 len. 15]: It had no effect upon the cries ; no pendulum could be more regular .
Parsing [sent. 6429 len. 49]: `` For the reason that my hand had this effect -LRB- I assume -RRB- , I had sat by the side of the bed for half an hour , with the two brothers looking on , before the elder said : '' ` There is another patient . '
Parsing [sent. 6430 len. 17]: `` I was startled , and asked , ` Is it a pressing case ? ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6431 len. 17]: ` You had better see , ' he carelessly answered ; and took up a light .
Parsing [sent. 6432 len. 25]: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- `` The other patient lay in a back room across a second staircase , which was a species of loft over a stable .
Parsing [sent. 6433 len. 31]: There was a low plastered ceiling to a part of it ; the rest was open , to the ridge of the tiled roof , and there were beams across .
Parsing [sent. 6434 len. 24]: Hay and straw were stored in that portion of the place , fagots for firing , and a heap of apples in sand .
Parsing [sent. 6435 len. 14]: I had to pass through that part , to get at the other .
Parsing [sent. 6436 len. 7]: My memory is circumstantial and unshaken .
Parsing [sent. 6437 len. 40]: I try it with these details , and I see them all , in this my cell in the Bastille , near the close of the tenth year of my captivity , as I saw them all that night .
Parsing [sent. 6438 len. 33]: `` On some hay on the ground , with a cushion thrown under his head , lay a handsome peasant boy -- a boy of not more than seventeen at the most .
Parsing [sent. 6439 len. 27]: He lay on his back , with his teeth set , his right hand clenched on his breast , and his glaring eyes looking straight upward .
Parsing [sent. 6440 len. 36]: I could not see where his wound was , as I kneeled on one knee over him ; but , I could see that he was dying of a wound from a sharp point . ''
Parsing [sent. 6441 len. 21]: ` I am a doctor , my poor fellow , ' said I. ` Let me examine it . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6442 len. 18]: ` I do not want it examined , ' he answered ; ` let it be . '
Parsing [sent. 6443 len. 19]: `` It was under his hand , and I soothed him to let me move his hand away .
Parsing [sent. 6444 len. 30]: The wound was a sword-thrust , received from twenty to twenty-four hours before , but no skill could have saved him if it had been looked to without delay .
Parsing [sent. 6445 len. 6]: He was then dying fast .
Parsing [sent. 6446 len. 50]: As I turned my eyes to the elder brother , I saw him looking down at this handsome boy whose life was ebbing out , as if he were a wounded bird , or hare , or rabbit ; not at all as if he were a fellow-creature . ''
Parsing [sent. 6447 len. 10]: ` How has this been done , monsieur ? '
Parsing [sent. 6448 len. 10]: said I. '' ` A crazed young common dog !
Parsing [sent. 6449 len. 3]: A serf !
Parsing [sent. 6450 len. 22]: Forced my brother to draw upon him , and has fallen by my brother 's sword -- like a gentleman . '
Parsing [sent. 6451 len. 18]: `` There was no touch of pity , sorrow , or kindred humanity , in this answer .
Parsing [sent. 6452 len. 40]: The speaker seemed to acknowledge that it was inconvenient to have that different order of creature dying there , and that it would have been better if he had died in the usual obscure routine of his vermin kind .
Parsing [sent. 6453 len. 17]: He was quite incapable of any compassionate feeling about the boy , or about his fate .
Parsing [sent. 6454 len. 24]: `` The boy 's eyes had slowly moved to him as he had spoken , and they now slowly moved to me . ''
Parsing [sent. 6455 len. 21]: ` Doctor , they are very proud , these Nobles ; but we common dogs are proud too , sometimes .
Parsing [sent. 6456 len. 23]: They plunder us , outrage us , beat us , kill us ; but we have a little pride left , sometimes .
Parsing [sent. 6457 len. 10]: She -- have you seen her , Doctor ? '
Parsing [sent. 6458 len. 16]: `` The shrieks and the cries were audible there , though subdued by the distance .
Parsing [sent. 6459 len. 14]: He referred to them , as if she were lying in our presence .
Parsing [sent. 6460 len. 12]: `` I said , ` I have seen her . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6461 len. 8]: ` She is my sister , Doctor .
Parsing [sent. 6462 len. 31]: They have had their shameful rights , these Nobles , in the modesty and virtue of our sisters , many years , but we have had good girls among us .
Parsing [sent. 6463 len. 12]: I know it , and have heard my father say so .
Parsing [sent. 6464 len. 6]: She was a good girl .
Parsing [sent. 6465 len. 16]: She was betrothed to a good young man , too : a tenant of his .
Parsing [sent. 6466 len. 14]: We were all tenants of his -- that man 's who stands there .
Parsing [sent. 6467 len. 14]: The other is his brother , the worst of a bad race . '
Parsing [sent. 6468 len. 27]: `` It was with the greatest difficulty that the boy gathered bodily force to speak ; but , his spirit spoke with a dreadful emphasis . ''
Parsing [sent. 6469 len. 179]: ` We were so robbed by that man who stands there , as all we common dogs are by those superior Beings -- taxed by him without mercy , obliged to work for him without pay , obliged to grind our corn at his mill , obliged to feed scores of his tame birds on our wretched crops , and forbidden for our lives to keep a single tame bird of our own , pillaged and plundered to that degree that when we chanced to have a bit of meat , we ate it in fear , with the door barred and the shutters closed , that his people should not see it and take it from us -- I say , we were so robbed , and hunted , and were made so poor , that our father told us it was a dreadful thing to bring a child into the world , and that what we should most pray for , was , that our women might be barren and our miserable race die out ! '
Parsing [sent. 6470 len. 18]: `` I had never before seen the sense of being oppressed , bursting forth like a fire .
Parsing [sent. 6471 len. 33]: I had supposed that it must be latent in the people somewhere ; but , I had never seen it break out , until I saw it in the dying boy . ''
Parsing [sent. 6472 len. 9]: ` Nevertheless , Doctor , my sister married .
Parsing [sent. 6473 len. 37]: He was ailing at that time , poor fellow , and she married her lover , that she might tend and comfort him in our cottage -- our dog-hut , as that man would call it .
Parsing [sent. 6474 len. 36]: She had not been married many weeks , when that man 's brother saw her and admired her , and asked that man to lend her to him -- for what are husbands among us !
Parsing [sent. 6475 len. 25]: He was willing enough , but my sister was good and virtuous , and hated his brother with a hatred as strong as mine .
Parsing [sent. 6476 len. 23]: What did the two then , to persuade her husband to use his influence with her , to make her willing ? '
Parsing [sent. 6477 len. 33]: `` The boy 's eyes , which had been fixed on mine , slowly turned to the looker-on , and I saw in the two faces that all he said was true .
Parsing [sent. 6478 len. 39]: The two opposing kinds of pride confronting one another , I can see , even in this Bastille ; the gentleman 's , all negligent indifference ; the peasants , all trodden-down sentiment , and passionate revenge . ''
Parsing [sent. 6479 len. 27]: ` You know , Doctor , that it is among the Rights of these Nobles to harness us common dogs to carts , and drive us .
Parsing [sent. 6480 len. 8]: They so harnessed him and drove him .
Parsing [sent. 6481 len. 32]: You know that it is among their Rights to keep us in their grounds all night , quieting the frogs , in order that their noble sleep may not be disturbed .
Parsing [sent. 6482 len. 22]: They kept him out in the unwholesome mists at night , and ordered him back into his harness in the day .
Parsing [sent. 6483 len. 6]: But he was not persuaded .
Parsing [sent. 6484 len. 2]: No !
Parsing [sent. 6485 len. 38]: Taken out of harness one day at noon , to feed -- if he could find food -- he sobbed twelve times , once for every stroke of the bell , and died on her bosom . '
Parsing [sent. 6486 len. 19]: `` Nothing human could have held life in the boy but his determination to tell all his wrong .
Parsing [sent. 6487 len. 27]: He forced back the gathering shadows of death , as he forced his clenched right hand to remain clenched , and to cover his wound . ''
Parsing [sent. 6488 len. 70]: ` Then , with that man 's permission and even with his aid , his brother took her away ; in spite of what I know she must have told his brother -- and what that is , will not be long unknown to you , Doctor , if it is now -- his brother took her away -- for his pleasure and diversion , for a little while .
Parsing [sent. 6489 len. 9]: I saw her pass me on the road .
Parsing [sent. 6490 len. 24]: When I took the tidings home , our father 's heart burst ; he never spoke one of the words that filled it .
Parsing [sent. 6491 len. 34]: I took my young sister -LRB- for I have another -RRB- to a place beyond the reach of this man , and where , at least , she will never be HIS vassal .
Parsing [sent. 6492 len. 23]: Then , I tracked the brother here , and last night climbed in -- a common dog , but sword in hand .
Parsing [sent. 6493 len. 7]: -- Where is the loft window ?
Parsing [sent. 6494 len. 6]: It was somewhere here ? '
Parsing [sent. 6495 len. 16]: `` The room was darkening to his sight ; the world was narrowing around him .
Parsing [sent. 6496 len. 27]: I glanced about me , and saw that the hay and straw were trampled over the floor , as if there had been a struggle . ''
Parsing [sent. 6497 len. 9]: ` She heard me , and ran in .
Parsing [sent. 6498 len. 13]: I told her not to come near us till he was dead .
Parsing [sent. 6499 len. 20]: He came in and first tossed me some pieces of money ; then struck at me with a whip .
Parsing [sent. 6500 len. 18]: But I , though a common dog , so struck at him as to make him draw .
Parsing [sent. 6501 len. 39]: Let him break into as many pieces as he will , the sword that he stained with my common blood ; he drew to defend himself -- thrust at me with all his skill for his life . '
Parsing [sent. 6502 len. 25]: `` My glance had fallen , but a few moments before , on the fragments of a broken sword , lying among the hay .
Parsing [sent. 6503 len. 7]: That weapon was a gentleman 's .
Parsing [sent. 6504 len. 18]: In another place , lay an old sword that seemed to have been a soldier 's . ''
Parsing [sent. 6505 len. 13]: ` Now , lift me up , Doctor ; lift me up .
Parsing [sent. 6506 len. 6]: Where is he ? ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6507 len. 24]: ` He is not here , ' I said , supporting the boy , and thinking that he referred to the brother . ''
Parsing [sent. 6508 len. 3]: ` He !
Parsing [sent. 6509 len. 13]: Proud as these nobles are , he is afraid to see me .
Parsing [sent. 6510 len. 8]: Where is the man who was here ?
Parsing [sent. 6511 len. 7]: turn my face to him . '
Parsing [sent. 6512 len. 14]: `` I did so , raising the boy 's head against my knee .
Parsing [sent. 6513 len. 31]: But , invested for the moment with extraordinary power , he raised himself completely : obliging me to rise too , or I could not have still supported him . ''
Parsing [sent. 6514 len. 56]: ` Marquis , ' said the boy , turned to him with his eyes opened wide , and his right hand raised , ` in the days when all these things are to be answered for , I summon you and yours , to the last of your bad race , to answer for them .
Parsing [sent. 6515 len. 17]: I mark this cross of blood upon you , as a sign that I do it .
Parsing [sent. 6516 len. 31]: In the days when all these things are to be answered for , I summon your brother , the worst of the bad race , to answer for them separately .
Parsing [sent. 6517 len. 18]: I mark this cross of blood upon him , as a sign that I do it . '
Parsing [sent. 6518 len. 25]: `` Twice , he put his hand to the wound in his breast , and with his forefinger drew a cross in the air .
Parsing [sent. 6519 len. 28]: He stood for an instant with the finger yet raised , and as it dropped , he dropped with it , and I laid him down dead .
Parsing [sent. 6520 len. 25]: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- `` When I returned to the bedside of the young woman , I found her raving in precisely the same order of continuity .
Parsing [sent. 6521 len. 23]: I knew that this might last for many hours , and that it would probably end in the silence of the grave .
Parsing [sent. 6522 len. 26]: `` I repeated the medicines I had given her , and I sat at the side of the bed until the night was far advanced .
Parsing [sent. 6523 len. 22]: She never abated the piercing quality of her shrieks , never stumbled in the distinctness or the order of her words .
Parsing [sent. 6524 len. 14]: They were always ` My husband , my father , and my brother !
Parsing [sent. 6525 len. 24]: One , two , three , four , five , six , seven , eight , nine , ten , eleven , twelve .
Parsing [sent. 6526 len. 3]: Hush ! '
Parsing [sent. 6527 len. 14]: `` This lasted twenty-six hours from the time when I first saw her .
Parsing [sent. 6528 len. 20]: I had come and gone twice , and was again sitting by her , when she began to falter .
Parsing [sent. 6529 len. 26]: I did what little could be done to assist that opportunity , and by-and-bye she sank into a lethargy , and lay like the dead .
Parsing [sent. 6530 len. 21]: `` It was as if the wind and rain had lulled at last , after a long and fearful storm .
Parsing [sent. 6531 len. 23]: I released her arms , and called the woman to assist me to compose her figure and the dress she had to .
Parsing [sent. 6532 len. 42]: It was then that I knew her condition to be that of one in whom the first expectations of being a mother have arisen ; and it was then that I lost the little hope I had had of her . ''
Parsing [sent. 6533 len. 6]: ` Is she dead ? '
Parsing [sent. 6534 len. 24]: asked the Marquis , whom I will still describe as the elder brother , coming booted into the room from his horse . ''
Parsing [sent. 6535 len. 16]: ` Not dead , ' said I ; ` but like to die . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6536 len. 11]: ` What strength there is in these common bodies ! '
Parsing [sent. 6537 len. 12]: he said , looking down at her with some curiosity . ''
Parsing [sent. 6538 len. 18]: ` There is prodigious strength , ' I answered him , ` in sorrow and despair . '
Parsing [sent. 6539 len. 14]: `` He first laughed at my words , and then frowned at them .
Parsing [sent. 6540 len. 46]: He moved a chair with his foot near to mine , ordered the woman away , and said in a subdued voice , '' ` Doctor , finding my brother in this difficulty with these hinds , I recommended that your aid should be invited .

Parsing [sent. 6543 len. 14]: `` I listened to the patient 's breathing , and avoided answering . ''
Parsing [sent. 6544 len. 13]: ` Do you honour me with your attention , Doctor ? ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6545 len. 23]: ` Monsieur , ' said I , ` in my profession , the communications of patients are always received in confidence . '
Parsing [sent. 6546 len. 22]: I was guarded in my answer , for I was troubled in my mind with what I had heard and seen .
Parsing [sent. 6547 len. 19]: `` Her breathing was so difficult to trace , that I carefully tried the pulse and the heart .
Parsing [sent. 6548 len. 8]: There was life , and no more .
Parsing [sent. 6549 len. 17]: Looking round as I resumed my seat , I found both the brothers intent upon me .
Parsing [sent. 6550 len. 39]: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- `` I write with so much difficulty , the cold is so severe , I am so fearful of being detected and consigned to an underground cell and total darkness , that I must abridge this narrative .
Parsing [sent. 6551 len. 30]: There is no confusion or failure in my memory ; it can recall , and could detail , every word that was ever spoken between me and those brothers .
Parsing [sent. 6552 len. 7]: `` She lingered for a week .
Parsing [sent. 6553 len. 25]: Towards the last , I could understand some few syllables that she said to me , by placing my ear close to her lips .
Parsing [sent. 6554 len. 21]: She asked me where she was , and I told her ; who I was , and I told her .
Parsing [sent. 6555 len. 13]: It was in vain that I asked her for her family name .
Parsing [sent. 6556 len. 20]: She faintly shook her head upon the pillow , and kept her secret , as the boy had done .
Parsing [sent. 6557 len. 29]: `` I had no opportunity of asking her any question , until I had told the brothers she was sinking fast , and could not live another day .
Parsing [sent. 6558 len. 41]: Until then , though no one was ever presented to her consciousness save the woman and myself , one or other of them had always jealously sat behind the curtain at the head of the bed when I was there .
Parsing [sent. 6559 len. 33]: But when it came to that , they seemed careless what communication I might hold with her ; as if -- the thought passed through my mind -- I were dying too .
Parsing [sent. 6560 len. 32]: `` I always observed that their pride bitterly resented the younger brother 's -LRB- as I call him -RRB- having crossed swords with a peasant , and that peasant a boy .
Parsing [sent. 6561 len. 29]: The only consideration that appeared to affect the mind of either of them was the consideration that this was highly degrading to the family , and was ridiculous .
Parsing [sent. 6562 len. 30]: As often as I caught the younger brother 's eyes , their expression reminded me that he disliked me deeply , for knowing what I knew from the boy .
Parsing [sent. 6563 len. 17]: He was smoother and more polite to me than the elder ; but I saw this .
Parsing [sent. 6564 len. 17]: I also saw that I was an incumbrance in the mind of the elder , too .
Parsing [sent. 6565 len. 30]: `` My patient died , two hours before midnight -- at a time , by my watch , answering almost to the minute when I had first seen her .
Parsing [sent. 6566 len. 26]: I was alone with her , when her forlorn young head drooped gently on one side , and all her earthly wrongs and sorrows ended .
Parsing [sent. 6567 len. 15]: `` The brothers were waiting in a room down-stairs , impatient to ride away .

Parsing [sent. 6578 len. 13]: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- `` I am weary , weary , weary-worn down by misery .
Parsing [sent. 6579 len. 13]: I can not read what I have written with this gaunt hand .
Parsing [sent. 6580 len. 27]: `` Early in the morning , the rouleau of gold was left at my door in a little box , with my name on the outside .
Parsing [sent. 6581 len. 14]: From the first , I had anxiously considered what I ought to do .
Parsing [sent. 6582 len. 44]: I decided , that day , to write privately to the Minister , stating the nature of the two cases to which I had been summoned , and the place to which I had gone : in effect , stating all the circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 6583 len. 38]: I knew what Court influence was , and what the immunities of the Nobles were , and I expected that the matter would never be heard of ; but , I wished to relieve my own mind .

Parsing [sent. 6624 len. 45]: `` That night , the last night of the year , towards nine o'clock , a man in a black dress rang at my gate , demanded to see me , and softly followed my servant , Ernest Defarge , a youth , up-stairs .

Parsing [sent. 6635 len. 13]: I was brought here , I was brought to my living grave .
Parsing [sent. 6636 len. 62]: `` If it had pleased GOD to put it in the hard heart of either of the brothers , in all these frightful years , to grant me any tidings of my dearest wife -- so much as to let me know by a word whether alive or dead -- I might have thought that He had not quite abandoned them .
Parsing [sent. 6637 len. 27]: But , now I believe that the mark of the red cross is fatal to them , and that they have no part in His mercies .
Parsing [sent. 6638 len. 48]: And them and their descendants , to the last of their race , I , Alexandre Manette , unhappy prisoner , do this last night of the year 1767 , in my unbearable agony , denounce to the times when all these things shall be answered for .

Parsing [sent. 6773 len. 7]: Let me think it out ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6774 len. 36]: Checking his steps which had begun to tend towards an object , he took a turn or two in the already darkening street , and traced the thought in his mind to its possible consequences .
Parsing [sent. 6775 len. 6]: His first impression was confirmed .
Parsing [sent. 6776 len. 28]: `` It is best , '' he said , finally resolved , `` that these people should know there is such a man as I here . ''
Parsing [sent. 6777 len. 9]: And he turned his face towards Saint Antoine .

Parsing [sent. 6779 len. 21]: It was not difficult for one who knew the city well , to find his house without asking any question .

Parsing [sent. 6781 len. 14]: For the first time in many years , he had no strong drink .

Parsing [sent. 6783 len. 20]: It was as late as seven o'clock when he awoke refreshed , and went out into the streets again .

Parsing [sent. 6997 len. 44]: He walked on the other side of it and protected it to the courtyard of the house where the afflicted heart -- so happy in the memorable time when he had revealed his own desolate heart to it -- outwatched the awful night .
Parsing [sent. 6998 len. 25]: He entered the courtyard and remained there for a few moments alone , looking up at the light in the window of her room .
Parsing [sent. 6999 len. 16]: Before he went away , he breathed a blessing towards it , and a Farewell .
Parsing [sent. 7000 len. 19]: XIII Fifty-two In the black prison of the Conciergerie , the doomed of the day awaited their fate .
Parsing [sent. 7001 len. 11]: They were in number as the weeks of the year .
Parsing [sent. 7002 len. 18]: Fifty-two were to roll that afternoon on the life-tide of the city to the boundless everlasting sea .
Parsing [sent. 7003 len. 37]: Before their cells were quit of them , new occupants were appointed ; before their blood ran into the blood spilled yesterday , the blood that was to mingle with theirs to-morrow was already set apart .
Parsing [sent. 7004 len. 8]: Two score and twelve were told off .
Parsing [sent. 7005 len. 29]: From the farmer-general of seventy , whose riches could not buy his life , to the seamstress of twenty , whose poverty and obscurity could not save her .
Parsing [sent. 7006 len. 43]: Physical diseases , engendered in the vices and neglects of men , will seize on victims of all degrees ; and the frightful moral disorder , born of unspeakable suffering , intolerable oppression , and heartless indifference , smote equally without distinction .
Parsing [sent. 7007 len. 24]: Charles Darnay , alone in a cell , had sustained himself with no flattering delusion since he came to it from the Tribunal .
Parsing [sent. 7008 len. 16]: In every line of the narrative he had heard , he had heard his condemnation .
Parsing [sent. 7009 len. 30]: He had fully comprehended that no personal influence could possibly save him , that he was virtually sentenced by the millions , and that units could avail him nothing .
Parsing [sent. 7010 len. 28]: Nevertheless , it was not easy , with the face of his beloved wife fresh before him , to compose his mind to what it must bear .
Parsing [sent. 7011 len. 54]: His hold on life was strong , and it was very , very hard , to loosen ; by gradual efforts and degrees unclosed a little here , it clenched the tighter there ; and when he brought his strength to bear on that hand and it yielded , this was closed again .
Parsing [sent. 7012 len. 26]: There was a hurry , too , in all his thoughts , a turbulent and heated working of his heart , that contended against resignation .
Parsing [sent. 7013 len. 34]: If , for a moment , he did feel resigned , then his wife and child who had to live after him , seemed to protest and to make it a selfish thing .
Parsing [sent. 7014 len. 8]: But , all this was at first .
Parsing [sent. 7015 len. 39]: Before long , the consideration that there was no disgrace in the fate he must meet , and that numbers went the same road wrongfully , and trod it firmly every day , sprang up to stimulate him .
Parsing [sent. 7016 len. 24]: Next followed the thought that much of the future peace of mind enjoyable by the dear ones , depended on his quiet fortitude .
Parsing [sent. 7017 len. 25]: So , by degrees he calmed into the better state , when he could raise his thoughts much higher , and draw comfort down .
Parsing [sent. 7018 len. 23]: Before it had set in dark on the night of his condemnation , he had travelled thus far on his last way .
Parsing [sent. 7019 len. 29]: Being allowed to purchase the means of writing , and a light , he sat down to write until such time as the prison lamps should be extinguished .
Parsing [sent. 7020 len. 58]: He wrote a long letter to Lucie , showing her that he had known nothing of her father 's imprisonment , until he had heard of it from herself , and that he had been as ignorant as she of his father 's and uncle 's responsibility for that misery , until the paper had been read .
Parsing [sent. 7021 len. 52]: He had already explained to her that his concealment from herself of the name he had relinquished , was the one condition -- fully intelligible now -- that her father had attached to their betrothal , and was the one promise he had still exacted on the morning of their marriage .
Parsing [sent. 7022 len. 65]: He entreated her , for her father 's sake , never to seek to know whether her father had become oblivious of the existence of the paper , or had had it recalled to him -LRB- for the moment , or for good -RRB- , by the story of the Tower , on that old Sunday under the dear old plane-tree in the garden .
Parsing [sent. 7023 len. 55]: If he had preserved any definite remembrance of it , there could be no doubt that he had supposed it destroyed with the Bastille , when he had found no mention of it among the relics of prisoners which the populace had discovered there , and which had been described to all the world .
Parsing [sent. 7024 len. 57]: He besought her -- though he added that he knew it was needless -- to console her father , by impressing him through every tender means she could think of , with the truth that he had done nothing for which he could justly reproach himself , but had uniformly forgotten himself for their joint sakes .
Parsing [sent. 7025 len. 44]: Next to her preservation of his own last grateful love and blessing , and her overcoming of her sorrow , to devote herself to their dear child , he adjured her , as they would meet in Heaven , to comfort her father .
Parsing [sent. 7026 len. 30]: To her father himself , he wrote in the same strain ; but , he told her father that he expressly confided his wife and child to his care .
Parsing [sent. 7027 len. 30]: And he told him this , very strongly , with the hope of rousing him from any despondency or dangerous retrospect towards which he foresaw he might be tending .
Parsing [sent. 7028 len. 15]: To Mr. Lorry , he commended them all , and explained his worldly affairs .
Parsing [sent. 7029 len. 18]: That done , with many added sentences of grateful friendship and warm attachment , all was done .
Parsing [sent. 7030 len. 6]: He never thought of Carton .
Parsing [sent. 7031 len. 17]: His mind was so full of the others , that he never once thought of him .
Parsing [sent. 7032 len. 14]: He had time to finish these letters before the lights were put out .
Parsing [sent. 7033 len. 18]: When he lay down on his straw bed , he thought he had done with this world .
Parsing [sent. 7034 len. 17]: But , it beckoned him back in his sleep , and showed itself in shining forms .
Parsing [sent. 7035 len. 54]: Free and happy , back in the old house in Soho -LRB- though it had nothing in it like the real house -RRB- , unaccountably released and light of heart , he was with Lucie again , and she told him it was all a dream , and he had never gone away .
Parsing [sent. 7036 len. 33]: A pause of forgetfulness , and then he had even suffered , and had come back to her , dead and at peace , and yet there was no difference in him .
Parsing [sent. 7037 len. 39]: Another pause of oblivion , and he awoke in the sombre morning , unconscious where he was or what had happened , until it flashed upon his mind , `` this is the day of my death ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7038 len. 20]: Thus , had he come through the hours , to the day when the fifty-two heads were to fall .
Parsing [sent. 7039 len. 36]: And now , while he was composed , and hoped that he could meet the end with quiet heroism , a new action began in his waking thoughts , which was very difficult to master .
Parsing [sent. 7040 len. 13]: He had never seen the instrument that was to terminate his life .
Parsing [sent. 7041 len. 79]: How high it was from the ground , how many steps it had , where he would be stood , how he would be touched , whether the touching hands would be dyed red , which way his face would be turned , whether he would be the first , or might be the last : these and many similar questions , in nowise directed by his will , obtruded themselves over and over again , countless times .
Parsing [sent. 7042 len. 14]: Neither were they connected with fear : he was conscious of no fear .
Parsing [sent. 7043 len. 52]: Rather , they originated in a strange besetting desire to know what to do when the time came ; a desire gigantically disproportionate to the few swift moments to which it referred ; a wondering that was more like the wondering of some other spirit within his , than his own .
Parsing [sent. 7044 len. 23]: The hours went on as he walked to and fro , and the clocks struck the numbers he would never hear again .
Parsing [sent. 7045 len. 22]: Nine gone for ever , ten gone for ever , eleven gone for ever , twelve coming on to pass away .
Parsing [sent. 7046 len. 24]: After a hard contest with that eccentric action of thought which had last perplexed him , he had got the better of it .
Parsing [sent. 7047 len. 13]: He walked up and down , softly repeating their names to himself .
Parsing [sent. 7048 len. 8]: The worst of the strife was over .
Parsing [sent. 7049 len. 19]: He could walk up and down , free from distracting fancies , praying for himself and for them .
Parsing [sent. 7050 len. 5]: Twelve gone for ever .
Parsing [sent. 7051 len. 34]: He had been apprised that the final hour was Three , and he knew he would be summoned some time earlier , inasmuch as the tumbrils jolted heavily and slowly through the streets .
Parsing [sent. 7052 len. 37]: Therefore , he resolved to keep Two before his mind , as the hour , and so to strengthen himself in the interval that he might be able , after that time , to strengthen others .

Parsing [sent. 7054 len. 9]: The hour had measured like most other hours .
Parsing [sent. 7055 len. 26]: Devoutly thankful to Heaven for his recovered self-possession , he thought , `` There is but another now , '' and turned to walk again .

Parsing [sent. 7058 len. 11]: The key was put in the lock , and turned .

Parsing [sent. 7294 len. 7]: `` I salute you , citizens .
Parsing [sent. 7295 len. 8]: -- And the first danger passed ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7296 len. 19]: These are again the words of Jarvis Lorry , as he clasps his hands , and looks upward .
Parsing [sent. 7297 len. 21]: There is terror in the carriage , there is weeping , there is the heavy breathing of the insensible traveller .
Parsing [sent. 7298 len. 8]: `` Are we not going too slowly ?
Parsing [sent. 7299 len. 10]: Can they not be induced to go faster ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7300 len. 9]: asks Lucie , clinging to the old man .
Parsing [sent. 7301 len. 10]: `` It would seem like flight , my darling .
Parsing [sent. 7302 len. 14]: I must not urge them too much ; it would rouse suspicion . ''
Parsing [sent. 7303 len. 15]: `` Look back , look back , and see if we are pursued ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7304 len. 9]: `` The road is clear , my dearest .
Parsing [sent. 7305 len. 9]: So far , we are not pursued . ''
Parsing [sent. 7306 len. 31]: Houses in twos and threes pass by us , solitary farms , ruinous buildings , dye-works , tanneries , and the like , open country , avenues of leafless trees .
Parsing [sent. 7307 len. 17]: The hard uneven pavement is under us , the soft deep mud is on either side .
Parsing [sent. 7308 len. 30]: Sometimes , we strike into the skirting mud , to avoid the stones that clatter us and shake us ; sometimes , we stick in ruts and sloughs there .
Parsing [sent. 7309 len. 32]: The agony of our impatience is then so great , that in our wild alarm and hurry we are for getting out and running -- hiding -- doing anything but stopping .
Parsing [sent. 7310 len. 34]: Out of the open country , in again among ruinous buildings , solitary farms , dye-works , tanneries , and the like , cottages in twos and threes , avenues of leafless trees .
Parsing [sent. 7311 len. 14]: Have these men deceived us , and taken us back by another road ?
Parsing [sent. 7312 len. 9]: Is not this the same place twice over ?
Parsing [sent. 7313 len. 5]: Thank Heaven , no .
Parsing [sent. 7314 len. 3]: A village .
Parsing [sent. 7315 len. 13]: Look back , look back , and see if we are pursued !
Parsing [sent. 7316 len. 2]: Hush !
Parsing [sent. 7317 len. 3]: the posting-house .
Parsing [sent. 7318 len. 83]: Leisurely , our four horses are taken out ; leisurely , the coach stands in the little street , bereft of horses , and with no likelihood upon it of ever moving again ; leisurely , the new horses come into visible existence , one by one ; leisurely , the new postilions follow , sucking and plaiting the lashes of their whips ; leisurely , the old postilions count their money , make wrong additions , and arrive at dissatisfied results .
Parsing [sent. 7319 len. 26]: All the time , our overfraught hearts are beating at a rate that would far outstrip the fastest gallop of the fastest horses ever foaled .
Parsing [sent. 7320 len. 17]: At length the new postilions are in their saddles , and the old are left behind .
Parsing [sent. 7321 len. 22]: We are through the village , up the hill , and down the hill , and on the low watery grounds .
Parsing [sent. 7322 len. 22]: Suddenly , the postilions exchange speech with animated gesticulation , and the horses are pulled up , almost on their haunches .
Parsing [sent. 7323 len. 4]: We are pursued ?
Parsing [sent. 7324 len. 3]: `` Ho !
Parsing [sent. 7325 len. 5]: Within the carriage there .
Parsing [sent. 7326 len. 4]: Speak then ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7327 len. 6]: `` What is it ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7328 len. 9]: asks Mr. Lorry , looking out at window .
Parsing [sent. 7329 len. 8]: `` How many did they say ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7330 len. 9]: `` I do not understand you . '' ''
Parsing [sent. 7331 len. 6]: -- At the last post .
Parsing [sent. 7332 len. 8]: How many to the Guillotine to-day ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7333 len. 4]: `` Fifty-two . ''
Parsing [sent. 7334 len. 5]: `` I said so !
Parsing [sent. 7335 len. 4]: A brave number !
Parsing [sent. 7336 len. 15]: My fellow-citizen here would have it forty-two ; ten more heads are worth having .
Parsing [sent. 7337 len. 5]: The Guillotine goes handsomely .
Parsing [sent. 7338 len. 4]: I love it .
Parsing [sent. 7339 len. 3]: Hi forward .
Parsing [sent. 7340 len. 3]: Whoop ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7341 len. 6]: The night comes on dark .
Parsing [sent. 7342 len. 37]: He moves more ; he is beginning to revive , and to speak intelligibly ; he thinks they are still together ; he asks him , by his name , what he has in his hand .
Parsing [sent. 7343 len. 11]: O pity us , kind Heaven , and help us !
Parsing [sent. 7344 len. 13]: Look out , look out , and see if we are pursued .
Parsing [sent. 7345 len. 46]: The wind is rushing after us , and the clouds are flying after us , and the moon is plunging after us , and the whole wild night is in pursuit of us ; but , so far , we are pursued by nothing else .
Parsing [sent. 7346 len. 35]: XIV The Knitting Done In that same juncture of time when the Fifty -- Two awaited their fate Madame Defarge held darkly ominous council with The Vengeance and Jacques Three of the Revolutionary Jury .
Parsing [sent. 7347 len. 26]: Not in the wine-shop did Madame Defarge confer with these ministers , but in the shed of the wood-sawyer , erst a mender of roads .
Parsing [sent. 7348 len. 37]: The sawyer himself did not participate in the conference , but abided at a little distance , like an outer satellite who was not to speak until required , or to offer an opinion until invited .
Parsing [sent. 7349 len. 17]: `` But our Defarge , '' said Jacques Three , `` is undoubtedly a good Republican ?
Parsing [sent. 7350 len. 3]: Eh ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7351 len. 21]: `` There is no better , '' the voluble Vengeance protested in her shrill notes , `` in France . ''
Parsing [sent. 7352 len. 29]: `` Peace , little Vengeance , '' said Madame Defarge , laying her hand with a slight frown on her lieutenant 's lips , `` hear me speak .
Parsing [sent. 7353 len. 27]: My husband , fellow-citizen , is a good Republican and a bold man ; he has deserved well of the Republic , and possesses its confidence .
Parsing [sent. 7354 len. 20]: But my husband has his weaknesses , and he is so weak as to relent towards this Doctor . ''
Parsing [sent. 7355 len. 44]: `` It is a great pity , '' croaked Jacques Three , dubiously shaking his head , with his cruel fingers at his hungry mouth ; `` it is not quite like a good citizen ; it is a thing to regret . ''
Parsing [sent. 7356 len. 18]: `` See you , '' said madame , `` I care nothing for this Doctor , I .
Parsing [sent. 7357 len. 24]: He may wear his head or lose it , for any interest I have in him ; it is all one to me .
Parsing [sent. 7358 len. 23]: But , the Evremonde people are to be exterminated , and the wife and child must follow the husband and father . ''
Parsing [sent. 7359 len. 14]: `` She has a fine head for it , '' croaked Jacques Three .
Parsing [sent. 7360 len. 22]: `` I have seen blue eyes and golden hair there , and they looked charming when Samson held them up . ''
Parsing [sent. 7361 len. 11]: Ogre that he was , he spoke like an epicure .
Parsing [sent. 7362 len. 12]: Madame Defarge cast down her eyes , and reflected a little .
Parsing [sent. 7363 len. 26]: `` The child also , '' observed Jacques Three , with a meditative enjoyment of his words , `` has golden hair and blue eyes .
Parsing [sent. 7364 len. 8]: And we seldom have a child there .
Parsing [sent. 7365 len. 7]: It is a pretty sight ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7366 len. 28]: `` In a word , '' said Madame Defarge , coming out of her short abstraction , `` I can not trust my husband in this matter .
Parsing [sent. 7367 len. 47]: Not only do I feel , since last night , that I dare not confide to him the details of my projects ; but also I feel that if I delay , there is danger of his giving warning , and then they might escape . ''
Parsing [sent. 7368 len. 17]: `` That must never be , '' croaked Jacques Three ; `` no one must escape .
Parsing [sent. 7369 len. 9]: We have not half enough as it is .
Parsing [sent. 7370 len. 10]: We ought to have six score a day . ''
Parsing [sent. 7371 len. 39]: `` In a word , '' Madame Defarge went on , `` my husband has not my reason for pursuing this family to annihilation , and I have not his reason for regarding this Doctor with any sensibility .
Parsing [sent. 7372 len. 8]: I must act for myself , therefore .
Parsing [sent. 7373 len. 7]: Come hither , little citizen . ''
Parsing [sent. 7374 len. 29]: The wood-sawyer , who held her in the respect , and himself in the submission , of mortal fear , advanced with his hand to his red cap .
Parsing [sent. 7375 len. 36]: `` Touching those signals , little citizen , '' said Madame Defarge , sternly , `` that she made to the prisoners ; you are ready to bear witness to them this very day ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7376 len. 9]: `` Ay , ay , why not ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7377 len. 4]: cried the sawyer .
Parsing [sent. 7378 len. 25]: `` Every day , in all weathers , from two to four , always signalling , sometimes with the little one , sometimes without .
Parsing [sent. 7379 len. 6]: I know what I know .
Parsing [sent. 7380 len. 8]: I have seen with my eyes . ''
Parsing [sent. 7381 len. 30]: He made all manner of gestures while he spoke , as if in incidental imitation of some few of the great diversity of signals that he had never seen .
Parsing [sent. 7382 len. 9]: `` Clearly plots , '' said Jacques Three .
Parsing [sent. 7383 len. 4]: `` Transparently ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7384 len. 10]: `` There is no doubt of the Jury ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7385 len. 15]: inquired Madame Defarge , letting her eyes turn to him with a gloomy smile .
Parsing [sent. 7386 len. 10]: `` Rely upon the patriotic Jury , dear citizeness .
Parsing [sent. 7387 len. 9]: I answer for my fellow -- Jurymen . ''
Parsing [sent. 7388 len. 15]: `` Now , let me see , '' said Madame Defarge , pondering again .
Parsing [sent. 7389 len. 5]: `` Yet once more !
Parsing [sent. 7390 len. 9]: Can I spare this Doctor to my husband ?
Parsing [sent. 7391 len. 7]: I have no feeling either way .
Parsing [sent. 7392 len. 6]: Can I spare him ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7393 len. 18]: `` He would count as one head , '' observed Jacques Three , in a low voice .
Parsing [sent. 7394 len. 18]: `` We really have not heads enough ; it would be a pity , I think . ''
Parsing [sent. 7395 len. 47]: `` He was signalling with her when I saw her , '' argued Madame Defarge ; `` I can not speak of one without the other ; and I must not be silent , and trust the case wholly to him , this little citizen here .
Parsing [sent. 7396 len. 10]: For , I am not a bad witness . ''
Parsing [sent. 7397 len. 24]: The Vengeance and Jacques Three vied with each other in their fervent protestations that she was the most admirable and marvellous of witnesses .
Parsing [sent. 7398 len. 17]: The little citizen , not to be outdone , declared her to be a celestial witness .
Parsing [sent. 7399 len. 12]: `` He must take his chance , '' said Madame Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 7400 len. 9]: `` No , I can not spare him !
Parsing [sent. 7401 len. 18]: You are engaged at three o'clock ; you are going to see the batch of to-day executed .
Parsing [sent. 7402 len. 4]: -- You ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7403 len. 64]: The question was addressed to the wood-sawyer , who hurriedly replied in the affirmative : seizing the occasion to add that he was the most ardent of Republicans , and that he would be in effect the most desolate of Republicans , if anything prevented him from enjoying the pleasure of smoking his afternoon pipe in the contemplation of the droll national barber .
Parsing [sent. 7404 len. 51]: He was so very demonstrative herein , that he might have been suspected -LRB- perhaps was , by the dark eyes that looked contemptuously at him out of Madame Defarge 's head -RRB- of having his small individual fears for his own personal safety , every hour in the day .
Parsing [sent. 7405 len. 16]: `` I , '' said madame , `` am equally engaged at the same place .
Parsing [sent. 7406 len. 30]: After it is over-say at eight to-night -- come you to me , in Saint Antoine , and we will give information against these people at my Section . ''
Parsing [sent. 7407 len. 14]: The wood-sawyer said he would be proud and flattered to attend the citizeness .
Parsing [sent. 7408 len. 37]: The citizeness looking at him , he became embarrassed , evaded her glance as a small dog would have done , retreated among his wood , and hid his confusion over the handle of his saw .
Parsing [sent. 7409 len. 40]: Madame Defarge beckoned the Juryman and The Vengeance a little nearer to the door , and there expounded her further views to them thus : `` She will now be at home , awaiting the moment of his death .
Parsing [sent. 7410 len. 7]: She will be mourning and grieving .
Parsing [sent. 7411 len. 16]: She will be in a state of mind to impeach the justice of the Republic .
Parsing [sent. 7412 len. 10]: She will be full of sympathy with its enemies .
Parsing [sent. 7413 len. 7]: I will go to her . ''
Parsing [sent. 7414 len. 12]: `` What an admirable woman ; what an adorable woman ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7415 len. 6]: exclaimed Jacques Three , rapturously .
Parsing [sent. 7416 len. 7]: `` Ah , my cherished ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7417 len. 8]: cried The Vengeance ; and embraced her .
Parsing [sent. 7418 len. 31]: `` Take you my knitting , '' said Madame Defarge , placing it in her lieutenant 's hands , `` and have it ready for me in my usual seat .
Parsing [sent. 7419 len. 6]: Keep me my usual chair .
Parsing [sent. 7420 len. 20]: Go you there , straight , for there will probably be a greater concourse than usual , to-day . ''
Parsing [sent. 7421 len. 22]: `` I willingly obey the orders of my Chief , '' said The Vengeance with alacrity , and kissing her cheek .
Parsing [sent. 7422 len. 8]: `` You will not be late ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7423 len. 10]: `` I shall be there before the commencement . ''
Parsing [sent. 7424 len. 7]: `` And before the tumbrils arrive .
Parsing [sent. 7425 len. 34]: Be sure you are there , my soul , '' said The Vengeance , calling after her , for she had already turned into the street , `` before the tumbrils arrive ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7426 len. 40]: Madame Defarge slightly waved her hand , to imply that she heard , and might be relied upon to arrive in good time , and so went through the mud , and round the corner of the prison wall .
Parsing [sent. 7427 len. 28]: The Vengeance and the Juryman , looking after her as she walked away , were highly appreciative of her fine figure , and her superb moral endowments .
Parsing [sent. 7428 len. 43]: There were many women at that time , upon whom the time laid a dreadfully disfiguring hand ; but , there was not one among them more to be dreaded than this ruthless woman , now taking her way along the streets .
Parsing [sent. 7429 len. 60]: Of a strong and fearless character , of shrewd sense and readiness , of great determination , of that kind of beauty which not only seems to impart to its possessor firmness and animosity , but to strike into others an instinctive recognition of those qualities ; the troubled time would have heaved her up , under any circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 7430 len. 29]: But , imbued from her childhood with a brooding sense of wrong , and an inveterate hatred of a class , opportunity had developed her into a tigress .
Parsing [sent. 7431 len. 6]: She was absolutely without pity .
Parsing [sent. 7432 len. 18]: If she had ever had the virtue in her , it had quite gone out of her .
Parsing [sent. 7433 len. 29]: It was nothing to her , that an innocent man was to die for the sins of his forefathers ; she saw , not him , but them .
Parsing [sent. 7434 len. 45]: It was nothing to her , that his wife was to be made a widow and his daughter an orphan ; that was insufficient punishment , because they were her natural enemies and her prey , and as such had no right to live .
Parsing [sent. 7435 len. 20]: To appeal to her , was made hopeless by her having no sense of pity , even for herself .
Parsing [sent. 7436 len. 67]: If she had been laid low in the streets , in any of the many encounters in which she had been engaged , she would not have pitied herself ; nor , if she had been ordered to the axe to-morrow , would she have gone to it with any softer feeling than a fierce desire to change places with the man who sent here there .
Parsing [sent. 7437 len. 11]: Such a heart Madame Defarge carried under her rough robe .
Parsing [sent. 7438 len. 28]: Carelessly worn , it was a becoming robe enough , in a certain weird way , and her dark hair looked rich under her coarse red cap .
Parsing [sent. 7439 len. 11]: Lying hidden in her bosom , was a loaded pistol .
Parsing [sent. 7440 len. 11]: Lying hidden at her waist , was a sharpened dagger .
Parsing [sent. 7441 len. 48]: Thus accoutred , and walking with the confident tread of such a character , and with the supple freedom of a woman who had habitually walked in her girlhood , bare-foot and bare-legged , on the brown sea-sand , Madame Defarge took her way along the streets .
Parsing [sent. 7442 len. 45]: Now , when the journey of the travelling coach , at that very moment waiting for the completion of its load , had been planned out last night , the difficulty of taking Miss Pross in it had much engaged Mr. Lorry 's attention .
Parsing [sent. 7443 len. 53]: It was not merely desirable to avoid overloading the coach , but it was of the highest importance that the time occupied in examining it and its passengers , should be reduced to the utmost ; since their escape might depend on the saving of only a few seconds here and there .
Parsing [sent. 7444 len. 40]: Finally , he had proposed , after anxious consideration , that Miss Pross and Jerry , who were at liberty to leave the city , should leave it at three o'clock in the lightest-wheeled conveyance known to that period .
Parsing [sent. 7445 len. 51]: Unencumbered with luggage , they would soon overtake the coach , and , passing it and preceding it on the road , would order its horses in advance , and greatly facilitate its progress during the precious hours of the night , when delay was the most to be dreaded .
Parsing [sent. 7446 len. 22]: Seeing in this arrangement the hope of rendering real service in that pressing emergency , Miss Pross hailed it with joy .
Parsing [sent. 7447 len. 67]: She and Jerry had beheld the coach start , had known who it was that Solomon brought , had passed some ten minutes in tortures of suspense , and were now concluding their arrangements to follow the coach , even as Madame Defarge , taking her way through the streets , now drew nearer and nearer to the else-deserted lodging in which they held their consultation .
Parsing [sent. 7448 len. 48]: `` Now what do you think , Mr. Cruncher , '' said Miss Pross , whose agitation was so great that she could hardly speak , or stand , or move , or live : `` what do you think of our not starting from this courtyard ?
Parsing [sent. 7449 len. 15]: Another carriage having already gone from here to-day , it might awaken suspicion . ''
Parsing [sent. 7450 len. 18]: `` My opinion , miss , '' returned Mr. Cruncher , `` is as you 're right .
Parsing [sent. 7451 len. 13]: Likewise wot I 'll stand by you , right or wrong . ''
Parsing [sent. 7452 len. 32]: `` I am so distracted with fear and hope for our precious creatures , '' said Miss Pross , wildly crying , `` that I am incapable of forming any plan .
Parsing [sent. 7453 len. 15]: Are YOU capable of forming any plan , my dear good Mr. Cruncher ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7454 len. 22]: `` Respectin ' a future spear o ' life , miss , '' returned Mr. Cruncher , `` I hope so .
Parsing [sent. 7455 len. 20]: Respectin ' any present use o ' this here blessed old head o ' mind , I think not .
Parsing [sent. 7456 len. 32]: Would you do me the favour , miss , to take notice o ' two promises and wows wot it is my wishes fur to record in this here crisis ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7457 len. 8]: `` Oh , for gracious sake ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7458 len. 28]: cried Miss Pross , still wildly crying , `` record them at once , and get them out of the way , like an excellent man . ''
Parsing [sent. 7459 len. 48]: `` First , '' said Mr. Cruncher , who was all in a tremble , and who spoke with an ashy and solemn visage , `` them poor things well out o ' this , never no more will I do it , never no more ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7460 len. 45]: `` I am quite sure , Mr. Cruncher , '' returned Miss Pross , `` that you never will do it again , whatever it is , and I beg you not to think it necessary to mention more particularly what it is . ''
Parsing [sent. 7461 len. 18]: `` No , miss , '' returned Jerry , `` it shall not be named to you .
Parsing [sent. 7462 len. 29]: Second : them poor things well out o ' this , and never no more will I interfere with Mrs. Cruncher 's flopping , never no more ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7463 len. 42]: `` Whatever housekeeping arrangement that may be , '' said Miss Pross , striving to dry her eyes and compose herself , `` I have no doubt it is best that Mrs. Cruncher should have it entirely under her own superintendence .
Parsing [sent. 7464 len. 7]: -- O my poor darlings ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7465 len. 82]: `` I go so far as to say , miss , moreover , '' proceeded Mr. Cruncher , with a most alarming tendency to hold forth as from a pulpit -- `` and let my words be took down and took to Mrs. Cruncher through yourself -- that wot my opinions respectin ' flopping has undergone a change , and that wot I only hope with all my heart as Mrs. Cruncher may be a flopping at the present time . ''
Parsing [sent. 7466 len. 7]: `` There , there , there !
Parsing [sent. 7467 len. 28]: I hope she is , my dear man , '' cried the distracted Miss Pross , `` and I hope she finds it answering her expectations . ''
Parsing [sent. 7468 len. 49]: `` Forbid it , '' proceeded Mr. Cruncher , with additional solemnity , additional slowness , and additional tendency to hold forth and hold out , `` as anything wot I have ever said or done should be wisited on my earnest wishes for them poor creeturs now !
Parsing [sent. 7469 len. 26]: Forbid it as we should n't all flop -LRB- if it was anyways conwenient -RRB- to get 'em out o ' this here dismal risk !
Parsing [sent. 7470 len. 5]: Forbid it , miss !
Parsing [sent. 7471 len. 10]: Wot I say , for -- BID it ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7472 len. 18]: This was Mr. Cruncher 's conclusion after a protracted but vain endeavour to find a better one .
Parsing [sent. 7473 len. 17]: And still Madame Defarge , pursuing her way along the streets , came nearer and nearer .
Parsing [sent. 7474 len. 68]: `` If we ever get back to our native land , '' said Miss Pross , `` you may rely upon my telling Mrs. Cruncher as much as I may be able to remember and understand of what you have so impressively said ; and at all events you may be sure that I shall bear witness to your being thoroughly in earnest at this dreadful time .
