Parsing [sent. 7476 len. 10]: My esteemed Mr. Cruncher , let us think ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7477 len. 17]: Still , Madame Defarge , pursuing her way along the streets , came nearer and nearer .
Parsing [sent. 7478 len. 39]: `` If you were to go before , '' said Miss Pross , `` and stop the vehicle and horses from coming here , and were to wait somewhere for me ; would n't that be best ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7479 len. 8]: Mr. Cruncher thought it might be best .
Parsing [sent. 7480 len. 9]: `` Where could you wait for me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7481 len. 4]: asked Miss Pross .
Parsing [sent. 7482 len. 16]: Mr. Cruncher was so bewildered that he could think of no locality but Temple Bar .
Parsing [sent. 7483 len. 2]: Alas !
Parsing [sent. 7484 len. 17]: Temple Bar was hundreds of miles away , and Madame Defarge was drawing very near indeed .
Parsing [sent. 7485 len. 11]: `` By the cathedral door , '' said Miss Pross .
Parsing [sent. 7486 len. 26]: `` Would it be much out of the way , to take me in , near the great cathedral door between the two towers ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7487 len. 10]: `` No , miss , '' answered Mr. Cruncher .
Parsing [sent. 7488 len. 27]: `` Then , like the best of men , '' said Miss Pross , `` go to the posting-house straight , and make that change . ''
Parsing [sent. 7489 len. 25]: `` I am doubtful , '' said Mr. Cruncher , hesitating and shaking his head , `` about leaving of you , you see .
Parsing [sent. 7490 len. 9]: We do n't know what may happen . ''
Parsing [sent. 7491 len. 20]: `` Heaven knows we do n't , '' returned Miss Pross , `` but have no fear for me .
Parsing [sent. 7492 len. 33]: Take me in at the cathedral , at Three o'Clock , or as near it as you can , and I am sure it will be better than our going from here .
Parsing [sent. 7493 len. 6]: I feel certain of it .
Parsing [sent. 7494 len. 2]: There !
Parsing [sent. 7495 len. 6]: Bless you , Mr. Cruncher !
Parsing [sent. 7496 len. 17]: Think-not of me , but of the lives that may depend on both of us ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7497 len. 20]: This exordium , and Miss Pross 's two hands in quite agonised entreaty clasping his , decided Mr. Cruncher .
Parsing [sent. 7498 len. 28]: With an encouraging nod or two , he immediately went out to alter the arrangements , and left her by herself to follow as she had proposed .
Parsing [sent. 7499 len. 21]: The having originated a precaution which was already in course of execution , was a great relief to Miss Pross .
Parsing [sent. 7500 len. 22]: The necessity of composing her appearance so that it should attract no special notice in the streets , was another relief .
Parsing [sent. 7501 len. 14]: She looked at her watch , and it was twenty minutes past two .
Parsing [sent. 7502 len. 14]: She had no time to lose , but must get ready at once .
Parsing [sent. 7503 len. 48]: Afraid , in her extreme perturbation , of the loneliness of the deserted rooms , and of half-imagined faces peeping from behind every open door in them , Miss Pross got a basin of cold water and began laving her eyes , which were swollen and red .
Parsing [sent. 7504 len. 42]: Haunted by her feverish apprehensions , she could not bear to have her sight obscured for a minute at a time by the dripping water , but constantly paused and looked round to see that there was no one watching her .
Parsing [sent. 7505 len. 21]: In one of those pauses she recoiled and cried out , for she saw a figure standing in the room .
Parsing [sent. 7506 len. 19]: The basin fell to the ground broken , and the water flowed to the feet of Madame Defarge .
Parsing [sent. 7507 len. 20]: By strange stern ways , and through much staining blood , those feet had come to meet that water .
Parsing [sent. 7508 len. 21]: Madame Defarge looked coldly at her , and said , `` The wife of Evremonde ; where is she ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7509 len. 21]: It flashed upon Miss Pross 's mind that the doors were all standing open , and would suggest the flight .
Parsing [sent. 7510 len. 8]: Her first act was to shut them .
Parsing [sent. 7511 len. 13]: There were four in the room , and she shut them all .
Parsing [sent. 7512 len. 15]: She then placed herself before the door of the chamber which Lucie had occupied .
Parsing [sent. 7513 len. 21]: Madame Defarge 's dark eyes followed her through this rapid movement , and rested on her when it was finished .
Parsing [sent. 7514 len. 49]: Miss Pross had nothing beautiful about her ; years had not tamed the wildness , or softened the grimness , of her appearance ; but , she too was a determined woman in her different way , and she measured Madame Defarge with her eyes , every inch .
Parsing [sent. 7515 len. 23]: `` You might , from your appearance , be the wife of Lucifer , '' said Miss Pross , in her breathing .
Parsing [sent. 7516 len. 12]: `` Nevertheless , you shall not get the better of me .
Parsing [sent. 7517 len. 6]: I am an Englishwoman . ''
Parsing [sent. 7518 len. 24]: Madame Defarge looked at her scornfully , but still with something of Miss Pross 's own perception that they two were at bay .
Parsing [sent. 7519 len. 34]: She saw a tight , hard , wiry woman before her , as Mr. Lorry had seen in the same figure a woman with a strong hand , in the years gone by .
Parsing [sent. 7520 len. 29]: She knew full well that Miss Pross was the family 's devoted friend ; Miss Pross knew full well that Madame Defarge was the family 's malevolent enemy .
Parsing [sent. 7521 len. 47]: `` On my way yonder , '' said Madame Defarge , with a slight movement of her hand towards the fatal spot , `` where they reserve my chair and my knitting for me , I am come to make my compliments to her in passing .
